chapters.title: Chapter 1
chapters.content:
The wind howled, cutting through my ears like a blade. The whites and greys of the storm blinded my sight. I clutched my bad arm, wincing with each step from the pain of the fall. The fall hadn’t broken my arm, yet the pain was only magnified by the bleak winds that surrounded me. I wore clothes suited for the Northern summer, not whatever frigid climate I was dropped in. Would this be my undug grave? Would anyone even find me here? I shivered violently at the thought. The overbearing wind only howled in response, clouding my thoughts.

I trudged forward through the snow stubbornly, leaving knee deep footprints. The deep snow made each step a battle, a war I could not endure forever. The snow climbed up deep into my trousers, and the cold sank deep into my bones. The fog clung to the landscape like a thick veil, leaving the world in a shade of white and blue. I had to keep moving, for if I stopped, I would not be able to pick myself up again.

As the winds slowed down, my mind cleared with it. To my left I could just make out the rocky cliffside of a mountain. I did not know how I got on that mountain, but I did know I had to keep moving forward until something—anything—happened. Deep down, I knew no one would find me here, that even if there were people on this miserable mountain, they would not find me in this storm.

Panic surged momentarily, but I forced it down. Panic would do nothing, I shifted my focus on trying to find cover, maybe a rock or small crevice that I could hide behind. My blood threatened to simply freeze, and my limbs groaned with each move. Still hope whispered in my ears—if I was thrown out here, it must have been for some reason. If my abductor wanted to kill me, they could’ve done it already.

My feet began to numb and lose any sensation, I tried to run but with the deep snow, I only tripped face first. As I stumbled through the snow, the pain in my arm only got worse with each passing step. I wanted to scream, but nature would not hear my cries, would not gain any satisfaction nor hate. I kept trudging through the snow, praying for some semblance of humanity on this dreaded, frozen mountain.

The cold sliced at my eyes, my vision worsening, each breath was agony. In my delirium, the streaks of gray and white merged into a surreal canvas. I saw fleeting shapes, not of the warm embrace of family nor the comfort of home, but something else, strange faces, distant landscapes I’d never visited, faces I didn’t recognize, places I hadn’t yet been.

I do not know how long I laid there in the snow. My breath slowed, time blurred, and the snow pressed against my body. My breath came in short gasps, oxygen a blessing to come by. I closed my eyes, not to sleep, not to dream, but since there was nothing more to see, nothing left to take. This would be my resting place, maybe I—

Pain shot up my ribs as a heavy boot struck me, not hard enough to break anything, but enough to jolt my body into motion. I gasped, snow spraying from my lips.

“Oi, what the hell are ye doin’ out here kid”

The voice was ragged, angry, but human. I blinked through the snow, eyes bleary, I saw a man wrapped in thick furs, face shadowed by his hood.

He crouched down until I could barely make out his face, he squinted and looked me up and down.

“You ain’t dead yet, are ya?”

The man muttered something incoherent under his breath, then reached down and grabbed me by the collar, dragging me to my feet roughly.

“Damn bloody fool, you’re lucky I found ya.”

Praise the Light. I didn’t feel lucky, but I was alive.

chapters.title: Chapter 2
chapters.content:
“The name’s Faux, what’s yours?”

I opened my mouth, lips barely moving “Rand’ar.”

He grunted in response and pulled out a blanket made of animal hide from his large pack. The blanket was lined with age and stiff from the cold, its edges frayed and thin.

“Here, wrap this around yourself kid”, he said, his face turning to mine. The warmth of the blanket felt like a sweet respite—it felt like a mercy.

The man’s age was hard to determine just by looking at his face, hooded as it was. His features seemed to shift with every glance, he could have been in his late twenties, or perhaps somewhere in his forties. He had a disheveled beard, barely three inches long, which gave a rough, unkempt look, yet the shape of his jaw was strongly defined, betraying youthful vitality. A pale scar ran down from his right eye down to the corner of his lip, twisting every time he spoke. His expression was guarded, as if unsure of what to do with me, so I made things easy for him.

“Where are we going?”, I asked, my voice hoarse, barely above a whisper.

“Ye gotta speak up, can barely hear shit in this wind” he replied without sparing a glance at me.

“I said, where are we going?”, I repeated, louder this time and slightly irritated.

“Somewhere warmer than this. It’s easier to just show you” he said, not easing my fears, but I continued walking with him. What choice did I really have?

“It ain’t much further from here”, he added. My feet had turned to jelly, snow was packed deep into my trousers, my legs had gone so cold, I could hardly even notice it anymore.

“How do you even know where we’re going? I can’t see shit”, I asked, my tone casual, but I was watching him carefully. If he really knew this terrain, I needed to know how. If I had to run or hide, I’d need some idea of where we were, or where he might take me.

He didn’t answer right away, as if formulating his answer, just kept walking through the snow with an air of confidence.

“There’s markings on the stones or some of the trees. Can’t see ‘em unless ya know what to look for.”

Our path veered to the left, I was careful to make a mental image of the location. There were orange markings marked in a nearby rock. I slowed just a little as we passed the rock, letting my eyes linger on the markings. Faded orange paint, two slashes intersected by a horizontal line. Quick, deliberate, and almost easy to miss if you weren’t looking for it.

“I got separated from my group. They must be looking for me”, I said, lying through my teeth.

“They better find shelter soon then, else they’ll be dead before they find ya”, he replied without looking at me. He didn’t sound convinced, I couldn’t blame him, my bewildered state and summer clothes was telling. But if he doubted me, his face never betrayed it.

The fog pressed in close, a wall of white that surrounded us, I made sure to keep close to Faux.. My legs, which had turned to jelly, somehow kept moving. Each step felt like lifting a stone, and each breath inhaled icy air that pierced my lungs.

The hill soon flattened out and I could see other footprints ahead of us. Not as deep as ours, the snow had filled them in. Wherever Faux was taking me, we were close to it.

The path widened greatly and through the thick curtain of mist I saw the silhouette of a tremendous gate. Two pillars of turquoise and white, adorned with hints of gold rising out of the mists like sentinels. Between them hung a massive portcullis, its iron teeth rusted but still imposing, suspended just above the path. Looming above the gate was a watchtower, its whites and grays almost invisible in the fog. The gate must have been two or three times Faux’s height, who was a head and a half taller than me. Above in the watchtower, I could see figures moving behind the slitted windows. Faux raised a hand and made a quick gesture I couldn’t catch, and after a moment, the gate creaked to life and slowly lifted.

“We’ve a doctor in the lower grounds, she’ll fix ya up, then you’ll be on yer way” Faux said, the sounds of the chains pulling the portcullis rattling in the background.

I lingered for a moment under the gate. If I went through the gate, I’d be in their hands—whoever those people were. But no other choice presented itself, I’d be dead within the hour out there in the storm. And who knows where my abductors were, or what they really wanted. Why drop me here of all places? Why leave me alive?

Faux couldn’t answer those questions, and I didn’t trust him enough to ask. So I stood there, the portcullis yawning above me like a jaw of iron teeth. I wondered how long it’d been since I was taken from home. Hours? Days?

I must have looked like a fool standing under the gate for so long. Faux had already started walking forward toward what looked like a small village. I followed after him before I lost him in the thick fog.

The settlement was underwhelming after the massive gate. A handful of stone buildings huddled close to one another, their rooftops heavy with snow and their chimneys coughing out trails of smoke. There was a main path leading further uphill hidden behind thick fog but we turned into a smaller alley. The alley was tight and uneven, worn by weather and footsteps. There were no signs, no stalls, but Faux knew exactly where to go.

We stopped in front of a two storey building with a dark wooden door. The building looked older than most I’d seen so far, there weren’t many windows, one side made entirely of gray bricks, devoid of any charm, lacking the grandeur of the gate we’d seen.

Faux knocked three times before the doctor finally opened the door. I expected an old man given the withered building, but a woman in what appeared to be her mid-thirties opened it. She had a serious, worn look about her, like someone who'd seen too many patients too far gone to save.

She gave me a once-over, then sighed through her nose. “What have you dragged in this time, Faux?”

“A straggler”, he said. “Claims he got separated by his group on the mountain.”

She raised an eyebrow. “And you believed that?”

“I didn’t say that,” Faux replied, brushing past her. “He’s frostbitten in both hands, maybe his feet too. Right arm’s useless, probably sprained, maybe worse. He needs heat, salve, and whatever you’ve got for the shakes.”

She sighed and then stepped aside without another word, already turning toward a cluttered shelf of supplies. “I hope you’re not expecting a miracle.”

“I’m expecting him not to die in yer doorway.” Faux said. “He’s gotta be in one piece when he sees Lord Astaron.”

The doctor stilled for half a second, then gave a quiet, almost imperceptible sigh. Her eyes flicked to me, more curious now than concerned.

“Right”, she said, grabbing a cloth and a tin from a nearby shelf. “I’ll keep him breathing.”

Faux had already walked out by then, the door left open and the cold wind poisoned the room with sharp air.

“Shut the door and sit down here will you?”, the doctor said as she pulled out a rickety wooden chair.

I shut the door behind me, sealing out the storm. A serene silence filled the room, I unwrapped the blanket Faux gave me earlier, the decrepit thing had kept me alive. The chair creaked as I lowered myself into it, every joint in my body protesting. The doctor worked in silence, her hands quick and practiced, dabbing warmth into frozen skin, wrapping my arm without asking too many questions.

I didn’t ask any either, I had my own worries to sort through. A Lord Astaron was waiting.

chapters.title: Chapter 3
chapters.content:
“I don’t know how you survived honestly”, Doctor Oroya said as she brewed a pot of coffee. The steam curled around her face, softening her otherwise stern expression.

“You should have died within the hour, even if Faux did find you, you should’ve been frozen, but you walked in here. Summer clothes, no gear, yet you were moving out and about”, she shook her head, almost disbelieving my recounting of what happened. I hadn’t told her about the kidnapping, unsure why. Maybe it didn’t matter by then.

“Either you’re absurdly lucky, or someone up there’s looking out for you”, she poured a cup and offered it to me.

“I don’t drink coffee”, I muttered.

“Suit yourself,” she said, setting it down with a shrug.

I rubbed the sleep from my eyes. I had slept for so long after the day before's misadventures, too long almost. I remembered her tending to me the night before, muttering to herself as she tenderly removed my soaked clothes. She wrapped my bad arm, checked my hands, and made me drink something bitter but warm that brought me back to life. Then she handed me a folded set of clothes and pointed me to a room on the second floor to sleep in. I don’t even remember lying down, only the warmth and fuzzy feeling of wearing new clothes.

A servant girl made breakfast in the kitchen, she must have been a Marshin. She looked younger than me, yet she worked meticulously. I felt a pang of shame just looking at her, me wrapped in clean clothes, being tended to, her toiling in servitude at such a young age. We were the same, yet our lives were so far apart, I could never feel her struggle.

“I do warn you, Rand'ar, speak the truth when you stand before Lord Astaron. He’ll see through lies before you finish breathing them. That expedition tale of yours won’t hold for long.”

She paused, her eyes looking into her mug, as if the coffee was particularly interesting.

“You don’t have to tell me what happened, but tell him—do it for yourself. You can’t have happened here by accident…”, she trailed off. Her eyes were distant, insinuating, like I’d faked my injuries, my story to get into this place. That I was sent here with an agenda. How could I tell her or this Astaron my real story without seeming even more ridiculous. I just happened to be kidnapped and dropped on one of your scouts paths, how convenient. They’d never believe me.

And who was this Lord Astaron, anyway? Why was a meager village guarded by such a grand gate? Was this man seriously calling himself the lord of this place? The man certainly had a taste for theatrics.

“Then why’d you save me?”, I asked, a hint of irritation in my voice. I could not bring myself to look at her.

“I’m a doctor, my job is to help people, it doesn’t matter who you are or where you’re from.” She reached out and placed a hand on my arm, “And I’m still trying to help you here”,

“How can I even explain it to you? You wouldn’t believe me even if I told you the truth.” I almost shouted, and reminded by the servant girl’s presence, lowered my voice.

Doctor Oroya didn’t flinch. She just crossed her arms, watching me with a soft expression.

“I’m not asking you to trust me,” she said. “But shouting won’t change where you are. And pretending none of this happened won’t get you home.”

The girl brought out our breakfast and retreated before anyone said anything. The doctor was indifferent to her, but the girl’s presence felt intrusive in our conversation.

“Start by eating, then tell me everything you know, and we’ll see from there.”

So I did—everything that I knew, from the faceless mask of my captor looming in the dark, to the cold metal of the blade at my neck. I told her about waking up in the snow, alone, freezing, my arm barely moving. About the storm. Faux. The gate.

My story must have been incoherent to her, yet she listened quietly the whole time, her face unchanging. I didn’t try to shape my story in any way, just the hard truth.

The room was quiet for a while after I finished, only the storm howling outside, it hadn’t settled yet. Doctor Oroya hadn’t touched her breakfast, but I was almost done by the time I finished recounting my tale.

I finished my meal and we sat there quietly for a while. She opened her mouth to speak a couple of times, but something stopped her. Eventually she settled on a question.

“Why you?”

“I’ve been asking myself that, this whole time. I told you everything I know. Where are we anyway? The Belt?”,

If I was a plant, I’d already know.

“Southeastern edge of the Belt,” she said finally. “At least two days from anything resembling civilization, even if you know where you’re going.” She paused, “Do you even have the money for it?”

I had no money, and no papers. I tried to jog my memory of the geography of the area. I’d need to take a boat around the Belt, since going through was not an option. The mountains were impossible to scale the closer you go to the centre of the Belt. And a boat was laughable in my current state, no papers, no stamp of approval. I was just another Marshin to them, I’d get whipped and sold off so fast I wouldn’t be able to say my name.

“No I don’t just keep money in my pockets while sleeping, don’t really expect kidnappers every night ya know?” I replied dryly.

“Well, maybe you should”, she said with a faint smirk, the closest thing to a joke I’d hear from her.

I could tell she had more questions but she decided not to press on, but instead handed me a mop and told me to make myself useful. My back was hurting within minutes, and I was dragging more water around than I was cleaning up. We had servants for these sorts of things back home.

Eventually, with a sharp sigh and a muttered curse I didn’t catch, she snatched the mop out of my hands with more force than necessary and all but shoved me toward the hallway. I made my way back to the room she’d given me the night before, sat on the edge of the cot, and waited. When the storm cleared, Astaron would call for me.

The call came sooner than I expected. Faux was at the door, he’d brought some proper clothes. A thick, wool-lined coat in a deep slate gray, clearly made for someone broader than me, hung past my knees and made my arms look even thinner than they were. The sleeves swallowed my hands. The boots were sturdy leather, worn but warm, and rose halfway up my calves. They clunked awkwardly with each step, like a child playing dress-up in his father’s armor. I must’ve looked ridiculous, but I wasn’t about to complain. Warmth outweighed pride that afternoon.

I said my goodbyes to Doctor Oroya and thanked her in case I didn’t see her again, and we set off. The sky was bright that day, the clouds mostly dissipated. The narrow alley was a lot less sinister without the fog. We turned onto the main path, and I was able to take in the view of the surrounding mountains. Beyond the village, rising like twin monoliths, were two jagged peaks. The one to the left arched slightly inward near its summit, as though it had bent forward over centuries to whisper secrets to its smaller sister. The other rose straight and proud, its powerful face only broken by lines of stone.

Looking back down toward the gate, I saw the valley unfold in breathtaking silence. A vast, snowy basin stretched far below, flanked on both sides by towering ranges, their backs covered in brilliant white. Thousands of dark green pines clung to the slopes, the scale of it all made the village a speck in a grand painting.

“Listen, err, Rand’ar, ya gotta be real with Lord Astaron, he ain’t gonna believe yer expedition bullshit”, Faux said, his tone casual, but eyes sharp. “Man’s seen enough to see through your lies before ya breathe. You try to spin him a tale, and he won’t call you out, he’ll just stop listenin’. And when that happens, yer gonna wish he had called you out.”

He adjusted the sheath on his belt. The hilt was a deep navy blue, wrapped tightly for grip, and capped with bronze fittings. I couldn’t help but wonder what he needed a sword for out here in the mountains.

He glanced once more at me, “Look you don’t gotta tell me what yer story is, and I don’t care to know it ‘less you want to tell it. But whatever you do, don’t insult his time.”

I wasn’t sure if he was trying to give me or he was serious, but I had decided to just tell Astaron the truth.

The path winded uphill as we went through the village, and began to widen fast. We came upon a grand set of stairs. Each step was carved from a dark stone. At the top, was another looming gate. The gate we had seen earlier paled in comparison. Its frame was built from veined marble, reinforced with metal bands. Massive, spiked hinges held two towering doors that looked like they could hold back armies.

Halfway up the staircase, nestled in a cutout in the stone, sat an immense boulder, rugged and gray. Dozens of swords had been driven into it, their hilts protruding like a forest of forgotten battles. It looked ceremonial or ritualistic in nature, each blade must’ve told a story.

The gate was left ajar, the keepers were expecting us. The sun blinded my eyes so I couldn’t see beyond the gap. I stepped through anyway

chapters.title: Chapter 4
chapters.content:
Divine, it must have been, for no man could have pictured such a place nestled deep in the mountains. Beyond the gate was a structure that defied simple classification, a castle—no—a temple, for it was regal.

The central courtyard stretched far and wide, paved with slate stones darkened by snowmelt. Two massive buildings flanked either side, mirror images of each other—long, formidable halls of dark stone and lacquered timber, their roofs pitched steeply against the snowfall. Tall windows lined their walls, most shuttered or barred, and banners of deep blue and bronze hung still in the thin mountain air. They bore the severity of a fortress with the elegance of a sanctuary.

Their architecture was tiered, rising in layers with ridged gables that flared outwards like the wings of a great beast. The roofs were layered with snow and the ice clung to the gable edges. Each drip had frozen mid-fall, forming long icicles that glittered in the pale light.

Wide wooden doors, reinforced with iron studs, were spaced at regular intervals along their length. The silence was serene, save for the faint rustle of banners that draped down along the walls, some of which had frozen mid-flutter in the mountain air.

Straight across the gate, on the far side of the intimidating courtyard was a tower that pierced the sky. The tower soared far above the rest of the keep, a six-sided colossus shaped unlike anything I’d ever seen. Each of its sides curved gently inward, giving the tower an imposing figure. It rose up, tier by tier, balconies on each level, railings decorated with ornamental patterns. Each level crowned with a wide, sweeping roof that curled at the edges, and snow blanketed each ledge. It didn’t look built, it looked conjured.

I assumed we would be meeting Lord Astaron in the great tower, but Faux turned left toward one of the vast halls that bordered the courtyard.

“The big man isn’t up there?” I asked Faux.

“Nah, he’s usually down here, with the men”, he replied without looking back.

“Are these some sort of training grounds?”, I asked.

“You could say that”, he said, not slowing his pace.

Before I could stop myself, I said, “You’re building an army here, aren’t you?”

He gave a faint smile, pausing for a moment, to spare a glance at me, “Sharp one, aren’t ya?”

Despite my peril, the situation was galvanizing, sparking something fierce within me. What a place I was in, tucked away in some corner of the world, shrouded by veils of snow, cradled by mountains. Each step forward strengthened me for the confrontation ahead.

Faux made his way to one of the wooden doors and slid it open with a single hand, the motion was fluid but noticeably one sided, betraying an injury in his other hand. We stepped inside and took off our boots. Immediately, I heard the shouting and holler of a fight.

“Every damn mornin’ with these idiots”, Faux muttered to himself, stomping towards the noise.

We turned into a large candle lit chamber, the noise swelling as the door creaked open. At its center lay a sunken dueling platform, circular, with two short steps leading down from the stone floor. The flickering candlelight cast long shadows across the walls, dancing over the eager faces of a dozen young men who stood around the edge, watching intently at the two dueling below.

A duel would be too dignified a word, for what unfolded before us was no such thing. This was a brawl in its rawest form, a one-sided thrashing paraded as sport. The stockier of the two boys was getting his arse handed to him. Yet it seemed like the onlookers were cheering for him, “STUBBY, STUBBY”, they chanted.

If they were naming them based on body type, then the other one should’ve been called ‘Lithey’ or maybe ‘Spindle’. He moved like a whip, and hit like one too. He dodged and weaved Stubby’s lethargic uncoordinated punches with graceful ease. I tried to squeeze between the other onlookers to get a better look, but they wouldn’t budge, so I stood on top of a nearby stool.

Stubby threw a wild punch at Spindle, putting all the force his squat little frame could muster, but Spindle was already out of reach, leaving him swinging mid air. Stubby was panting by then, already out of breath, but Swindle was just getting started. He ran at Stubby before he could get his breath back, closed the distance in a flush, ducking Stubby’s late swing, and slammed his shoulder into Stubby’s gut. The impact knocked the wind out of him, and before Stubby could react, Swindle had hooked a leg behind his knee and twisted. The larger boy toppled like a felled tree, crashing hard into the platform. The crowd was roaring by now.

Faux finally stepped in, he must’ve been interested in the fight too, but it had gone too far, and the winner was evident. One moment Faux was standing next to me behind the rest of the crowd, and the next he was between Stubby and Swindle, tearing them apart.

“Do I gotta break up a new fight every goddamn day”, Faux roared. The crowd went silent, shrinking behind his anger. Stubby was slumped on one knee, clutching his side, while Swindle stood over him. “You all want Orem finding out? ‘Member what happened last week?”

“Wait Faux wait, it was just for fun, no one got hurt”, one of the other boys pleaded. Stubby shot him a glare, clutching his ribs.

“Besides, Stubby’s the one who started it, he was just frustrated after Orem put him outside for ‘missing a spot’ on the table. You know how Orem gets, he’s looking for a reason to keep us freezing,” some of them snickered at that, and Stubby shot him glares, but Faux was unimpressed. He walked over to the boy, and narrowed his eyes.

“Oh? Then I’ll be sure to let Orem know you’ve got some things to say” Faux said coolly. “I’m sure he’d love to hear yer thoughts on his teaching.”

“I’m sorry sir”, the boy replied, terrified of whatever Orem might have in store.

Faux drew in a slow breath and faced the rest of the crowd. “You’re all brothers now, nothing can change that, you instigate Tommy here to fight, so that you can all have a laugh, but what do you think happens out on the field. They’ll cut ya down if you don't stand together like a pack. When one falls—”

He stepped forward, reached down, and hauled Stubby to his feet with one hand. The boy winced, but didn’t resist.

“When one falls,” Faux continued, his voice lowered, “you pick them up and get them to their feet, and ya get right back at the bastards who dropped them.”

He took another long pause before saying, “Better not see any more infighting after this.”

A silent weight fell over the room, whatever heat had been in the room moments ago had dissipated, replaced by a quiet understanding. No one dared to meet Faux’s gaze. It was not out of fear, but something close. The boys slowly filed out, drifting off to whatever duties or drills awaited them.

“Rand’ar, to me. Astaron’s waiting”, he said, arms crossed while leaning on the door.

We walked further down the hall and up two sets of stairs before we came across a wide, high-ceilinged chamber. The room was colder than the last, the walls of stone echoed the heavy movements. The floor was covered in thick, straw-colored mats, worn down from years of grinding feet and spilt blood.

A group of men, no older than their mid twenties, were spaced out in pairs, fencing with wooden swords. Their clothes were torn, smeared with dirt and dried blood, and fresh bruises blossomed across exposed skin. They circled around each other defensively, aiming to pierce their opponents guard, each swing deliberate and controlled.

There was no laughter here like the younger group. It was a grim sight, every man stood for power. Their movements were disciplined yet thoughtful. One man fell to his knees after a brutal hit to the ribs, his opponent didn’t hesitate and drove his sword into the fallen man’s guts. Two other men moved the unconscious body to the side without ceremony, leaving him slumped against the wall like a piece of broken gear.

At the front of the group stood a man older than the rest, older than Faux even, his stance and posture impeccable. A swordmaster, clearly, he spoke little, letting the rhythm of the routine guide the training. This wasn’t mild sparring, this was the training of an elite group of warriors.

“Is that Lord Astaron?” I asked Faux, nodding toward the swordmaster. His left sleeve betrayed that he had only one arm. I wondered how a man with one arm could become a swordmaster.

“No, that’s Hurbasa, the Sabelir. Astaron’s up there”, Faux said, gesturing toward a balcony that wrapped around the perimeter of the chamber. I followed his gaze.

Astaron stood in the centre of the balcony above. His robes were dark, a deep, saturated navy veined with threads of crimson. Though we were indoors, the robes were thick and heavy, lined with black fur around the collar and cuffs, a reminder of the mountain chill that surrounded us.

In his left hand, he held a long intricately crafted wooden staff, almost as tall as he was. He planted it firmly on the floor. not as a crutch, but perhaps a marker of presence. He didn’t lean on it, he didn’t need to. Unlike the sight below, his manner and clothing were pristine yet there was an undeniable weight to him.

I followed Faux up the steps, my heart was throbbing in my chest, each step reminding me of what awaited at the top. If I failed here, I’d be discarded like the unconscious man thrown to the side, except I’d be dead. Lord Astaron stood still and absolute, his focus on the chamber below. The staff at his side stood like a pillar, anchoring him to the ground. Two men flanked his sides.

“Rand’ar”, he said without turning back. “How has the Mountain been treating you?”

The question threw me off guard, I paused for a moment and looked at Faux, who simply nodded as if to say yer gonna be fine kid.

“It’s cold, to say the least,” I replied, trying to keep my voice steady.

Astaron let out a low chuckle, still facing the training floor, “A fair answer. Nature is honest that way, it reveals its force without warning and without prejudice.”

He finally turned to face me, his face a mask of stone and reticence, “Faux informs me you spent nearly an hour in the storm, dressed for spring and lacking any form of protection, yet you survived. What a curious thing, wouldn’t you say?”

Whatever form of ease he seemed to bring was gone in an instant, yet his expression did not betray anger, or even suspicion. His face—and voice, betrayed nothing, he was simply asking a question, and he expected a simple answer. But I did not have a simple answer, not then.

“I swear to you on everything I do not know. I don’t know how I got here, I was taken from my home in the dead of night. One instant I was asleep, the next I was being dragged out of my bed, something must’ve hit me—hard—and everything went black.

“When I woke up, I was lying in snow, in the middle of the storm, freezing, with nothing. I don’t know why they brought me here and I don’t know why they even did this. I just want to see my family again, I’ll forget I was ever here.”

“That’s not how this works boy,” he said evenly, voice as flat as his stony expression. “Deception won’t help you get back home. Tell me, boy,” he spat out, heavy with disdain. “By whose design were you sent here, and with what purpose?”

I tried to stammer out a response, but nothing came out. My judgement was clouded. All sense of confidence had vanished, my legs shook beneath me. The doctor had warned me—Faux too—what would happen if Lord Astaron was dissatisfied by my answer.

And so it had come, the drift of death, creeping into the edges of my thoughts. The walls, despite being so far apart, all closed in on me, and my head was on fire, possibilities going through my mind, things I could have done differently.

“I wasn’t sent, I was taken, I don’t even know where here is. And I don’t really care to find out” I uttered desperately.

“You don’t seem to understand, no one just strolls through here by accident. Never mind who sent you here. I will ask you only one more time, how did you find this place?”

My throat tightened, I had no reasonable answer to give, so I stayed silent. I was too far in to start spewing lies.

“Nothing to say? Fine, take him to the well,” he motioned to the two men on his sides.

Rough hands seized my arms. I struggled and flailed but could not loosen their grip. They simply picked me up from my arms and dragged me away.

I turned my head to get one last glimpse at Lord Astaron, “Silence will be your companion for the night—if you don’t freeze over first. We shall see when you’re ready to talk.”

I drove my feet into the ground to stop my jailers, but one of them dug the hilt of his sword into my head. A dull crack burst across my skull. My heels scraped across the rough floor, leaving streaks in the frost that clung to the floor.

They dragged me outside to the back of the building to an old stone well. The stones were etiolating, ice seeped into every crack. Cold rope bit into my wrists, tighter with every pull, until my fingers throbbed and went numb.

I thrashed violently to loosen the grip of the rope, but to no avail. The only thing I was met with was a fist to the gut, stealing the breath from my lungs.

“Let him learn silence down there,” one of them muttered, before shoving me forward toward the well. Before I knew it, I was pummeling down towards the dark pit at the bottom. I was weightless for a moment before the world slammed me down into the chilly stiff stone—no—ice. The water was frozen of course.

I looked up at the circle of light above. One of them peered down, laughed, then cut the rope. It fell in a heap at my feet.

I clawed at the stone wall, desperate to climb, but my hands found nothing. I slipped, cracked my head against the wall on the way down. Darkness swallowed me whole.

The cold gnawed at my throat, working its way into the confines of my insides. Each breath was a sharp knife to my nose, the air so sharp it hurt to see. The dull throb in my head made it hard to stay awake, I could feel myself slipping. The ropes only cut deeper into my wrists as I moved around.

Every part of me screamed to lie down, give in, and pray death came fast and swift.

But something deeper wouldn't let me. Keep going, Rand'ar. You're a Marshin. There's still fight left in you.

I sat up slowly and felt along the stone wall until I found a sharp edge of rock.

Hours—or maybe just one—slipped by as I worked desperately, sawing at the rope against the edge of the stone, each movement cutting further into my wrists. The bindings cut into my wrists, leaving them raw and bleeding. But eventually, the rope fell away.

Later, something plopped onto my head. A bag. Inside: stale bread and gloves. I ate slowly, grateful for whoever had thrown it down.

The small act of kindness steeled me in that forsaken place, I was committed to seeing it through. I vowed to myself that if they did cut me down, I would stand valiant and proud. In that moment, I prepared myself for what was to come, I steadied my breath, quieted the tremble in my hands, and buried the fear deep where no one would see it. I put on my own mask of iron, I would not flinch at the first chance of death if it came.

chapters.title: Chapter 5
chapters.content:
I could not sleep that night. No, the cold and brittle dark hollowed me out. I sat up against the wall hugging my knees and could only think. Oh how I missed home, my family, in that wretched pit.

I sat in the darkness for hours. My mother used to sing about this—The Abyss—the endless dark that swallows desperate men clinging to death. I’d always thought it was just a story to scare children into behaving. Alone in that well, I almost wished it was real. At least floating through darkness would be better than that dilapidated well.

Every few hours, someone would throw down some food. Stale bread, hard cheese, dried meat, always accompanied with water. I would gulp it down before it ever reached the bottom it seemed, yet it was never enough. The hunger was unending, it was all that consumed my mind.

It must have been a full day before a rope was thrown down at me, and a deep gruff voice commanded me to grab on.

So I did. I wrapped my arms and legs around the rope and held on for dear life. The overwhelming light from the setting sky blinded me as I crested over the top. I toppled onto the floor and immediately a rag was put over my head, my wrists and ankles bound in chains, and I was picked up in one full swoop.

The cold wind bit at me as I was carried, far sharper than the damp chill of the dark well I’d spent the night in. The air grew denser, less biting, carrying the faint scent of wood and dry earth. I couldn’t see anything, yet every shift beneath my hands and feet told me we were moving into some sort of shelter.

I was roughly slammed down into the creaky wooden floor. My abductor pulled the rag off my head. Immediately the scent of blood hit me, it was smeared all over the walls. Around me, bulging sacks squirmed with flies, their incessant buzzing filling the air with a maddening drone.

I forced my eyes to adjust to the dim light filtering through cracks in the walls. Shadows revealed shapes I couldn’t immediately identify; lumps beneath canvasses, presumably the bodies of the dead. Every instinct in me screamed that I was in terrible danger.

A large blocky square shouldered man towered above me. I assumed the figure must’ve been a man, the sheer bulk and height leaving little room for doubt. But as my eyes adjusted to the dim lighting, I saw the details more clearly. The dark long braided hair falling over the shoulders and spilling down her back, the sharpness of her cheekbones catching a stray beam of light, the curve of her frame beneath the rough furs she wore. Praise the Light! This was no man, although she was definitely bigger and taller than any man I’d ever seen.

She squatted down to bring her head down to my level. I writhed under the heavy chains. Her rough callused hands grabbed a fistful of my hair and she yanked up, jolting me alert.

In a deep, almost masculine voice, she said “The lord has hope for you yet, he thinks you’ll come round. I don’t have his patience, nor his generosity.”

The words cut through the haze in my mind. The lord, did she mean Astaron?

She pulled my head further up, sparks of pain went through my scalp down my spine.

“Let’s see if you’ll adhere to your silence now. You’ve had time to decide what matters are more important to you, the secrets you hide, or the little fingers in your hands.”

She ran the back of her other hand over my face, her fingers inspecting my cheek down to my chin, then tapping against my jaw as if checking for weakness.

“What are you doing?” I asked.

“Seeing how easily you’ll break,” she said.

“You’ll find I’m harder to snap than you think.”

A ghost of a smile flickered on her face, illuminated by a sliver of light passing through a crack in the walls. “Brave words for a boy in chains. You’re no different from the rest, rats squeal the same in the end.”

I forced my voice steady, “Then you haven’t listened closely enough. I don’t squeal.”

Her nails pressed into my throat now, not enough to choke, but enough to remind me how easy it would be. “You think defiance makes you strong? It only makes you bleed longer.”

She continued, “Child, I don’t think you understand the severity of your situation. I’ve been given free reign to do whatever I need to do, to get answers out of you. Or perhaps... to see what you're truly capable of when pushed."

“I can feel your heart pounding in your chest, boy. I will ask you once. On whose orders are you here?”

“I don’t know! Someone grabbed me in Nothello—I never saw their face. I woke up here. That’s all I know.”

Then her fist shot forward.

The impact was like being hit with a cannon, my chest caved in under the sheer force, and the chains rattled violently as I was thrown into the wall. A sickening crack tore through my body, a flash of white hot pain bore my eyes.

A scream tore out of me, raw and beastly, reverberating against the chamber walls until it dissolved into hoarse gasps.

A wicked laugh spewed from her throat, animalistic and wild. She had broken my damned ribs. And she was laughing. The pain was excruciating, every breath I took brought me closer to passing out. I took short quick gulps of air to try and steady myself. I could feel my bones moving around inside me, it was intolerable. I hunched forward as far as the chains would allow, desperate to cradle the wound, but her grip on my hair wrenched me upright again.

“Do you hear yourself? Every scream, every gasp you choke out . . . it thrills me. Good, good, so now we both understand where this goes unless you start babbling. I won’t ask twice,” her voice went from wild laughter to total sobriety uncomfortably fast.

“Who holds your leash?” she pulled on my chains as if to say she held the leash now.

“I’m not a mutt like you, Marshin” I spat out that last word like it was the most vile insult, as if I wasn’t a Marshin myself. And that riled her up, she pulled the chains on my arms and shook them violently. The dull ache worsened with each vicious manoeuvre.

It went on for a while like that, she would ask the same questions again, who do you work for? How did you get here? My unsatisfactory answers would provoke another bout of shaking. She never threw another hit like that first one again, perhaps fearing I’d simply roll over and expire.

Eventually I passed out, and the horrid woman must have left. In small bouts of consciousness, I saw—felt—someone working on me. A man, although I could never be sure, moved like a shadow, silently. He never made a sound, he simply worked. Coarse cloth wrapped around my chest, pulled tight until every shift of my ribs screamed. He did not have the tender touch that Doctor Oroya had. His hands were rough, yet meticulous.

As he wrapped my ribs with mechanical precision, he muttered under his breath—not to me, but to himself: "Subject remains unresponsive. No manifestation. Continue observation." Subject? I was too delirious to even process what that meant.

Whatever it was, his labour was not out of mercy like the good doctor, but out of duty to keep me alive. I expected there would be more rounds of questioning.

And those rounds came, they were careful to let my ribs heal, but there was no mercy for my fingers, legs, and other extremities. They simply left me tied to a wall in that box with its revolting smell of bodies. My own blood had left stains, on my clothes, the floor, the chains. And every time, the same man would come and fix me up, make me presentable for another round of torment.

They ripped my fingernails apart, cut me open and crudely stitched me back together. Some days, they would go easy on me by resorting to a simple beating. All the while asking the same question, who do you serve?

It was utterly despicable. I had simply been a child, yet no mercy had been spared. In those moments, the dread and hate for my own people heightened. My parents were right to leave those wretched people, I thought. What terrible fate brought me back to them, I wondered.

I thought back to the stories and history my parents taught, the Sargaryn greed and the oppression the Marshin faced. I saw none of that as I lay clutching countless bruises in that damned box. I saw only beasts dressed in the skin of men.

Somehow, my bones healed fast, within a week. The stoic man who had bandaged me had a look of surprise when he came to check on the bandages.

The large woman who had broken my ribs had returned, but her demeanor had shifted. The wild cruelty was gone, replaced by something clinical. She studied me like a physician studies a patient, looking for symptoms that refused to appear.

She came with a new method. She had brought a bucket with her, filled to the brim with a dark squirming liquid. The metallic tang hit me before I saw it. I barely had time to inhale before she yanked my hair and plunged my face into the thick, cold liquid. My mind shut down all thoughts except for the desperate clinging exigency for oxygen. When I thought I could take it no more, a sharp tug pulled me out. The taste of iron engulfed my other senses. Through the thick red liquid, I looked into the bucket and finally realized what it was. Blood. Puke littered my clothes, I could not stop myself.

“Barbarians. You’re all barbarians”, I spewed out. I should not have spoken, I had accidentally swallowed the vile liquid.

“Child, you’ve been at this for a week. Still nothing? Lord Astaron will be disappointed.”

She didn’t even acknowledge what I said, she cleaned her hands with a towel and simply left. What the hell did they want from me? At that point, it was all for sport. Why didn’t they just kill me? Even if I was a rat, how much danger could I bring to them? They were exacting their desperate revenge on a boy, barely fifteen.

The bucket of blood had left me sick. The metallic tang lingered in my mouth, and every small sound set my nerves on edge.

By the third day, the nausea had begun to ebb, leaving me drained and starving. Every nibble of food they had given me had come back out. I was no longer chained to the wall, but still locked inside the chamber. I could move around, but preferred to stay in the same corner, the unending stench of bodies straggled everywhere else, bringing about more bouts of gagging.

They left me alone for a few days after that. Someone would drop off some food, but when they realized I stopped eating that too, they force fed me, shoving down every morsel of dried meat down my throat.

The door to the shed swung wide open, the light of a new day peered down on my face.

“Get up!” someone shouted in a gruff voice. I recognized the voice, it was Faux. The same Faux that had inadvertently sentenced me to weeks of agony by ‘saving’ me.

I heard his footsteps before I saw him. “I said, get up!” He repeated.

The man cursed under his breath, but then halted when he finally noticed me. My tattered hair, the dirt, grime and blood spread all over my clothes and body. The bruises from lashes and lacerations that had left my body purple.

His jaw tightened, “My god…” he muttered to himself.

He crouched down, no longer barking orders, but studying me like I was some ruined creature he’d stumbled across by accident. He cleared his throat and spoke again, softer this time, though the gruffness lingered out of habit.

“How’re you ...” he started. “How’re ya even alive?”

I stared at him blankly, tilting my head. My lips parted, but no sound came out. My throat was too raw to speak.

Faux shook his head. “They shouldn’ta done this. Not to you. Not like this.” He muttered a curse under his breath. “Damn Astaron, damn that Yaḍeha. You’re barely more than a boy.”

I drank the water, but it only burned my throat.

“You’ve survived longer than anyone thought possible. That’s something. That means something,” he muttered to himself.

I coughed, the sound hollow and weak. “Means … what?”

Faux leaned in closer, his voice almost a whisper now, as if he didn’t want anyone outside to hear. “It means yer stronger than them. Stronger than the ones who tried to break you. You’re … meant for more than… than this!” he pointed his hands out at me, conflicted in his thoughts.

“... more?” I asked.

His lips pressed into a thin line, and he looked away for a moment before meeting my eyes again. “Astaron was wrong about ya. Wrong to bring you here like this, wrong about what you are.”

“So what, you here to save me now? Didn’t work out so well last time, did it?” My voice was coming back to me then, hoarse and brittle.

Faux flinched like I’d hit him with a battering ram. For a long moment, he said nothing. Then he slowly reached into his belt. I tensed, expecting another lash, but instead he pulled out a small iron key.

“No,” he began. “Not to save you. I already failed at that. But to help ya.” He undid my chains and held out his hands to help me up.

For the first time in weeks, I could move my arms properly. I tried to bring my arms to my face, to feel the horrors they’d done to me. I tried to stand, but my legs had become frail, I stumbled but Faux caught me.

“Easy,” he said. “Come on. There’s water, clean water. I’ll get ya to it.”

I tripped as I tried to walk. Faux tightened his grip, surprisingly patient.

“You don’t got to trust me,” he murmured as he half-dragged, half-carried me toward the door. “Not yet. But let me do this much.”

I wanted to spit out some bitter reply, but my voice failed me. All I could manage was a ragged breath.

The door groaned open. Light spilled in, blinding after weeks in the dark. Faux stepped forward, and I let him carry me.

One step. Then another.

chapters.title: Chapter 6
chapters.content:
I tried to scrub the scars away. The lashes and contusions, but they would not go. They never would, even when they eventually faded away over years, those wounds stayed with me.

It took copious amounts of effort to scrub away the dried blood and grim that clung to my skin. Even the scented soap burned against the raw patches and wounds, sending sharp jolts of pain down my body.

Faux had helped me to a small room devoid of any windows, furniture or adornments. Yet still, it was a vast improvement from the repulsive chamber I had spent the weeks before in. Only a bucket of warm water, and a small bar of soap filled the room.

I dipped my hands into the water, and held them up to my eyes. The skin was mottled with deep purples and angry reds, cuts crisscrossing my knuckles. I recoiled at the horrid sight. These couldn’t be my hands.

The water rippled. My reflection fractured.

Then—

I was falling.

Not the water. Not the room. Just me. I was falling.

You know that feeling. That jolt when you're drifting off to sleep and suddenly your body thinks you've slipped off of a ledge. Your limbs spasm, stomach lurches, and for one terrible instant you're certain you're plummeting, before you slam back into your bed, heart racing, sheets twisted around you.

Now imagine that feeling never stops.

I fell through nothing. Through black that had weight and texture, thick as oil, cold as the void between stars. My body tumbled, or perhaps it didn't move at all and the darkness simply poured past me. I couldn't tell. There was no up or down, no sense of direction, only the endless, nauseating drop.

My stomach stayed lodged in my throat. That lurch, that sickening moment of freefall—it stretched on and on, every second an eternity of the same horrible instant. I tried to scream but I had no mouth. Tried to flail but my limbs did not move, phantoms I couldn't quite remember how to control.

The darkness had a sound. A low hum, barely perceptible, like the ringing after a bell has stopped—that lingering vibration that makes your teeth ache. It burrowed into my skull, resonating in the hollows of my bones.

I was aware, horribly aware, of myself dissolving. Not dying—that would have been mercy. Unraveling. The edges of my consciousness frayed like rotted rope. Memories surfaced and sank: my mother's face, already fading at the edges; the pink tree in moonlight, its blossoms turning to ash; Minarra's laugh, distorting into something alien and cruel.

And I kept falling.

Time had no meaning here. Was it seconds? Hours? Years? I was falling before I was born and would be falling after I died. The fall was all there ever was or would be. The Abyss, it didn't kill you—it convinced you that you were already dead, had always been dead, that life was the dream and this endless drop was the only reality.

I tried to hold onto something—anything. My name. But what was a name? Just sounds. Rand'ar. The syllables scattered like dust. My father's face—gone. My home—a concept that had no meaning. There was only falling, and the certainty that I deserved this fall, that I had been falling my entire life and only now realized it.

The darkness began to whisper. Not in words—words would have been a comfort. These were pre-verbal things, thoughts that bypassed language entirely and planted themselves directly in the meat of my mind.

Something grabbed me.

Rough hands that felt solid and real and hurt, and that hurt was the most beautiful thing I'd ever felt because pain meant I had a body, meant I existed somewhere outside this void.

The darkness screamed. I felt it rip at me, trying to drag me back down, trying to convince me the hands were just another layer of the dream. But they held fast. They pulled.

And I surfaced. Gasping, retching, slammed back into a body that felt foreign and broken. Something felt different. Wrong. The room's edges seemed sharper than they should be, colors bled into each other in ways that made my eyes ache. I could hear Faux's heartbeat—no, that was impossible, I was imagining it. The exhaustion, the trauma, it made me see things that weren't there.

The small room. The bucket. The stone floor cold against my knees. Blood dripping down somewhere. I blinked hard, trying to clear my vision, but the strangeness lingered at the periphery—like watching the world through heavy fog.

“Praise the Light! What’s happenin’ to ya!” Faux’s voice boomed. His words sounded distant and muffled, but with his chest heaving, it was clear he was shouting. He grabbed me and hugged me tight, desperate to not let me continue my self-induced torment.

He shook me once, twice, as if he could jar me back into myself. “Damn it”, he muttered, low and ragged, the curse meant more for the room than for me.

“Yer eyes…” he started, then stopped. He shook his head, “Never mind, you’re back now.”

“What happened to ya?” Faux said, quieter now, almost a whisper.

The words would not come out of my mouth, I could not scream like I wanted to at that moment. So I clung to Faux tighter and let the tears flow like the blood that dripped down my head.

It was the first time I had cried since this nightmare had begun. Through the well, through the hunger, through the broken ribs, through the blood, through it all. I’d endured.

And in that moment, something stirred. For the first time in my entire life, I felt alive and there in the moment, like I had simply been coasting along all this while. The pain, the shame, the fear, the hunger—all of it was proof that I was really alive, that I was human.

“Easy now…” Faux’s voice wavered as though the words had turned brittle in his throat. His grip on my shoulder tightened, not to comfort, but to steady himself. “Don’t… don’t try to speak of it. Best not.”

He swallowed hard, eyes flicking to the shadows as though something might be listening.

I buried my face against him, his thick wool coat nudging against me. I breathed rapidly, trying to calm myself, feeling the sensations of my hands, making sure I truly had command of myself.

“Let me get you some clothes—and somethin’ to dry up with,” he said.

In that raw moment, I knew with a desperate, aching certainty—I wanted to live.

I dried off and put on the fresh clothes Faux provided me. They fit me better than the last pair of clothes Faux had provided me with, the ones I had endured in for weeks. They were unremarkable, yet putting them on felt like a small sense of order returning.

I caught my reflection in a scrap of polished metal hanging on the wall for just a moment. My eyes, they looked … wrong. The colour looked off. I couldn’t tell what it was exactly. I blinked and they were normal again. Just exhaustion.

“Where are we going?” I asked Faux as we walked through winding halls littered with rooms on either side.

“Astaron wants to see ya,” he replied.

I ground my teeth. “He couldn’t come down to the shit hole himself? Sends you instead?”

Faux kept his eyes ahead, defeated.

“Never said I agreed with him,” Faux said, his eyes narrowing. “I’m only tellin’ ya what he thinks. Got you out of that hellhole so ya could hear it straight from him.” He paused, stepping closer. “Look, I ain’t sure what he’s gonna say to ya, but if he gives you an offer, just take it, ‘kay?”

“What’s he going to offer?” I asked meekly.

“Not sure, he didn’t say. But it’s better than that shit box, right?”

“Sure,” I narrowed my eyes. “Just take me to Astaron,”

Faux gave a stiff nod, saying nothing more. He finally turned and led me to the sliding wooden door that opened up to the exterior facade. An outdoor balcony made of rippled stone that overlooked the vast courtyard below.

The air outside slapped me raw, ever the reminder of the Belt’s unrelenting climate. I hunched into myself as he tossed my coat into my hands. I pulled it over my shoulders, the silence between us as thick as the frost that clung to the tiered roofs of the great tower.

On the far edge of the balcony was a simple wooden bench, its back draped in snow. And there he sat—Lord Astaron. His ever-watchful staff was propped diagonally across him: the base nestled under his left boot, while the long shaft leaned against the curve of his right thigh. Even at rest it was poised for command.

My eyes were drawn to it, its elaborate design. The staff was designed like a pillar, split into two distinct halves by a polished bronze that gleamed in the sunlight.

The upper half was carved with intricate patterns, arched crescents and full discs, etched to depict the twin moons and their constant battle in the night sky. The lower half stood in radiant contrast to the depiction above. Where the upper half whispered of night, this part blazed with the mark of day. Etched into the wood were flaring sunbursts, flaring arcs and jagged lines representing solar flares. I wondered what the depictions meant, perhaps balance or harmony of the celestial bodies.

His face was shadowed by a round iron hat that sat on his head. It too had engravings depicting the celestial bodies in our sky. The twin moons carved in their fleeting dance, orbiting around the eternal sun.

“Sit, Rand’ar,” Astaron said as I neared him, patting the empty space beside him on the bench.

“I prefer to stand, Lord,” I said with venom in my voice.

“Suit yourself,” He finally looked up at me. His old and tired face was worn down from the decades. I wanted to strike him there and then. To make him feel an ounce of the pain I had felt. I doubted my hand would make it anywhere near his face, he may have been old, but he had the look of a true warrior.

“Rand’ar, you’ve put me in a troubling situation. On one hand, I’ve got a northern spy scouting my lands, his masters itching to butcher us. On the other hand, the spy is just a kid who should never have survived a night in the Belt.” He leaned forward, “So I had to be certain. Certain you weren't a plant. And certain you weren't... something else. My people have methods for both."

He studied me. "You survived them. That tells me what I needed to know."

“I’m no spy,” I spat.

Astaron gave a faint, knowing smile. “No? Yet here you are with no trail, no gear, no plausible tale. Where are your kidnappers then? You insult me with half-truths, boy, but I’ll give you this, you’ve got a stubborn fire in you.”

He continued, “What do you think it is we do here?”

“Teach men how to starve and freeze.”, I replied.

“Don’t play the fool with me boy, you know better than that.”

I mulled it over for a moment. “You’re leading a rebellion. Trying to bring back the Marshin glory days?”

“What do you know of history, Northerner? My people have suffered for millennia. For their prophecies, they butcher us and call it a mercy. We—”

“I’m not a Northerner,” I blurted, sharper than I meant. His gaze snapped to mine, cold and appraising. “I’m a Marshin. My parents left the southern continent before I was born. But I’m Marshin through and through.”

His brow furrowed, “What’s your full name, then, boy?”

“Rand’ar Torin Haestus.” Rand’ar, son of Haestus.

The staff clattered against the stone. For a moment—just one—I saw the mask crack. His face didn't twist with rage. It went slack, like I'd struck him.

“Say that again.”

"Haestus was my father. He's dead now." I kept my voice flat, watching him carefully, “Did you know of him?”

Astaron's hand found the staff again. His knuckles went white. "Haestus had no son."

“He had two, and two daughters. He left here for North before any of us were born."

"He left." The words came out strangled. "Yes. He did."

Astaron turned his back to me, staring out over the courtyard. When he spoke again, his voice had gone hollow. "Haestus was the greatest man I ever knew. He orchestrated The Withdrawal—freed our people from chains that had held us for over a millennium. We thought we'd won."

He laughed, but there was no humor in it. "We threw celebrations. We crowned our own kings. We believed the lie." He turned back to face me, and for the first time I saw something besides cold calculation in his eyes. It was grief. "And Haestus... he saw it first. Before any of us. That we'd traded iron chains for invisible ones. That our kings answered to theirs. That freedom was just a word they let us have because it cost them nothing."

"So he left," I said quietly.

"So he left." Astaron's grip tightened on his staff. "The man who'd given everything, his youth, his blood, his certainty—he just walked away. Left a letter saying he couldn't watch us celebrate a defeat dressed as victory. That he was done with grand causes and empty triumphs." His voice dropped to almost a whisper. "That he wanted something real. Something that mattered."

The wind howled through the courtyard. Inside, the sounds of training continued.

"We called him a coward," Astaron continued. "A traitor. Some said he'd lost his nerve. Others said he'd gone mad." He studied me with those hard eyes. "But he just saw the truth before the rest of us could bear to. That we'd have to burn it all down and start again. That The Withdrawal wasn't the end—it was just clearing away the old lie to reveal the deeper one."

"And you stayed," I said.

"I stayed. Because someone has to finish what he started. Someone has to win the war he realized we'd never stopped fighting." He planted his staff between us. "So tell me, son of Haestus. Did he ever speak of us? Of the cause he abandoned? Or did he find his 'something real' and forget we still bleed down here?"

The question was like a knife to my gut, and he knew it.

"He never talked about the rebellion," I admitted. "Never talked about the south at all. He just... trained me with a sword every night and told me to be stronger than he was."

Astaron's expression shifted—I couldn't read it. Satisfaction? Vindication? Disappointment?

"Stronger than he was," he repeated. "And are you, boy? Are you strong enough to finish what your father couldn't? To see the hard truth and not run from it?"

"I don't know what you're asking me."

"I'm asking if you're your father's son—the man who won a false victory then fled—or if you're something else. Something that can endure what comes next." He leaned forward. "What do you know about The Withdrawal, son of Haestus?"

I steadied myself, trying to grasp where this was leading. "What do I know, you ask? Let's see. The Sargaryn slaveowners left with their tall chains. We gained our freedoms for the first time and—"

"Wrong and wrong. We have never been more powerless as a people. Have you seen the state of these lands? The kings we bow to are not our kings. No, they are planted by foreign hands, puppets dressed in stolen crowns. We hold no lands, no coin, no voice. Our farmers still till soil that isn't theirs, our smiths forge the irons that chain us, and our sons bleed for banners that rule us. Our daughters still bartered off like cattle.”

“They dangled the keys to power in front of the few chosen Marshin, and they snatched it like starving dogs. Now they wear fine robes, take pleasure in the finer luxuries and believe themselves to be lords, but they are nothing more than servants, slaves made overseers. They've turned the same chains that held them, toward us. It is all a facade.”

“And the Sargaryn? They sit back in their high city, laughing as their work is done for them. So no, the slaveowners did not leave, they only changed their positions."

"Why are you telling me all this?" I asked.

"If you are going to betray your own people, you should know the truth."

“I don't care about the truth. You tortured me. Why should I care what happens to any of you?"

"Careful, boy," he growled. "You think you've seen hardship? You've never seen a girl of six so starved that her body contorts in on itself. And the parents of that child, they don't have a chance to worry since they have to work in endless labor to keep their family alive for another day. No, you've lived a comfortable life."

"Comfortable? We may have had food on our table every night, but every time we left the house it was a danger. Up North, Marshin don't get to live. If anyone ever found out who we were, we'd be hunted to death, all for sport. I was never allowed to get close with anyone, make any friends, for fear of them finding out."

His eyes narrowed. "You had choices. You had food, shelter, blood to claim you. My people have none of that. We are bred into bondage, with no hope for a better life."

"I won't feel guilty for being born into a better life, that's not my choice. But you had a choice, a choice to hear me out, but you just locked me up in a box."

"Isn't it strange, Rand'ar? That in a world so tightly controlled, you found your way to the one place where your kind still resists. Some would call it fate. Others," he glanced at me, "might call it obligation."

"You think you can turn me into your agent? You still think that I work for them?” I came closer and whispered, “Let me tell you some good news then. I don't have a secret button to call in the cavalry. There is no one coming to destroy you. Just let me go back home."

"You survived the storm. Alone. With nothing. And you came to us from the north, unmarked, untracked. Tell me, Rand'ar... does that not strike you as strange?" he asked.

I didn't answer. I couldn't. The fire in his words had quieted, but it left behind a pressure. I wasn't sure if his question was accusatory or not.

"It does," I hesitated. "Which is all the more reason I have to go back home. The longer I stay, the harder it'll be to explain any of this."

Astaron studied me, unmoved. "Perhaps. But how will you cross the border? You'll need to ID yourself."

He tilted his head slightly, his voice controlled, "You think the border guards will just wave you through? You have no identification. No name in their books. As far as they're concerned, you don't exist. You're just a runaway slave to them."

I wrapped the coat tighter around myself.

"Yes I don't have my papers," I said. "But I'll wait at the border if I have to—until the registry ships them back to me. I'm sure they'll find my records eventually. I'm not some ghost."

"Rand'ar, I don't want to put you back in a cell. I really don't. I didn't enjoy any of this. I do what I must to ensure the safety of my people. And right now, you are a liability, left unchecked, who knows what trouble comes knocking." He shook his head, unwavering in his decision. "I can't let you leave, not yet, but eventually. The circumstances of your arrival are too anomalous. I am giving you an opportunity here," he paused, spreading his arms, as if he was offering me paradise, but it was only darkness ahead.

"So you'll keep me prisoner, until you decide what to do with me."

"Not prisoner," he said, with an almost patronizing sadness. "You'll be watched, yes. You'll earn our trust—or not. But you will be fed, clothed and sheltered and treated just like any other student. It's better than the alternative, we both don't want to see you back in that cell."

He let the weight of his words hang in the punishing air for a moment. His threat—no—his promise hung between us.

"Speak plainly, what are you saying?" I spat. I already knew what he was going to say, the offer Faux had mentioned.

He stood up, with an outstretched hand. "Your father abandoned our people.”

His eyes lingered on my face for a moment—no—my eyes. He looked deep in them, searching for something. The silence stretched for an uncomfortable moment and I looked away, not before I caught something in his expression. Disappointment? No, that didn't make sense. He barely knew me.

“You can either follow his path or forge your own. Join me Rand'ar,” he began. I could have sworn his voice carried less conviction than before, “let us topple the Citadel of Sorrows and liberate our people."

chapters.title: Chapter 7
chapters.content:
I scoffed at the thought, he wanted me to give up my life and dreams for a pointless pursuit. What could I say to that? I had no choice, he would not let me go to the border, not yet.

I could try to run now. It was just me and the old man Astaron, no one was in the courtyard below. The gate was open when we had first come through, would it still be? Could I make it to the outer wall before they caught me? And then what? Two days through the Belt with no supplies, no papers, no way to cross the border without being sold off.

I wondered just briefly what refusal would bring me, what dark bloody end I’d meet. The men here didn’t seem to forgive hesitation, and Astaron didn’t strike me as a man who repeated his offers. If I said no, I doubted I’d be shown the door. No, I’d simply vanish in one of these cold halls and never walk out again, only death to greet me on the far end. Whatever end I would meet would no doubt be worse than the shed. The promises of safety and shelter were only under the guise of obedience.

But it wasn't fear that stopped me from running. Not entirely.

Your father abandoned our people, Astaron had said. The words circled back through my mind, sharp and insistent. My father, Haestus, had been more than just the man who trained me in our courtyard at night. He'd been a legend here. The architect of The Withdrawal. Their greatest hope, who'd walked away when they needed him most.

And I knew nothing about it. Nothing about why he’d led them, how he did it, or why he left. What made him choose his exile over glory? The man who'd taught me to be strong had carried a history I'd never questioned, never even known to ask about. I had that chance then, to find out the truth of his past. I don’t know how fate had spun its gears to bring me to that place, but I had to find out more about father.

What kind of son goes home without understanding who his father was?

I thought of returning to my family—walking through our door, sitting beneath the pink tree with Minarra, pretending everything was normal. But how could I sit there knowing I'd been within reach of the truth and turned away? How could I face my aunt's questions about where I'd been, knowing I'd fled before learning what my father had started, what he'd abandoned, whether he'd been a hero or a coward?

The shame of it twisted in my gut. Not shame at being tortured—no one could fault me for that. Shame at the ignorance. At living fifteen years as Haestus's son without understanding what that name meant to anyone but us.

And beneath that shame, something else stirred. Something that I didn’t want to name because it felt like betraying everything they’d done to me. Curiosity. Not about Marshin culture in some abstract sense. I had no love for these people—not after what they’d put me through. But I needed to understand what my father had seen in them. What cause had been worth leading, then worth abandoning. Whether the man who'd raised me had been running toward something real in the North, or just running.

“I don’t see how I have a choice.” I finally said.

But even as the words left my mouth, I knew they were a lie. I did have a choice. I could run, could take my chances with the cold and the border guards and the long journey home. I could return to my family and spend the rest of my life wondering.

Or I could stay. Not for Astaron or his rebellion. Not for some grand cause I couldn’t care to believe in. I’d stay for myself, because I couldn't leave without answers. Because somewhere in this frozen fortress was the truth about the man who'd shaped me, and I would not go home ignorant of it. And I still needed to find out who’d brought me here. I suspected my answer was closer than I thought.

So I would earn his trust, learn his teachings, and find my own way out of that place—or so I told myself. The truth, which I couldn't yet admit, was that I wanted to stay. I needed answers more than I needed freedom. But I wrapped that need in the language of strategy, of patience, of eventual escape. It made the choice easier to live with.

“My father,” I began. “You said you knew him, worked with him. I want to know what he was really like. Why he left. What he did here."

Astaron's expression didn't change, but something flickered in his eyes.

“Haestus was a complicated man, but an honorable one. There is much I could tell you about him, much you deserve to know.”

“But" Astaron continued, his voice measured, "such knowledge is not given freely. Your father earned his place in our history through action, through sacrifice, through achievement." He paused, letting the words settle. "Achieve greatness on the battlefield and for our cause, and I will tell you more about him. Prove yourself worthy of his legacy.”

He wanted to use me as just another one of his puppets. So I’d play along, achieve greatness as he’d said. He dangled answers I desperately wanted just out of reach—making me perform for them. But it didn’t matter, I needed those answers more than I needed my pride.

“I will watch your journey with great curiosity, Rand'ar. I do hope you are better than your father.” He said, a twinkle in his eye.

That day, beneath frostbitten skies and foreign stone, I made the first of many decisions that cannot be undone. Astaron turned, his robes catching the wind, and beckoned me back inside. I followed him and we found Faux, ever the watchful, leaning on a wall.

“So, we tossing him to the wolves? Or is he staying?” Faux laughed.

“Get him a bunk, he trains with the others starting tomorrow,” Astaron replied. He whispered something quickly into Faux’s ear, to which he nodded.

Faux stood up to his full imposing height, and grinning ear to ear, said “Welcome to The Gauntlet, kid.”

Faux put on his boots and motioned me to follow him outside. We walked outside toward the large building on the opposite end of the courtyard. The cold had worsened now as the sun set into the peaks. The courtyard felt larger than ever with the wind cutting at my face. How would I survive this damned bitter cold, I thought as we walked.

“So,” Faux began, I was struggling to keep up with his tall stride. “How’d you convince the old man to not put ya in a cell?”

“I didn’t,” I replied. The truth was, I wasn’t sure why Astaron decided to let me walk free. He expected something from me, that much was clear, but what exactly, I couldn’t say.

“Worked some magic on him, did ya? Hiding somethin’ behind those eyes of yers?” He sneered.

“Sure, also enchanted him to give me the room at the top of the big tower.” I replied flatly.

Faux chuckled at that, shaking his head. “Believe me, ya don’t wanna be up there, way colder than it is down ‘ere.” He shivered at the thought.

We reached the far end of the courtyard. From outside, this building looked like a mirror image of the one we’d first emerged from. The ridged gables hung expansively above me. The black stone and deep wood of the walls were a respite from the howling winds. Lanterns hung on the walls, their glass panes fogged, casting a warm golden hue across the stone. The light within flickered, dancing along the grain of timber frames and catching on the thin layer of frost hugging the ledges. A pair of wide double doors loomed ahead, their surface weathered and frayed. Faux motioned me to slip it open, so I did and allowed Faux to go in first.

If I stepped in, I would be a part of these people, a cog in the machine. If someone betrayed this place, we’d all be killed, butchered, never to be heard of again. The Sargaryn aristocrats would scour the earth to find us, to snuff out any flames of rebellion, for Marshin are lesser than humans. If I died here, I’d never train Minarra again, never watch her grin after a good parry or her scowl when I corrected her form. She always did take after me, more than she should have. If I did die here, would she grow into her own person, or chase the shadow of someone who never came back. I wondered what lay on the other side, was there something more than the mundane life I’d grown to grieve.

Faux must have thought I was mad, always hesitating under doorways or gates. I’d done the same thing at the outer gate, the weight of doubts holding me back. As if stepping through would leave whatever certainty I had left behind.

It was peacefully quiet inside, the warmth a blessing from the bleak outdoors. The building felt a lot more inviting. The main door led us into a chamber with dark wood that lined the floors, soft handcrafted carpets and large cushioned settees. On the wall opposite me, a broad stone fireplace stood. The hearth was wide, framed by carved stonework that rose upward in a towering chimney, vanishing somewhere into the heights of the ceiling. Bookshelves lined the walls, most lined with dust from decades of neglect. Large banners hung on the walls, depictions of the sun and twin moons were embroidered, not unlike the ones on Lord Astaron’s staff.

The room was empty save us, it seemed the other students still had duties or training to attend to. Faux plumped down into one of the seats near the fireplace, so I took one near him. He lit a match and got a fire going. We waited to warm up near the fire. I stared into the frantic flames, wondering if it was destiny or chance that had woven me onto this journey.

“Faux,” I started slowly, “Don’t tell anyone what happened to me either. Not a word.”

He gave me a puzzled look, but I leaned in before he could speak. “Some things aren’t meant to be spoken aloud. Not here, not anywhere. People think it’s unholy, sinful…” I let my words trail off, my chest tightening at the thought of what had happened. “Just promise me Faux, let it die in silence.”

He sat up straighter and promised. “You have my word.”

“So, how long do you think I’m stuck here for?” I asked Faux.

“Till Astaron trusts you to leave, I suppose.” He took a big gulp of water from a half empty glass on a nearby table. “What’s the hurry? Nothin’ out there for us. I came from Ashford myself. Up there, we’re nothin’ but rats roaming their cities to ‘em. They don’t want us there.”

“Don’t you all have families? People waiting for you? Lives to get back to?” I prodded.

“What d’you think happened to all these people?” Faux said, his voice grim. “They got nothin’ left, families butchered, enslaved, sold across the continent, never to see each other again. We came here with nothin’, but Astaron gave us something to climb up for. A purpose.”

He took a deep breath, his eyes were distant, “Some of us left things behind, things we can never go back to.”

“There’s nothin’ out there for us,” he repeated, more adamant this time. “Only we can carve out our own path.”

We sat in reticence for a while, him mulling over some darker thoughts in his mind, perhaps whatever he had left behind.
