I picked a book from a nearby shelf and opened up to a random page. The writing was in a language I could not read. So I scrolled through the pages mindlessly, sparing a glance at the many diagrams and depictions of the anatomy of the brain. Without understanding the words, the diagrams were meaningless, so I closed the book and let the fire seep warmth back into my bones.

Eventually, Faux leaned forward and rubbed his palms together. “Come on,” he muttered, standing with a stretch. “I’ll show you yer room. You’ll be bunkin’ with the others—don’t worry, they ain’t snore too loud.”

The bunk room, one of dozens, was dim and cramped. Light shone through from a small window, illuminating one half of the room.

“These two are empty—I think. Take whichever one ya want. And you get this closet for your things. Well, err, I don’t suppose you have any things.”

The other two beds were neatly made, blankets folded with care, tucked in properly at the edges. But the space around them was lived-in—boots left by the footboard, a half-unrolled satchel against the wall, and a couple of shirts draped carelessly over the back of a chair.

I took the bed in the far corner from the door, draped in darkness. Faux was right, I didn’t have any things, save for the clothes on my back. I made to hang the coat in one of the closets, before Faux stopped me.

“Don’t think this one fits ya, let me take this back. I’ll send someone to bring something more fittin’ to yer size,” so he took the coat back. He eyed me for a moment, as if getting the measurements for my clothes, then gestured towards the door. “You should eat. Others already had their share, but there’s still somethin’ left in the kitchens.”

Before I could say anything, he gave me a brief nod and stepped out, his footsteps thudding softly against the wooden floor as he disappeared down the hall.

The kitchen wasn’t far. A few embers still glowed in the hearth, and a plate of cold meat and bread sat under a linen cloth on the table. I ate quickly, the food plain but filling.

With Faux gone and nothing left to do in the evening, it seemed the perfect time to wander a little. The halls were dimly lit by hanging lanterns, their warm light flickering against the old stone. I passed by a study room lined with shelves, papers, and stacks of tomes. A few desks sat beneath narrow windows, with pens still resting in place. All of it empty, save for a few servants working about.

Eventually, the stillness caught up with me. My body ached, not just from the pain and the cold, but from everything I’d been through. I returned to the dormitory and lay down on my new bed, its frame creaking lightly beneath me. The clean smell of the sheets, along with the quiet setting, made it easy to fall into a nap.

I don’t know how long I was out before I awoke to shouting.

“Oi! Get up! This ain’t a bloody resort for urchins!” Someone shouted at me.

My eyes fought to open. For a moment I wasn't sure where I was—the dark well, the shed, somewhere worse. My chest tightened before I recognized the wooden ceiling above me, the scratch of wool blankets against my skin. Real. This was real.

I didn’t recognize him at first. It was the fat kid I’d seen on my first day, Stubby, or whatever the others had called him. I belched from the smell, he reeked of sweat.

“Did you hear me, how’d you get in here? You ain’t one of those strays they pick up from the mountain, are you?” he pulled a knife from his belt and started waving it around, as if it made him any more threatening.

I should have felt threatened. Instead I just stared at the blade, thinking how small it was. How insignificant. I'd survived worse than whatever this boy could do with his butter knife.

I rubbed my eyes open and stretched slowly, testing that my limbs still obeyed. There was another boy with him, the one who’d spoken out when Faux broke up the fight.

“Wait Tommy, I saw him with Faux earlier,” the other boy said, but Tommy, Stubby, was looking for a reason to swing.

Tommy’s knife wobbled in his chubby grip, more likely to slip and slice his own finger than anything else. “Don’t think I won’t use this!” he threatened, taking a step closer. The floor creaked beneath his weight.

“On who? Me or yourself?” I said. The words came out flatter than I meant. I was too tired for this. Too worn down to muster the energy for proper fear or anger.

The other boy, tall and lanky, snickered. He put a hand on Tommy’s shoulder. “Put it away mate. Faux wouldn’t bring in some rando without reason.”

Tommy huffed, still holding the knife out like it owed him something.

“Yea well, we’ll see about that. He looks a little too comfortable in that bed. And just sayin’, you’re sleeping awful close to my boots, stranger.”

I almost laughed. Almost. "You worried I'll cuddle with them or something?"

The lanky one chuckled. “Don’t mind Tommy here, he thinks every new face is either an assassin or here to steal his socks.” He stuck out a hand for me to shake, “Name’s Mirvel.”

“Rand’ar,” I shook it. His grip was warm, solid. Another small proof that I was here, present, alive.

Tommy finally sheathed his little knife, “What kinda wacko name is that,” he snorted. “Sounds like your momma sneezed when she came up with it.”

“They call you Stubby, so I wouldn’t be one to talk.”

Mirvel burst out laughing at that. Tommy stammered out, “It’s an endearing nickname, you just don’t get it.”

“Whatever you say.” I lay back down, pulling the blanket up. The simple act of lying in a real bed, in a room with other breathing people, felt like a mercy I didn't deserve. "Now I'm going back to sleep."

We each settled into our beds, the room falling into a lull of shifting blankets and creaking frames. I kept my eyes open in the dark, watching the ceiling, making sure it stayed solid above me.

“We heard you were dead. Some rumour about a stray kid … frozen half dead at the bottom of a pit,” Mirvel said.

My throat tightened. "People do love to talk."

They weren't far off. I had almost died. Just not the way they thought.

“They sure do. Truth is, there’s no one up here in the mountains except for us. So the older lads, they love spinning tales to keep us jumpy.”

“I’ve heard stories of cannibals in the Belt,” I said.

“Yea I’ve heard those too, but I ain’t seen it for myself. Although, that might just be because I’ve been snug in The Gauntlet all this while.” He shifted under his blanket. “Though they say part of training is they send you out into the mountains for a week. A group of four. No food, no fire. Just to see if you’ve got the grit for the cold.”

I stared up at the ceiling. “Sounds like a good way to fill those pit-rumours back up again.”

“Yeah.” His voice dropped quieter. “Still … better than rotting in here, right?”

I wasn't sure about that. But I didn't say so.

I could hear the wind howling despite the thick walls, rattling against the gables. I focused on Tommy's breathing, Mirvel's occasional shifts in his bed. The sounds were real. I was there with them, not falling through nothing.

“So . . . you’re not really a stray right?” he asked.

“Nah, I’m here to stay.” The words felt hollow, but maybe if I said them enough times, I'd believe them.

“Where’d you come from then, Veylands?” Mirvel asked.

I hesitated. The truth was a dangerous thing. It had already landed me imprisonment and torture for weeks. It was easier to go along with the question.

"Yeah," I said. "Veylands."

“Which faction?” Tommy asked excitedly.

Shit. I didn't know enough to answer that. "Small village. You wouldn't know it. "

"Try me. My cousin worked the river trade routes, been all over."

My mind raced. I knew nothing about Veylands geography, their cities, or their rivers. One wrong detail and I'd be caught.

"Look," I said, keeping my voice low. "I'd rather not talk about home. Lost people there. That's why I'm here."

Mirvel's expression softened slightly. Tommy grunted but didn't push.

It wasn't the truth. But it was a lie that might hold. At least for now.

Soon they both fell asleep, and I could hear Tommy’s incessant snoring. I lay there listening to it, grateful for the noise. For the first time in weeks, I wasn't alone. I was with my people, even if I felt like a stranger among them. Even if part of me was still falling through that dark place, wondering if I'd ever truly climbed out.

But I was here. In this bed. In this room. And tomorrow I'd wake up and prove it again.

chapters.title: Chapter 8
chapters.content:
The weeks that followed were a blur of duties, studies, and training. A vast change from the posh, pompous life and culture I came from. Also a vast change from the blood and grime of the box. Cleaning duties were no longer the concern of some slave or servant, they were my own burden. The incompetence I had feigned with Doctor Oroya no longer worked with Orem. He gave me three days of leniency—three days to find my footing, before I would be subject to the same standards as the rest of the Kethalan recruits.

Three days later, it seemed the broom did not want to work with me. And Orem had a special way of making sure I knew it. With me, he’d inspect every corner and examine every shelf. He even made me run my fingers on the ground and show them to him for inspection. If there was any dust, it was ten minutes outside without a coat. He said it built character, the only thing it built was frostbite.

Mirvel and Tommy told me to watch out for Orem, not to get on his bad side. They told me how they’d heard stories from the older men, about an old recruit who was tired of the punishing demands and picked a fight with Orem. By the time Orem was done, the boy could barely stand, beaten and bloodied well. That was hardly the end of his struggles. They threw him out into the cold for the night, and come morning, they found him frozen stiff, trousers halfway down as if he’d collapsed mid-piss. After hearing that, I learned quickly not to test my luck like I’d done with Astaron.

If the duties didn’t wear me down, the studies certainly tried. Lessons were either held inside a cramped room that smelled fairly of ink and books or outside in the courtyard for demonstrations. Orem or one of the other instructors would drone on about history, tactics and the Sagaryn subjugation, although there wasn’t much recorded history past The Mass Withdrawal. History that was common knowledge where I had come from.

They made us memorize and interpret maps, learn code signals, and study tactics. Although I noticed the maps they gave us never marked exactly where we were, it was clear they didn’t trust us—or me. Instead we studied the geography of everywhere else, as if the wider world mattered more than the ground beneath us.

We learned of two sovereign realms South of us. There was The Veylan Lands, a fertile realm known for its river valleys and many trade routes. It was also the bigger of the two. The second was The Droskar Territories, a fractured realm marked by its many fortress cities, always bleeding with constant skirmishes. On the surface, the two kingdoms were locked in rivalry, their rulers eager to claim the barren stretch of wilderness we occupied. Not because they valued the land, but because to them a kingdom was only as mighty as the borders it swallowed.

But beneath it all, both Veylan and Droskar patricians hung from the strings above. Their crowns were bought and painted by their true masters. Their wars, their rivalries, their hunger for conquest—it was all theater, staged, to hide the true ruling power. All while the peasants suffered the same, their false freedom an unholy lie, sinful to question, and painful to hold true. They believe that this was what freedom looked like, riddled with wars and the blood of their children. But those were the questions for lords and kings. For me, freedom meant something far simpler: surviving another day of drills under Orem’s gaze.

It seemed Mirvel was right, Orem loved singling out Tommy. Nothing Tommy could do was right in Orem’s piercing eyes, whether it was fumbling the answer to a question about battle formations, or even holding a map the “wrong” way during lessons. And it seemed that Orem had found a second target to scrutinize—me. And it only further pissed him off that Tommy and I were always together, every mistake by one of us was amplified by the other’s presence.

While the studying was a strain on my mind, and a pain to endure, the training was where I shined. For as long as I can remember, the blade and I moved together. There were countless nights where my father and I trained in the courtyard in the moonlight. He said the absence of light helped focus the rest of my senses, so I could hear and feel the opponent's blade without seeing it. My footing would be uneasy on the grass, and that’s where Father cornered me most, and these sessions often ended with a bruise or a cut.

Sometimes my mother would watch us from under the pink tree on the far end of the courtyard. The moonlight spilled through the branches, shining down on her hazel hair. She never spoke, never interfered, even though she wanted to tell my father to go easy on me. There was something calming about her gaze, like she was rooting for me to push through, her presence tethered me to the moment. On nights where Father’s blade left a cut, on my arm or a bruise in my ribs, I’d glance her way. She’d offer a faint smile—soft and reassuring—that was enough to steady me. And after we’d finish the training, I would jump in her open and waiting arms.

I was never bitter towards Father for his harsh lessons; I understood even then that his blade was meant to carve me into something stronger. When my parents passed and my aunt and uncle took me in, they hired a swordmaster named Esteban. But I suppose his mastery was untrue, since I would overwhelm him more often than not.

In time I stopped attending his lessons altogether, it wasn’t just his lack of skill, but nothing could replace the dark nights of training with my father. Esteban’s teachings lacked weight, and his strikes lacked purpose. So I took to training my younger sister, Minarra, instead. Passing on what Father taught me. With her, the courtyard felt alive again, and Daryen and the others would come to watch. For a time, it almost felt as those nights under the pink tree had returned. But that was another life, lost to me, and the weight of it faded as Hurbasa’s voice snapped me back to the present.

“Rand’ar. Stop!” he barked.

I froze, chest heaving, the wooden blade still raised in my hands. Across from me, Dan, my sparring partner, was sprawled on the floor, his hands raised in fear. His wooden sword had rolled a few feet away, useless to him now.

“Damn it, boy,” Hurbasa strode forward, and snatched the practice sword from my grip with his right hand. “This isn’t a street brawl. When your opponent yields, you stop.”

I stood there in shame, my mind had wandered to the past, the old memories had consumed me, and Dan had gotten hurt because of it. I offered him my hand to get him up, but he swatted it away and muttered something about me being an “enraged monkey.” I deserved it, but I wanted to spit something back anyway. But the glares from the others circling the training floor stopped me. I flicked my eyes toward Mirvel, who just shook his head in disappointment.

“Since you want to play dirty,” Hurbasa growled, his voice carried across the room. He raised his hand and pointed toward the ring, “you’ll face Kalandyr next.”

Murmurs went around the room—low and uncomfortable. I heard Tommy’s sharp intake of breath from behind me, saw Mirvel’s eyes go wide for a moment before his face went blank. Around the room, recruits shifted, some leaning forward with the anticipation of watching a beating, others suddenly finding the floor very interesting.

Then he stepped forward into the ring.

The same boy who'd dismantled Tommy on my first day, the one who’d moved with precision and speed. Kalandyr walked toward the ring like he'd done this a hundred times before, no swagger, no visible emotion. Just the quiet certainty of someone who knew exactly what was about to happen and found it routine. He had an air of bored confidence.

My body still ached from the weeks before. I was tired. My muscles were heavy with the particular exhaustion that came after a fight fueled by anger rather than strategy.

Hurbasa had called him specifically. Not just some recruit. He had said, ‘Since you want to play dirty.’ I’d clearly revealed too much, that I’d been trained, and now he was testing me with his best student.

Or maybe just to punish me for it, it wouldn’t be out of character with the miserable people here.

Someone muttered, “He only calls up Kal when he wants to make a point.” That didn’t ease my thoughts.

Kalandyr stepped into the ring without ceremony, picked up a practice sword, didn’t even test its weight and stood there with a dull expression. Simply waiting for it to be over. He didn’t even look at me directly. His eyes were dark and unreadable

“Well?” Hurbasa’s voice cut through my hesitation. "Get in the ring.” He threw the wooden sword at my feet.

I stepped forward. Around us, the recruits had gone quiet, watching. I wasn’t sure what they were looking for. A duel, or a beating.

I picked up the practice sword, it felt heavier than before, laden with my doubts.

Kalandyr hadn’t spoken, he hadn’t even moved. He simply … waited. Patient in a predatory way Dan’s wild senseless swinging could never be.

My father always told me, never fight angry, and never fight tired. I wondered how often he abided by those rules in his quest for rebellion.

I was about to break both.

Hurbasa’s hand dropped, “Begin.”

Before Hurbasa’s hand had even dropped to his side, Kalandyr was already moving.

He moved fast.

Kalandyr came at me with a high swing aimed for my chest. The muscle memory overrode my exhaustion as my sword arm came up to deflect the attack. The deflection was clean, textbook even. Too clean. I'd just shown more than I'd meant to. The wood cracked against wood and made a sound that left the other recruits flinching.

The impact singed down my arms and left me wincing, my ribs still healing.

Then he was gone, already back at the other side of the ring. His face betrayed no emotion but he was surprised. He hadn’t expected me to deflect his attack, he was used to practicing against much slower opponents.

Kalandyr paused. Not long—barely a breath—but enough that I knew he’d noticed. His stance shifted. Whatever calm assessment he had planned was over.

My heart hammered against my chest. The crowd's murmurs had died completely.

We circled around the floor, each wary of the other’s skill. My bare feet gripped the mat tightly, sweat poured down my forehead. One of us had to strike again.

I had to regain control, make him think the first block was luck, reflex, anything but a trained response. I could’ve ended it there, taken the next hit and went down. But I'd seen the faces watching when I'd deflected Kalandyr's opening strike—Tommy's surprise, Mirvel's sudden attention, even the older recruits were leaning forward. If I folded now, what would I tell them, it was blind luck? That I was weak?

And Astaron. He'd kept me alive because he expected something from me, even if I didn't know what. Showing nothing but incompetence wouldn't keep me useful—it would make me disposable.

I needed the middle ground. Competent enough to be taken seriously, but not skilled enough to draw too much attention. But not so polished that Hurbasa or the others started wondering exactly who had trained the refugee boy. Only Astaron needed to see who I was. I was Haestus’ son.

Fine. I’d give them a fight, just not the one Father would have expected.

I focused on his stance, it was relaxed, his sword arm out to his side, his other arm behind his back, as if inviting me to come attack.

I knew it was bait. I took it anyway.

Three strikes, fast and hard, I aimed to break his guard and go in for a tap. I put my full weight behind each one—like Tommy might’ve—aiming to break that infuriating calm.

Crack. Crack. Crack.

The screeching sound of wood against wood rang hard in my ears as he parried each of my attacks effortlessly, barely shifting his feet. But his eyes had changed, he wasn’t buying it.

“Interesting.” he said, voice flat. Then he moved.

His counterattack came immediately. It was a technique I’d recognized instantly. Father had drilled it into me a thousand times. It was too easy.

His blade feinted left, I took the lure, overcommitting to the strike like someone who’d seen the obvious play and panicked.

Then the sweep came low, as I’d expected. A quick swipe at my legs. I threw myself backward—not a clean dodge, but a stumbling half-fall that looked like desperation. I landed on my heels and nearly went down for real.

His wooden sword rose for the finishing strike, aimed at my exposed torso while I was off-balance and vulnerable.

But my sword arm was ready. As his strike pierced toward me, barely, just barely did I deflect it. The angle was wrong, not the way I’d practiced, so it really was a clumsy parry.

The hit pushed me back and one knee hit the mat. The exhaustion was catching up fast. Weeks in the box had left me weakened.

I pushed myself up, breathing hard, making it look like that exchange had cost me everything. But I'd defended all three strikes. Desperately, but I'd defended them.

Kalandyr stood opposite me, his sword lowered. “You read that before I moved.” He said.

The room had gone quiet.

“No, I didn’t. Just got lucky I suppose” I said.

“You did. You were off-balance, yet you blocked my every move. Your sword arm was always in position. That’s not luck.”

I tried to keep my breathing ragged, to seem more tired than I am. I got down on one knee to catch my breath. “I’ve seen that combination before. Back home, soldiers training outside in the yards. I used to watch them sometimes when I was young.”

“And you simply … remembered? Years later, in the midst of a duel?”

He stepped closer, close enough I could see the thoughts forming behind his eyes. I got back up before he reached.

“Useful memory you’ve got, but that’s just not true.”

I said nothing.

“Who trained you?”

Before I could even answer, Hurbasa’s voice whipped through the hall. “I didn’t call you up here to have a chat. Kalandyr, get back in line. Rand’ar, go join the others.”

Kalandyr’s question hung in the air between us. He held my gaze for a moment longer, one last scrutinizing look as if that would help him decipher the truth.

I pushed through to the back of the group, legs shaking. My ribs ached where they still hadn't fully healed. Around the ring, the other recruits were already turning back to their own sparring, the brief entertainment over.

Hurbasa’s eyes followed me to the edge of the room. "You'll do," he said, flat and dismissive. Not praise. Just acknowledgement that I wasn't completely useless.

I grabbed a rag from a bench and wiped the sweat off my face. A thought struck me then, unwelcome and cold. During all those weeks in the box, that woman had never asked about the North's defenses, never pressed for names of contacts or co-conspirators. Every question had been the same: who sent you, how did you find us. As if she'd already known the answer. As if she'd been asking the wrong questions on purpose.

But why would she already know? And if she knew, what had she been looking for instead?

I pushed the doubts away. It did not matter, I was surviving, barely scraping by, I had to focus on just making it through.

Across the room, Kalandyr had already picked up his wooden sword and was getting ready for another fight. Poor fool, whoever fought him.

Tommy appeared at my side, handed me a water skin. "Thought he was gonna kill you for a second there cuz."

“Yeah,” I said, gulping down the water. I had forgotten how thirsty a fight can get. “Me too.”

Mirvel leaned against the wall nearby. "You held your own though. More than most do against Kal."

“Hmm.” I said. I had held my own, but that hadn’t meant I’d won, and we all knew it. I couldn’t risk a fight like that again, I’d already revealed too much. I was sure someone would come asking questions. Maybe Kalandyr, maybe someone else, but when those questions would come, I’d be ready.

chapters.title: Chapter 9
chapters.content:
“—heard you held off Kalandyr—”

“Were you really in a cell?”

“Is it true you’ve trained in—”

A hand grabbed my shoulder suddenly, “Look for the mountain trial, my group needs someone who—”

"—can actually fight, not like these—"

"My cousin hid some supplies, we just need—"

Someone shoved through to my side, knocking two people aside. The terrible hot breath in my face, “You owe us, we all saw what you can—”

“What the hell are you all talking about?” I managed to get out.

“The Trial, obviously,” someone spoke up from behind me.

“Bullshit, he doesn’t owe anyone—” Mirvel snapped.

“Stay out of this, no one asked you to play white knight. I’m talking to—”

The voices blurred together. No, I could hear them all distinctively, at the same time, yet I could not focus on any of them. I couldn’t think, I couldn’t focus on anything but the noise. The food on my plate was still warm, but I didn’t feel like eating, not with the overwhelming shouting all around me.

The smell of sweat and body odour was overwhelming. At any point I thought I might puke, I had to get out of the crowd. But there were people packed all around me. They were all huddling together, hollering at each other, squawking in my ears. If anything, I knew I didn’t want to join them.

"—just one spot in my group, that's all I'm—"

"He's not picking you, are you stupid—"

"I can get us through the lower pass if—"

Another hand, this one gripping my forearm. "Listen to me, just listen—"

I shoved his grip away, but another person grabbed my shoulder. “Three days, that’s all we have before—”

"—heard people die out there every year—"

“Shut up, you’re just trying to scare—”

“Maybe you’re scared—”

The voices were too much, they each climbed up over each other, reaching the ceiling far above me, only to fall down right into my ears. There were three, maybe four people pressed up against me, and I could hear their heartbeats thumping loudly in their chests. I could feel their anxious anticipation—who would I choose?

I didn’t want any of them.

I clenched my hands under the table. I had survived the storm with no equipment. I had endured that woman’s punishment. I had survived, and I would continue doing so. I didn’t need their help. What had these people done except beg?

"—you have to understand, without someone who can—"

"Get off me," I yelled. It was too quiet, no one had heard me except Tommy, who gave me a queasy look.

"—my brother died in the trial last year, I can't—"

A hand grabbed my bad shoulder, the one still healing from the fight. Pain flared down my arm.

“I said—” I shoved the hand away, pushing it into someone else's face, “get OFF!”

Everyone went quiet for a moment, all the pointless bickering and screaming, it all died down. Oh, how peaceful that moment felt after the senseless yapping in my ears. I noticed Kalandyr in the far end of the dining hall, munching on his food quietly. He sat alone, and didn't look like he could care about the trial. Why didn’t they bother him instead?

My respite lasted mere moments, ever fleeting, before the quarreling started up again.

“Real nice,” someone muttered. “We just want to—”

“I’m just saying, one fight against Kal, thinks he’s—”

“Didn’t even win that fight—” another voice cut in, sharper.

"Lay off him," Tommy said, stepping closer. "He doesn't owe you anything."

"Oh, so you've already got your little group sorted then? That it?"

“We’re just asking—”

“You’re not asking, you’re demanding.” Mirvel shot back.

“And what, you two get first pick because you sleep in the same room.”

“What else is going on in that room?” Someone shouted, snickering.

“Oh, piss off.” Tommy said, shoving the boy.

That started a fight. Mirvel rushed to try to calm the other kid down, but it was too late. The shouting exploded, everyone rushed around them to pick a side, the bodies scuffling everywhere.

I couldn’t hear anything except the buzz of shouting. My head was pounding behind my eyes, threatening to pierce my skull. I used the chaos to slip away. My vision swam as I pushed past the edge of the crowd. Had to put a hand on the wall to steady myself. The voices were already quieter here, just a few steps away, but my head still throbbed with each heartbeat.

No one had noticed I’d left, they were too focused on Tommy swinging at some kid twice his height. No one except Kalandyr, his eyes were on me the whole time.

I stumbled through the winding hallways back to the dorm room, the headache immediately getting better without the inordinate racket in the dining hall. Tommy shouldn’t have fought for me, I had never asked for it. I didn’t want the attention it would bring, but part of me was grateful that he did. But this had complicated things.

I didn’t want friends, didn’t need them. Had always coasted through on my own. I wasn’t allowed to make friends in the North, and I’m glad for it, it always ends in disappointment or betrayal.

I’d just burned my only chance to find capable teammates. Now I was stuck with Tommy, who picked fights he couldn't win, and Mirvel. Now we were a team by default—not because I'd chosen them, but because I'd run from choosing anyone else. They defended me, and I’d wondered if I could have found someone more competent for the trial instead. The guilt sat heavy in my heart, but not heavy enough to erase the doubt. I had to survive the trial, gain Astaron’s trust and learn about who Father really was.

I collapsed into the bed, desperate to squeeze out the pain in my skull. I pressed my palms against my eyes until the throbbing eased. There were footsteps in the hallway. The door swung open.

"Thought you might be here," he said, shutting it behind him. He didn't ask if I was okay, just pulled up a chair and sat.

We waited in silence until Tommy arrived, knuckles bloody, grinning despite the split lip.

“Got him good.” He said, wiping the blood off his lip. I was surprised, I expected him to get his arse handed to him.

“Was it worth it?” Mirvel sighed.

“Aye, it was. That trick you showed me yesterday was real proper, cuz.”

“Hmm, which one?” I asked.

“Stepped into his reach when he swung, just like you told me.”

“Wouldn’t that make you easier to hit?” Mirvel asked.

“They expect you to back up, ruins their momentum when you don't.” I said, still rubbing my temple. “Why’d you jump in, Tommy?”

“Don’t mention it.” He grinned.

“No, you shouldn’t have done that. I could’ve handled it myself.”

“Sure, you looked real calm.” Tommy’s grin faded, “Like you were two seconds from breaking that guy's arm."

"I had it under control."

"You didn't," Mirvel said quietly. "You were shaking."

I opened my mouth to argue, then stopped. They were right. I hadn’t had it under control.

"Look," Tommy said, flexing his bruised knuckles, "you don't get to tell me when to fight. That's my call, not yours."

"And when they come after you for it? When Orem finds out and you're scrubbing floors for a week? Or worse, out in the storm for a night?"

“Then I better get scrubbing, and better learn how to make a fire.” He shrugged. “Worth it.”

"We're not gonna stand there and watch people talk to you like shit," Mirvel cut in. "You can handle yourself, fine. But that doesn't mean you have to."

“I don’t need—”

“Yea you do.” Tommy sat leaning against the wall. “Maybe not need, but … we’re in this together now, right cuz? The trial, all of it. That means we’ve got your back, and you better got ours.”

I much preferred to do things on my own, then everything is in my own hands, the successes and the failures. Other people are a complication, unpredictable, and never as structured. But I needed the allies … and the friends. They’d proven their loyalty, it was time for me to prove mine.

“So, guess we’re a team then, for The Trial I mean. I don’t get it though, why did everyone care to team with me so much? Just because I held my own against Kalandyr? Isn’t the trial about surviving?” I asked.

Mirvel and Tommy exchanged a glance.

“It is about surviving,” Mirvel said carefully. “But not just the cold and the mountain. There are … other groups out there.”

"What do you mean, other groups?"

“Trial ain’t just our year,” Tommy said. "It's anyone who hasn't completed it yet. Could be fifty, sixty people scattered across the mountains. Maybe more."

“And they’re all competing for the same resources. Food, shelter, and any other equipment they scatter out before the trial. Sometimes groups run into each other."

“And when they do?” I asked.

Tommy's grin was humorless. "Depends on the group. Some trade. Some avoid each other. Some..." He shrugged. "Fight for what the other has."

“People die out there, every year.” Mirvel said. “It’s a culling farm, keep the best and let go of the rest. Sometimes it’s the cold, or the wolves, but mostly, it’s just the other recruits.”

I stared at them. "So everyone wanted me because—"

“Because you can fight,” Tommy finished. "And out there, that matters more than knowing which berries are safe to eat."

“So why don’t they ask Kalandyr? He’s a better fighter than I am.”

“He’s been here for a few years, did the trial a while—” Mirvel said.

“Apparently, he did it by himself.” Tommy butted in. Of course he did the trial himself.

“Shut up, someone definitely made that up. No one’s doing the trial alone, only a fool would.” Mirvel said.

So what, that leaves me as the next best choice? At least I wouldn’t need to fight Kalandyr. But we still needed to survive out there, and I wouldn’t consider stumbling through the storm good experience. We’d need to hunt, stay warm, and keep safe from the others. And most importantly, we needed to stand out.

Astaron held the answers I'd come here for—who my father really was, why he'd left, what he'd done before abandoning it all. Prove yourself, he’d said. The old man wouldn't share the tales of Haestus with some mediocre recruit who barely scraped through training. He'd share it with someone who'd earned his attention.

“You're just jealous no one’s making up stories about you like that.” Tommy cooed back.

"When I survive the trial, they'll have plenty to say," Mirvel said proudly.

Tommy and Mirvel weren't the teammates I would've chosen if I'd had time to think, to plan, to assess who could help me succeed. But they'd stood up for me when no one else had. They'd chosen me before I'd chosen them.

That had to count for something.

"So we're agreed then," I said. "The three of us."

"The three of us," Mirvel confirmed.

Tommy cracked his knuckles and grinned. "Just try to keep up."

Outside, the wind howled against the wooden walls, a stark reminder of where we’d be spending our nights in just a few days. A week in the cold, outside, with the wolves, other recruits, and whatever else the Belt could throw at us.

We just had three days to prepare.

I could only pray that’d be enough.

chapters.title: Chapter 10
chapters.content:
The morning of the trial came faster than I’d wanted. We hadn’t had enough time to prepare, despite the full days of training, making fires, and hunting. The sky was a bland grey, and the wind had slowed to a still, the weather inviting us to the outdoors, only to trap us later.

The groups had been a mix of choice and assignment. Besides me, Mirvel and Tommy, we had a fourth. A scrawny boy named Jorik who looked like he’d been starved all his life—all sharp angles and hollowed cheeks. His hands were stained dark around the fingernails, and when he caught me looking, he tucked them into his sleeves.

I suspected he’d be the first to go, fading into the cold dark before we’d even made it three days in.

“I can work a snare,” he’d said quietly, after first being assigned to our group, and as we discussed in our dorm. “And gut whatever gets caught in it. Won't waste any of the meat."

“Great,” Tommy said, “So you can hunt.”

“Well, err, no. Not hunt. I mean—I set traps. Snares. For small game, rabbits mostly. And I can clean them proper. Use everything. The meat, the pelt, the sinew. Nothing wasted. I can—I mean, I know how to do it right. Won't waste nothing."

Tommy raised an eyebrow, “So you can’t hunt.”

“I set snares. Snares.” Jorik repeated. “It’s not the same as hunting, but it works. Keeps you fed. I can do it. I know how.”

“We heard you the first time.” Mirvel said unkindly.

Jorik’s hands twisted in his sleeves.“Right, sorry. Just … making sure you heard me.”

Today he shifted uncomfortably beside me. Out in the grand courtyard where all of us recruits stood.

As we stood there in the open, I noticed Kalandyr among the older Kethalan standing near the walls. What were they doing out here? They’d already completed the trial. Kalandyr’s violet eyes found mine for a brief moment before I looked away.

"What are the older ones doing?" I asked Mirvel.

He shrugged. "No idea. Probably just seeing us off."

Hurbasa was laying out the rules and explaining the trial. Astaron stood next to him, his face shadowed by that iron hat.

“You’ve all each been given a pack with a flask, compass, firestarter, a bedroll and a day's worth of rations.” His voice boomed through the courtyard. All around us, the towering mountains looked down at us, daring us to leave the safety of The Gauntlet, to enter their domain. “Beside that, each of your groups has been supplied with a rope, a map and some basic medical supplies. Lose any of these, and your journey may end with no return.”

“Your objective: reach the summit of Kael's Peak." He gestured toward the mountains behind him, somewhere in that vast white expanse. "It's marked on your maps. Three days to reach the base if you take the direct route, longer if you don't. Then the climb itself—another two days, depending on your path and your pace."

He paused, letting it sink in. Two weeks. Maybe more. I shivered at the thought, two weeks in the blinding cold. I looked around at our little motley crew. Tommy cracked his knuckles, Mirvel looked bored, Jorik shivered beside me. We’d need other allies.

"There are multiple routes up the mountain. Some are faster but more exposed. Others take longer but offer shelter and game. Choose wisely—your route will determine more than just how quickly you finish." His eyes swept across the assembled groups. "It will determine if you finish at all."

Murmurs spread throughout the crowd. Someone whispered something about other groups, and fighting for the best paths.

"You will encounter other groups," Hurbasa continued, as if he'd heard. "How you handle such encounters is your decision. You’ve each been armed with a sword and a beetle bow—although I’d recommend, keep the bow for hunting. But remember, reaching the summit and returning proves that you are worthy for the next phase of your training. Dead men don’t complete trials, so choose carefully.”

I glanced at the beetle bow strapped to my belt. Small enough to fit in one hand, with a spring-loaded lever built into the grip. Squeeze to compress the spring and draw the string, release the trigger with your thumb to fire. Quick at close range, accurate enough for hunting at distance. I'd seen a few of the older recruits training with them—compact, light, easier to learn than a longbow. The name came from how it looked when squeezed: the curved arms contracting like a beetle folding its antennae.

Astaron finally stepped forward, striking his long staff against the pale stone.

“Some of you will not return—unworthy,” he said, his voice not as loud as Hurbasa’s, but every recruit inched forward to hear it. “Some of you will fail—unworthy. Some of you will return emptyhanded—unworthy. And some will die. They will be the most unworthy of all.”

Someone from the back of the crowd shot out, “And what happens if we’re unworthy?”

“The Gauntlet doesn't keep dead weight. You'll be removed—contracts transferred to whoever will take you. I have no use for failures." Astaron’s response was cold, as if this was just the way of things.

“You came here as nothing. If you can’t prove yourselves otherwise, you’ll go back as nothing. Simple as that.” Hurbasa added.

The courtyard was silent, save Jorik’s shivering.

“But those of you who complete the trial, those of you who push through the cold, fear, hunger and stand atop that peak, those of you will be worthy. You will have proven you are more than recruits. You will have become Kethalan Bellators."

His eyes found mine, for just a moment, and I knew he was telling me to show him why I was worthy.

“The trial begins now. Stay firm, stay faithful.”

The courtyard erupted into motion. The groups scattered toward the opulent gates, some rushing, others trudging along. I saw Tommy and Mirvel already sprinting toward the village past the inner gate. I took one last look at the compound around me, at the towering walls, training halls, at the grandeur of it all, and the safety we were leaving behind.

Jorik stood frozen beside me, so I nudged him forward and we started sprinting too. I was a good runner, but Jorik was even faster than I was. He may have looked feeble, but he had a fire within him.

All of the recruits did, they all had a grim determination about them. Slaves given freedom, they knew this was their chance to prove themselves worthy and get back at their former masters and free their people.

But unlike them, I didn’t have that fire within me. I was in this cause purely for my own selfish reasons. Yet it mattered to me more than anything else.

The first few hours passed in a blur of movement. We'd headed in the general direction of the peak—south and east, following the sparse treeline until the compound disappeared behind us, marking our trail along the map as we went. Gradually, as the terrain forced decisions, many of the groups diverged, each taking their own path forward. Some climbed higher into the ridges. Others descended into the valleys.

By the time the sun reached its peak, most had scattered, there was still the odd group visible in the distance. Dark shapes draping across the white snow, barely visible.

We stopped at the edge of a group of trees that offered some shelter from the wind. Tommy dropped his pack with a grunt, Jorik collapsed against a boulder, and Mirvel pulled out the map.

“We need to decide,” Mirvel started. “Before we go any deeper, what’s our plan forward?”

We all looked at him blankly, how could we choose the path? Make the wrong decision and it’d be the end for us. We had to choose the path that had access to hunt, shelter in case of a storm, and the least resistance.

“Look, I’ve been studying the maps of The Belt from the library, and there are three main approaches toward Kael’s peak. Northern route follows the ridgeline, southern cuts through the valley, western route moves through the forest before climbing up.”

He traced the three paths with his gloved fingers.

“Northern looks the fastest, I’d say two days to the base, maybe less. But it’s exposed, no shelter, no cover from the wind or a storm. Any group that values speed will take it.”

“Western?” I asked.

“Longer, three days, maybe four if we’re slow. The forest has game and shelter. But it funnels everyone through one path once the trees finish. Choke points. If groups want to ambush or control resources, that's where they'll wait." He tapped his finger on where the forest finished and the climb started.

Tommy leaned over the map, “Southern one?”

“Four or five days, but we avoid most of the groups since they’ll want to take the shorter paths. We’d have to traverse around the entire base before starting our climb.” He made a tracing motion from the compound in the north to the southern base of Kael.

“It has more shelter from the elements, better hunting with cover for Jorik's snares. The climb from the base is gradual, making it easier before the final push. It’s not the fastest, but it’s the safest from both the elements and the other groups.”

“So we’d be avoiding the crowds.” I asked. That’s what worried me most. People would jump to quick violence out in the wild with no consequences.

“Mostly. There’ll still be some groups, but not the desperate ones looking for easy targets or the fastest routes.”

He continued, “I don’t want to make the final decision, you guys should decide.”

“Southern route,” I said immediately. “We avoid the crowd and we gather food before the final climb. Anyone taking the northern route is underestimating how long it’ll take to get up and will probably starve before making it halfway up.”

Jorik looked relieved and Tommy nodded in agreement.

“Southern it is,” Mirvel folded the map away, careful to not let the snow dampen the paper.

“Let’s move now, cover as much ground as we can today and put some distance between us and the other groups. If a scuffle breaks out in one of the other routes, more groups might filter towards the southern one, so let’s get ahead,” I said.

“Agreed,” Mirvel said.

We shouldered our packs and headed towards whatever awaited south.

I was keeping watch, stuck beyond the safety of the rock outcropping we had set up under for the night. A crude shelter made of sticks and firs, and the thin bedroll was all that protected us from the elements. We had a fire going earlier but the blazing winds had snuffed out the embers.

I sat in the branches of a nearby tree and felt the soft snow falling on my cheeks. It was the second night since we’d left the compound, we were halfway to the southern base, careful to avoid the obvious trails down south.

I considered getting up to check Jorik’s snares, they were our primary source of food, but alas, it was too cold, and I didn’t want to go far from the group. They all slept so peacefully, like this was all normal—just another day.

My sleep had been restless, I was jolted awake by the lightest crunches, the shuffling of blankets, and the shrieking of gusts.

As the wind slowed down, I jumped down to get the fire going again. The embers from the previous had long since died, leaving only soot and ash.

I pulled the firestarter from my pack, along with a small pouch of dry tinder we'd collected yesterday. My fingers were stiff from the cold, clumsy as I arranged the tinder in a small pile.

I struck the steel against the flint. Once. Twice. A spark landed, and I leaned in close, cupping my hands around it. The wind came to a still, the cold was a lot easier to bear suddenly, and the sounds of nature all came out.

Suddenly, I heard the distant sound of something crunching in the snow. Footsteps—no two sets, coming from opposite directions. One was far off, staying far beyond the perimeter of our camp, almost out of range.

I strained to track both, but the closer, heavier set demanded my attention. The sound was getting closer, it was coming from beyond the rock outcrop, I heard the dull voices of whispers, but I couldn’t be sure. Multiple voices. A group.

The distant footsteps faded away into the background, either moving away or overclouded by the closer set. We were being flanked, perhaps two groups that had allied. I wasn’t sure what to do, wake the others? Kill the fire? They had no doubt seen the smoke by now. I quickly nudged Jorik awake, the lightest of the sleepers.

“Footsteps, two groups, get your weapons ready, and wake the others.” I motioned him to stay quiet as I peeked over the boulders, it was too dark to see clearly but there must’ve been four figures, one of them carrying a lone torch. Definitely a group.

I heard their groaning as Jorik woke the others.

“Quiet,” I hissed.

“How the hell’d they find us?” Tommy whispered.

“Shut up, probably our footprints,” Mirvel answered. “What do they want though?”

“Get your weapons ready, and watch our flank, there might be someone going around.” I pointed at the trees behind us without turning back, my eyes still focused on the group ahead. They were running toward us, their footfalls making deep crunches in the snow.

My mind raced. Could I circle around fast enough? Come at them while they were focused on the others? No, that’d leave them exposed, and too risky to get lost in the dark. If they saw me, I’d be isolated, easy pickings. Besides, there’s the person watching from behind us, we had to be prepared for two groups.

Better we faced them together. Let them make the first move.

“Tommy, Jorik, get your bows ready and stand behind us, one of you keep an eye on the treeline, there might be another group.”

“You sure? I don’t hear anything behind us,” Mirvel piped up.

“Just trust me,” I didn’t have time to explain.

The footsteps stopped just beyond the firelight. Four shapes, barely visible in the darkness, the torch casting long shadows behind them.

“Oi, we know you’re awake.” A voice called out. Male, a deep voice, but strained. “We need something of yours.”

“What do you want?” I called back.

“Your map,” another voice called out. Feminine, but older than us.

“We lost ours. You guys look like you know where you’re going.” A third voice called out. Another boy, but this one was younger than the other two. “I’m sure you’ll figure out the way from here.”

The fourth one stayed quiet, furthest from the torchlight. I stayed weary of that one, he could easily slip into the shadows of night.

“I’ll have to refuse, not our problem you lost yours.” I shot out.

The first voice handed his torch to the girl beside him and jumped down the rock, sword at the ready. I unsheathed my own, letting the blade do the talking.

“Then we’ll have to take it.” He said matter-of-factly.

He was clearly visible in the firelight then, a head taller than me, broader in the shoulders, perhaps seventeen or eighteen. His face was gaunt, cheeks hollow from days without proper food, but his grip on the sword was steady. This wasn’t his first tussle.

He had a pugnacious look about him, his eyes were already flicking to the rest of the group, planning some strategy, the others in his group dropped down beside him. I stood my ground, on the opposite end of the campfire.

His eyes flicked past me to the figures behind. Tommy, still holding his bow. A smirk tugged at the older boy's mouth.

“Stubby, that you back there?” He started laughing, “Shit, if you’re the brains of the group, then this’ll be easier than I thought.”

Tommy’s jaw tightened, but didn’t respond.

“What does that leave you as?” He pointed his long blade straight toward me.

“Protection.”

chapters.title: Chapter 11
chapters.content:
I leaped to the left, careful to isolate the man in front of me, leaving his group behind him. The campfire on our side, still smoldering, its flames racing in the dark.

“You won’t beat me.” I said.

I got into stance, pulling the blade outstretched beside my head, my other arm reaching its length. I saw his expression change, unease etched across his face. Father always told me to unarm before resorting to maiming or going for the kill. This one before me was no threat. I had never killed a man, and I did not want to over a bloody map. But a little fear would do him good.

He struck first, wide arching slashes with a surprising amount of power, each one easy to deflect, and left an easy opening for a counterattack. I feinted once, to see how he would react, he hardly noticed, he was too focused on his own raging strikes.

I let him tire himself out, keeping an eye on the others. Would the others jump in? If they did, I’d need to make it quick. The rest of his group looked confused, as if they hadn’t expected us to actually fight. Were they stalling for the other group? Regardless, it was clear I needed to end the fight fast.

He grunted with each strike, sweat beads lined his forehead. He stepped back to create some distance between us, and took a second to breathe and wipe the sweat off.

“Finish him already,” one of his teammates called out—the girl holding the torch. Her voice was tight with nerves.

"He's toying with you, Garrett," another said, the smaller one to her left.

Garett grunted in response, “I’ve got this,” more to himself than the others.

The fourth stayed silent, still half-hidden in shadow.

I shifted my grip on the sword, enough stalling.

His next strike came tighter, angled for my arms, I quickly parried the attack, putting force behind it—his blade rang out and his grip faltered. He shouted in frustration but I closed the distance between us fast, ducking under his late swing. A quick knee to the liver and a hook to the jaw was all it took. Hard enough to hurt, but not break anything.

The sword fell from his grip, hitting the snow with a muffled thud.

He stumbled back, one hand clutching his head, the other his side, gasping for air desperately.

I quickly picked up his forsaken blade, ready for whoever came next.

“I warned you,” I shouted, loud enough for whoever was in the treeline behind us. “Now you’ve lost your sword and your map. Take your losses and head back.”

“We can still take them,” The girl hissed at Garrett, but Garrett couldn’t think straight, he simply stumbled into the rock and collapsed into the snow.

She didn’t wait for a response. Her sword scraped free of its sheath and she lunged—not at me, but past me, towards Mirvel.

She made it hardly two steps before a loud whoosh whizzed past me. The arrow took her right in the shoulder.

She screamed—sharp and high. “I’ve been shot! I’ve been … shot! Do something, get him!” she begged the other two.”

Tommy was already knocking another arrow, his face set. “Anyone else?” He called out, aiming his beetle bow at the other two, pointing rapidly at each of them.

The first lights of dawn were creeping over the horizon by then. The flank should have come by then, Jorik wasn’t even watching the back, his eyes were muddled with fear as he looked at the horrid scene around the fire.

The last two had their bows ready, but they were outnumbered.

“It didn’t need to come to this,” I said, pointing both swords toward them. “You can still walk away, just call off your flank.”

“What flank?” The fourth one finally yelled out.

I didn’t lower my blades. “I heard another group in the treeline. Either yours, or another group watching all of this." I gestured toward the treeline. "Either way, you're done. Two of you left standing, and whoever's out there is fresh."

The smaller one’s eyes darted between us and the shadows behind. Fear painted a new shade of pale on his stricken face.

Silence, except for the girl’s whimpering. Garrett still hadn’t moved.

“We’re leaving,” he finally decided, voice shaking. “Just let us take them and our stuff.”

“No, we keep the blade, and your arrows, drop them now,” Mirvel said.

“But—” the small one started.

“No buts, or you get an arrow in your back,” Tommy asked grimly, pointing the bow aggressively toward the kid.

“Drop all your arrows next to the fire and leave,” I repeated.

So they did, the two helped the girl up. Garrett finally got up, a dour look on his long face. He should’ve planned better, known better, fought better.

When they finally left, I tried to listen for the other set of footsteps, or any odd rustling, but whoever had been out there, was long gone.

Two days later we reached the southern base of Kael. After the encounter with Garrett’s group, we preferred to move in the early hours of the morning, and be better prepared for encounters at night.

The days blurred together, we walked until our legs burned, setting snares at each camp, rationing what food we had while Jorik's traps kept us from starving entirely. For water, we’d melt snow or drink from whatever streams hadn’t frozen over yet. Occasionally we’d see the other groups in the distance, but both sides kept clear—none of us were eager for another fight. The weather worsened as we reached the base, even our thickest layers felt like nothing against the thick winds.

Kael was a mountain that stood alone, valleys on all sides, connecting to other mountains. I looked up at the snow-capped peak and wondered what awaited us up there. Was there something to take back, showing proof of completion? I could only wonder.

I picked up the young deer, carefully removing the arrow from behind its shoulder. In just the last few days, I’d learnt how to use the beetle bow, through hunting and practice at camps. Despite that, no one got better results than Jorik. The scrawny boy had proved himself useful, keeping us all fed with his snares and traps.

But this was the biggest find we’d had since we got into the mountains. I dragged the carcass back to camp where Jorik was already working on a pair of dead rabbits from his morning traps. His eyes widened when he saw the deer.

“Where’d you find that?” He asked, eyes wide.

“Not far, small creek behind that hill.” I dropped it in front of him. “Can you handle something this size?”

“Uhh, sure, but get started on draining the blood like I showed you,” Jorik said softly, back to working on the rabbits. “Something this size, the blood needs to be drained fully or the meat’ll spoil faster.”

I grunted in response, this wasn’t the part I enjoyed. The thrill of the hunt was what excited me. To track the animal, to chase it through the forests, tracking its prints, its smell. To wait, imperturbably, for the target to settle down, to believe it is safe, and then let loose the arrow.

But dressing it was an important skill to learn. I rolled the deer onto its back and got to it, made a clean cut to drain the blood, careful not to let my knife slip too deep and puncture the gut. One mistake and we'd spoil half the meat.

“Where are Tommy and Mirvel?” I asked, watching the dark blood seep into the snow.

“They went scouting, I think—for a camp,” he said quickly. “Don’t want to get ambushed again, right?.”

“Good.” I replied, moving the carcass from the bloody snow. “We need to start planning our route up the mountain when they’re back.”

"You're good at this," I continued, watching him work.

Jorik shrugged, not looking up. "It's all I know how to do."

“Where’d you learn?”

His hands paused a moment, a small tremble passed through them. He dropped the knife and balled his fists, “My master. ‘Fore I came here. He'd take me hunting when I was young—not for sport, for food. Said I was too small for real work, but I could handle this."

He continued, “He used to beat me if I’d mess up, wasted any meat. ‘Every scrap matters when you’re ‘ungry,’ he’d say. Then he’d eat most of it anyway while he left me the scraps.”

I didn’t know how to respond to that, how to comfort him.

“He’s dead now, died a year ago. Left me to the streets, I guess that’s when Faux found me wandering.” He looked up at me with bitter eyes, “Turns out I’m still too small—too weak—for real work.”

"It's kept us alive. That's more than most people's skills can say."

He paused, just for a second, then kept working. But I caught the small smile.

“Could you … show me how you set up the snares for the rabbits?” I asked. “It’s a useful skill, and I'd rather not rely entirely on arrows when we're higher up. Game might be scarcer."

Jorik looked up surprised, “You… want me to teach you?”

“Yeah. Unless you want to keep it a secret.” I smiled back.

He wiped his hands on the snow, cleaning off the blood. "No, I just—most people don't care to learn. They think it's..." he trailed off.

"Beneath them?"

"Something like that."

I shook my head. “I may know how to fight, but if I can’t feed myself, I’d be dead before the fight.”

His smile grew a little wider. "It's not complicated. Just takes patience." He stood, brushing snow from his knees. "I'll show you after we finish here. Need to check the snares I set this morning anyway—you can help me reset them."

"Deal."

“I’m worried about the Trial,” Jorik started quietly.

“Why? We’ve been doing well so far,” I nudged him softly.

“I don’t want to go back,” he started. “To the streets—I mean. To being nothing.” he added quickly.

I looked at him. Really looked at him. Even then he second-guessed himself. He’d kept us all fed, knew every plant and trap, worked twice as hard as anyone else and still apologized when he spoke.

“You’re not nothing, Jorik. You’re the reason we’re not starving. I’m not that good at hunting, got lucky with that deer,” I nodded towards the carcass. “We’ll make it through. All of us.”

He nodded at me, “Thanks Rand’ar.”

We worked in silence for a few minutes before the sound of footsteps crunching snow in the distance grabbed my attention.

It was another group. I saw them coming up over the hill, they must have been following the blood trail from the deer I’d killed. I should’ve been more careful, drained the blood right there and then.

They waved from afar before they came close, hands raised and open. I put my hand on my blade, still sheathed, Garrett's one also hanging on my belt. "Easy—we're not looking for trouble!" They called out.

“What are you looking for then?” I shouted back. Beside me, Jorik was shaking, his beetle bow on the ready.

“An alliance,” one of the others called out as they walked closer. He looked around us, “Although, I don’t see the rest of your team.”

“They’ll be here soon.” I sure hoped they did.

Alliance? For what? We were doing fine on our own.

“How many groups are still out there?” I called back.

“Not sure, but we’ve heard the climb ahead is brutal. Groups fighting over whatever game there is up there.” The one who stood ahead said—their leader. They seemed more prepared than Garrett’s group, after all, they’d made it this far.

They were finally in view proper. Four males, they looked decently fed but tired. Their leader was tall and lean, maybe sixteen, with sharp eyes that kept sneaking glances at our supplies. The one beside him was stockier, a thick wool coat made him look even broader. The other two hung back, one had his bow gloved on his hand, but no arrow nocked, the last one was smaller, younger perhaps, constantly scanning the treeline as if he expected an ambush.

“Twin blades, is that you?” The leader asked, his face animated, like a child meeting their hero.

“Hmm?”

“We’d heard rumours, you took down Garrett’s squad, yea?” He said, pointing to the two blades at my belt.

“Oh. Yes, we did. They tried robbing us—didn’t work out too well for them.”

“Definitely didn’t, they looked like shit from what I heard. Heard Melissa was one foot in the grave.” The stocky one piped up.

“She shouldn’t have tried fighting us after Garrett got embarrassed,” A voice rang out behind me—Tommy’s, they were back.

Mirvel stumbled through the snow behind him, carrying fresh timber. He had a skeptical look about him and fingered his sheathe. I shook my head toward him ever so slightly. These guys didn’t look aggressive, they didn’t look like they were trying to start something, it was best to remain skeptical and keep an eye out. Besides if they had information for what lay ahead, might as well hear them out.

“Aye, Sure as hell shouldn’t have, twin blades here would’ve cut her up,” the stocky one said, nodding toward me and catching my eye. He had an unnerving look about him that I didn’t like, a hunger for more than food.

“What exactly are you proposing?” I asked, cutting the chatter short. “Make the climb together or just watch each other’s backs on the way up?”

“Nothing so formal, just look out for each other on the way up you know? Share game and all that,” the tall one said.

I didn’t like that, he was being vague, he wanted something else, he wanted more, and I wasn’t sure what it was.

“Besides, we already know each other, or at least me and Tommy go way back,” He continued, smiling widely, “Mirvel, you too, right? We've snuck past curfew together more than once. Remember that night we broke into the storage for extra rations? Orem nearly caught us."

Tommy grinned despite himself. "Barely made it out. Good thing Zach was on lookout." He said, nodding toward the small, jumpy one.

"Exactly. We look out for each other, always have." The tall one said, patting the younger one’s head, like an older brother might. He spread his hands. "That's all I'm asking for here. Same thing, different mountain."

“We need a moment to discuss. Stay there,” I said to them.

The tall one put his hands up in surrender, as he backed away, “Of course, of course, take your time. We’ll be all the way here.”

“I know these guys, we go way back. I say we—” Tommy started.

“I don’t like it,” Jorik jumped in, shaking his head. “Not one bit.”

“Who asked you?” Tommy glared at him.

“Nah I agree with him,” I said, gloving my bow. “They’re being pushy, what was that whole thing about sneaking past curfew, why’d he bring that up?”

“Yeah, besides, we’ve been doing fine up till now just us,” Mirvel insisted. “But if the climb really is as brutal as they say, and groups are fighting over resources up there, more numbers might mean the difference between if we make it or not.”

“More numbers means more mouths to feed, and we’ve been doing fine on our own. I saw how they were eyeing our stuff, it didn’t look good. What do they offer besides numbers?” I asked.

“Protection for one. See Kadar?”

“Who?” Jorik asked.

“The big one. He was a pit fighter before he came here. Used to wrestle for his master's entertainment. Broke a man's arm in three places once, bare-handed. If we run into trouble, having him on our side isn't nothing," Tommy said, punching the air in front of him.

“Great, so he’s strong enough to take down any of us if he gets close enough. Then why do they need us?” I asked.

“Look Rand’ar, I agree we should be suspicious, but we can’t just stay huddled up alone the whole way up. Everyone else’ll got allies on the mountain, we’ll need ‘em too,” Mirvel said.

He paused, matching me in the eye, “But you get the final say. You saved us back there with Garrett’s squad, and if we get into another fight, it’ll have to be you again.”

I wanted to say no. They were inviting us with nostalgia of old, bonds that once ran. But in the mountains, none of that matters, none of it matters as you lay buried in the snow, a frozen corpse, killed for the smallest disagreement.

I could see a look of wistfulness in Tommy’s eyes, fearful longing for home in Mirvel’s, they just wanted to make it out alive. Jorik’s hands twisted in his sleeves as his eyes darted between our group and theirs, desperate for someone to make the decision for him.

Mirvel was watching me, Tommy too. Waiting for the final call. Behind them, Rhen’s group stood ready, confident I’d say yes.

I was risking the mission either way really. To me, all that mattered was proving myself to Astaron, and keeping us alive.

I took a deep sigh, still unsure, but I had to make a decision. They all looked to me for it.

“Fine, but we keep our distance, we still keep watch for our own group, but if anything happens, we’ll fight with them.” I said, with uncertain finality.

Tommy and Mirvel nodded in approval, but Jorik’s face was blank.

“Alright,” I called out to the other group. “We’ll ally with you.”

“Great.” The tall one clapped his hands together, a warm smile on his face, “We've got another group we've been traveling with, they're camped about a mile east. Eight of us total climbing together."

Eight. The number hit me like a fist. Eight of them total, and only four of us. I’d weighed whether we could take them four on four, but with eight of them, maybe I could make it out, but the rest wouldn't. I'd just walked us into a position where we were completely outnumbered, surrounded by people I didn't know or trust. And I'd done it because Tommy smiled at an old friend.

I looked around, Tommy and Mirvel only looked delighted at hearing it, the more the merrier they must've thought. Only Jorik seemed to share my suspicions.

Eight. The number settled like a swallowed spear in my gut, twisting and churning. We were fucked if things went wrong.

chapters.title: Chapter 12
chapters.content:
It was loud, and my head begged to be split open. Twelve people meant twelve voices, twelve sets of footsteps, twelve heartbeats I couldn't shut out. I saw Tommy laugh with them all like they’d been friends for years. I sat apart, far removed from them all, watching.

They sat there, laughing and munching on that doe I had hunted. It was meant for the climb, but the other groups pressured us to share it.

“We’re all allies now, right? What’s the point of rationing when we’ve got fresh meat right here? Might as well feast while we can, ain’t nothing good gonna be up there. Nothing at all!” Kadar had said and Tommy had been quick to oblige.

I needed to get a word in to him, he’d been too trusting, too social with them. I tried to catch his eye, he looked back, chewing on the cooked venison, but he didn’t get my meaning. He turned back to the centre of attention.

"—so there I was," Rhen—the tall leader—said, hands gesturing widely, "halfway up that tower in the Gauntlet in the dead of night. Fifty feet up, freezing, thinking 'I'm finally gonna see what Astaron's hiding.' Then I hear—'Rhen, you absolute fucking idiot'—and it's Hurbasa, just standing there watching me dangle."

"Did Orem find out?" someone asked.

"I'm getting to it. So I'm hanging there, then I hear Astaron—'What are you doing up there, boy?' The old man himself."

Someone groaned sympathetically.

"So I panic and yell down, 'Lord Astaron! Checking the tower's structural integrity! For safety!' Dead silence. Then Astaron says, 'In the middle of the night. In your underclothes.' Because I'd stripped down to climb faster."

The group burst out laughing.

"So there I am, basically naked, freezing my balls off, and then I start sliding. Can't grip anymore. I'm cheese-grating myself down this tower, land right on my ass in front of both of them. Astaron looks at my scraped-up chest and says, 'Next time, wear some bloody pants.'"

The camp roared. Even some of my group were grinning.

"Never told Orem. But Hurbasa? Every time he sees me, he just smirks."

Imbeciles, the lot of them. I couldn’t bear the blasting laughter, so I slipped away. The headaches were getting worse each day, the sounds more irritating. I sat down at the foot of a large tree, far enough to just barely make out the camp’s voices.

My brain pounced at my skull behind my eyes, and in my desperation, I tried to rub my head against the tree trunk to calm the electrifying pain—it didn’t help.

I only heard the footsteps when they’d come right up to me. I looked around for the source in my dizzy state. It was Kalandyr, how long had he been standing there? How on Nerva was he there?

“Been having headaches, hmm? The sounds bother you more than they should, don't they?” He asked.

I didn’t understand, he was supposed to be back at the compound. But the second set of footsteps suddenly made sense—back at the standoff with Garrett, and in the days that followed, but how come only I’d heard them?

“I once had them too,” he leaned in, “Till I learned how to control them.”

“Why are you here? Have you been following me?” I asked.

“Oh no. No, you’re not that important alone. See, I’m a Watcher. What?” He asked, looking at my puzzled face.

“You think we let you all out here alone, to plunder and kill each other as you please,” he rolled up a ball of snow, throwing it as far as he could. “We make sure things don’t go too far out of hand, keep the Trial from turning into a massacre. Otherwise?" He shrugged. "We watch."

“What if I don’t need your watching? What if I told you to fuck off?”

Kalandyr grinned at that, “You could try. But then I’d have to report that the son of Haestus was being hostile. Astaron would certainly be interested to hear that.” He threw another ball of snow into the long dark. “Besides, I was going easy on you that day,” he exhaled with an irritating laugh.

“Keep my father’s name off your tongue. What do you know about him?” I demanded, rubbing my temples with my knuckles.

“Nothing really, I’ve just… heard some things.”

“You said you had the headaches once too, how’d you get rid of them?” I asked, desperate to be rid of them. They’d started the day I talked to Astaron, and only got worse with the passing nights. I hadn’t slept properly in days. The fatigue had caught up to me.

“Weren’t you just telling me to fuck off?” He chuckled with a dry humourless air. But then his voice turned weighty, “The sounds, the headaches—they’ll keep getting worse before they get better, don’t let it break you before then.”

“That’s it then. I know you know more, but you’re keeping it from me.”

He grinned at that, putting a finger to his mouth, “I’ll tell you one thing for now. The sounds, the details, you see more than the others do, focus on the elements you need. Make it back alive from the Trial, and I’ll answer one question about what’s happening to you.”

He started walking away after that, but I called out to him.

“So it happened to you too? The Ab—”

“It did—don’t say that out loud.” He hushed me. “It’s a cursed thing, don’t speak of it out here,” he shivered at the thought.

Cursed. I mulled the word over in my mouth, it dug around like a cold, sharp hook, prickly. Cursed, he’d said. Was that what had happened to me?

And with that, he was gone, disappeared back into the greys and whites of the mountains, all blending together with the wind.

I sat there for a long moment, my sword propped up beside me on the tree trunk. So there were people controlling the Trial. I wondered if they’d had to jump in yet in some corner of the mountain, perhaps to put down the dark tendencies of someone.

All those times I’d heard footsteps, just barely, I wasn’t dreaming it. It’s like seeing something at the edge of the peripheral, can’t be sure, but my gut told me it happened. It must’ve been Kalandyr all along, but why? For whatever reason, he was watching me specifically.

He didn’t seem to know much about Father, so it couldn’t have been to see the son of Haestus. He knew what was happening to me. The sounds, the headaches, the overwhelming sensory flood. He'd experienced it too. Called it cursed.

I returned to the camp as the groups settled in for the night, each turned toward their own packs, huddled around their own smaller fires. Tommy caught my eye, gestured to the spot they'd saved for me. I sat, said nothing about where I'd been.

Rhen’s group had set up their bedrolls close to ours, too close. We were one camp, sure, but we were still three groups.

I didn’t sleep well that night, not at all, plagued by nightmares of a tree wrapping around my lifeless body and squeezing while Kalandyr watched laughing. It kept going till I woke up in a sweat.

The climb got exponentially worse as we went further up, starting off gradually till we were on our hands and knees trying to crawl up to avoid being swept by the terrorizing winds.

The snow poured down on us, dropping any and all visibility to nothing. I only saw the whites and greys swirl together in front of my eyes as I clung on to the ragged rock.

A scream cut through the wind—high and terrified. Jorik.

I turned, squinting through the snow, almost losing my footing. I couldn’t see him, couldn’t see anything.

Kadar pushed past me, his massive silhouette pressed against the bleakness, toward where the scream had come from. I followed, grabbing onto the rope that connected us all.

At the end of it, Jorik was dangling off the edge, eyes wide with terror, one hand gripping the ice, the other flailing. Behind him a white void stretched on endlessly. My feet drifted toward the edge before I’d realized, tugged at my chest, like the Abyss had. While I was in my haze, Kadar didn’t hesitate. He dropped to his stomach and reached down toward Jorik.

I snapped out of it, my hand trembled over the grip of my sword. Was he—?

Kadar reached down and grabbed Jorik's wrist with both hands. "I've got you! Stop thrashing!"

He heaved, muscles straining, but he couldn’t with just a one arm grip. I reached down beside him.

“Jorik, grab my hand!” I screamed down toward him, praying the words weren’t drowned out by the storm.

I lunged for Jorik’s arm mid-swing and grabbed firmly. “Pull with me at once!” I screamed toward Kadar, he hadn’t noticed me going for my blade.

“NOW!” He bellowed. We pulled, my muscles strained till I thought my biceps might pop, the tendons threatened to burst. But slowly, inch by blasted inch, we pulled Jorik up to safe ground.

“Easy, easy,” Kadar said, surprisingly gentle for the big brute.

I embraced Jorik, the tears had frozen on his face. I patted him on the back, “Stay ahead of me for the rest of the way, alright? I’ll keep the back.”

Tommy clapped Kadar on the shoulder, “Good catch.”

He grinned at me and whispered in my ear, sparing a careful glance at Jorik, “See, I told you we could trust these guys.”

I stood there, shame burning through the cold. My arm had reached for my blade faster than I could think. What the hell had I been thinking?

Could we really trust these guys? I pondered. There was no reason for Kadar to help Jorik if they planned to turn on us. If anything it’d be an easy way to turn it into an eight on three. I had to learn to trust them, open my mind to the possibility that not everyone was out for my throat.

“Best we stop here till the storm lets out a bit,” Rhen called out from the front.

“Agreed,” someone from the other group said.

We were in a good spot, the outcropping protected us from the fierce wind. But we didn’t have the food to stay too long, we’d already been rationing on the way up. We hunted in the early parts of the climb, but game had disappeared entirely once the true ascension began.

The storm didn’t let up entirely but it certainly slowed down, and I pushed for us to keep moving. Sooner we made it up, the sooner we’d make it back down.

The winds pushed against us like a wall, and the mountain loomed ahead of us, challenging us to make the climb. The peak remained hidden behind grey clouds, but I could feel we were close, in my bones. Perhaps it was just the frigid air biting me.

We moved slower as a group but by the second morning we’d reached the clouds. The foggy landscape mingled with the blues of the clouds.

We huddled close around the spent fire, fingers chasing desperately for whatever warmth remained.

“My cousin did the trial two years ago, said there’s ten flags, and we’ve gotta make it back to the Gauntlet with one. Ten flags, twenty groups,” Luca broke the silence, one of the kids from the other group.

“Great, so we’re fucked from the start,” Rhen groaned. The words came quickly—too quickly, before Luca even finished speaking. Like he’d been waiting to say them.

“We should grab all the flags that are left, even if there’s more than three—fuck the other groups up,” Kadar grinned, looking at Rhen.

“My cousin also told me there’s proctors,” Luca continued, “‘Watchers’ he’d called ‘em, said they step in if anyone does what they’re not supposed—”

“Hell’s that mean, not supposed to, they didn’t tell us any rules at the start,” Tommy chimed in.

“And where’ve these ‘Watchers’ been? We ain’t seen ‘em yet,” Zach piped up, the jumpy one from Rhen’s group.

“Fuck you tryna say? My cousin’s a liar?” Luca shot back.

“Easy, Luca, he’s just saying they don’t seem to be around, maybe we’ll see one up top,” Rhen hurried in. Oh but they are around, I thought. Kalandyr might’ve been watching us from afar, nestled in a mound of snow, carefully following our tracks.

Their bickering continued, I simply tuned out the noise and studied the map for the rest of our path up.
