We continued up, my legs ached, each step a footfall in deep snow. The wind pushed down on us, each gust threatening to rip us off the mountain. Despite the gloves, my hands were numb, fingers strangled by the terrible winds. Just when Tommy was groaning about how he couldn’t go on much further, the wind stopped.

Not gradually, just a sudden stop. A serene quiet surrounded us, the clouds had disappeared. I lifted my head up—clear sky, bright sun—barely past its zenith. The storm below us roared on, muffled and distant.

We’d broken through the clouds.

The ridge ahead of us was clear of snow and a shallow climb, the peak ahead beckoning us to come.

We shimmied through the narrow ridge. I took the lead, grabbing fistfuls of rock, careful to keep my eyes forward and not glance at the sheer drop to my side. My foot almost slipped, a loose rock tumbled down the side—I didn’t hear it hit the bottom.

The summit came into view as the sun bore down on us, suddenly warmer than it had been below. I hadn’t realized my face was slick with sweat.

We reached the top with nothing to greet us except the flat expanse of rock and snow, and the screeching wind.

We were the first to arrive—it looked like, no prints in the snow. Or so I thought, until I saw the flags.

Two lone flags, planted deep in the snow, their fabric flapping viciously in the wind.

Two flags. Three groups.

chapters.title: Chapter 13
chapters.content:
I heard Rhen’s sharp intake of breath behind me.

“Alright, so here’s how—” before he even finished, I’d already slipped away to the flags.

“Slow down twin blades, there’s three groups and two flags. I’d reckon we did most of the heavy lifting to get up here. Me, Luca, and our boys. Your group just tagged along.”

“Didn’t you come asking us for an alliance?” Tommy asked.

“Shut your goddamn mouth,” Kadar growled, he licked his lips, hunger in his eyes.

While they talked, I’d yanked both flags from where they’d been buried, snow gushing out with them. I held my arms out to my sides for all to see.

“Now listen Rand’ar—” My mind was moving fast, I felt clarity in my thoughts like I hadn’t for weeks. “—there’s eight of us and four of you. Maths pretty clear on who—”

My body moved faster than my thoughts, I could feel the excitement, the adrenaline coursing through my blood. The math was pretty clear, it didn’t work, but I controlled the equation. It had to be there and then, I pulled one flag close, inhaled deeply and flung it with all the lifeblood within me—flung it far over the edge.

The flag was lost to the white void, never to be seen again.

“And now there are four of us each,” I called out calmly, holding the last flag up for them all to see.

“What the fuck are you doing?!” Luca pulled out his blade, his group followed.

I looked behind me, it was a steep drop, but padded with snow. I could make it.

The closest one to me was Zach. Tommy, Mirvel, and Jorik were at the back of the group.

Zach stared at me with his mouth agape, and a devious idea passed through my head.

Before I’d thought it through, I unsheathed one of my blades and put my sword to his neck.

“Any of you come closer, I’ll gut him,” I bluffed, blade aimed at Zach’s throat.

Rhen finally caught some sense, his hand went to his sword. “You wouldn’t—”

“Tommy!” I called out to the back. “The ridge—get down! Now!”

Tommy moved without hesitation, he pulled Mirvel down the descent with him. Jorik hesitated, stunned, he peeked over the ridge and froze.

“Move Jorik! Now!” Too late. Kadar lunged for him. Fuck, I needed to split them all up. Seven on one weren’t good odds. I hoped the insanity of it would make my pursuers think twice. I took one last look at the waning hill below, boulders riddled the path. A dangerous gambit, no doubt, but a risk I was willing to take.

I pulled Zach close, sheathed my sword and jumped—slipped rather—off the edge. I held tight onto both the flag and Zach, my tickets back to The Gauntlet.

We tumbled through fresh powder, the world spinning whites and mottled greys. Snow forced its way into my lungs, sending me into a coughing fit. We kept rolling, faster and out of control. Zach’s elbow caught my ribs, sending the wind out of me. Another impact, my hip against stone, sent a flaring line of pain up my side. The flag tangled around my arm, tried to rip itself free. But I gripped tighter, refused to let go as we tumbled endlessly down.

Only by the Hand of the Light or whatever higher force had taken me from my home kept me alive as we rolled down that sharp decline. It steered our path down, free of boulders, but not free of hurt entirely.

We rolled violently to a stop against a withering tree, spasms of white hot pain shooting up my spine. I coughed out the last of the snow while Zach moaned beside me.

I pushed myself up, “You hurt?”

“What do you care?” He snapped back, massaging his legs.

“Look, I don’t want to hurt you—so long as you work with me here. I just need Rhen to play along with our little game,” I inspected the flag, miraculously no rips on it. I still had my sword and bow. “You think Rhen’ll trade you for Jorik?”

He shot me the finger in response, still on the ground.

“Right, I’m gonna need your weapons and your compass—matter of fact, throw me your whole pack.” I pointed my blade at him, “Do it.”

I made him bury his things in the snow, save the rope which I held onto, and we began trudging through the sparse trees. The storm was calmer on the North side of Kael, its violent fury focused on ravaging the Southern side.

We continued in the general direction of The Gauntlet—North West, with only a compass to guide us. Zach tried to make a run for it twice, but he was no runner, and I caught him fast both times, threatening to take off a finger if he tried it again.

The descent down Kael was arduous, sparse with game, devoid of protection and lone of other groups. I suppose that was a good thing. We treaded down during the early hours of the morning and just before sunfall, times when other groups would be sleeping or making camp. At night, I tied Zach with a rope, bound to a tree while I kept watch.

I wondered where Tommy and Mirvel were, they jumped down the ridge right next to us, yet we never encountered them. I could only pray that they made it down safe.

My mind kept wandering to Jorik. He’d been wary of the others all along—I doubted he even fully trusted us. He was up there with Rhen and Kadar—if they'd even kept him alive. My gut twisted at the thought. I should’ve made sure he jumped with us, grabbed him if I needed to. But I’d been focused on the flag, getting away. Now Jorik was paying for my choices.

It took us an entire day to realize we were lost, with no map to guide us, we’d surrendered to the whims of nature. The compass kept us moving in the general direction sure, but without a planned route, we might end up somewhere else entirely. The mountains all looked the same, white slopes, dark rock, sparse trees. No landmarks that I recognized from our climb up. This was foreign land, we’d taken another path entirely.

By midday, I spotted movement through the trees below. Three figures, moving southeast. Another group.

I pulled Zach behind a tree. “Not a word,” I hissed, “You want to make it back alive right? Cause right now we're lost.”

I quickly buried the flag and my second blade beneath a twisted tree, marking the spot in my head.

“What now?” Zach whispered.

“Now we’re lost and desperate,” I put up my hands in surrender and called out. “Hey! We need help!”

“Stay there! What do you need?” One of them called out. “And where’s the rest of your group?”

“Got separated, they’ve got our map. We’re just looking for directions back to the compound, no problems.”

They showed us the route back to The Gauntlet, North through a valley, then East. We thanked them and headed on our way.

As we travelled toward the valley, our route became populated with hunt. Real food we hadn’t had in days. I managed to bring down a hare with my bow, and we ate it half cooked over a small fire, too weak to wait. The trees grew denser as we passed through the valley, providing cover from the wind. Zach even stopped glaring at me long enough to admit the direction looked right, we’d clear the valley by nightfall at this pace. For the first time since the summit, I let myself believe it was possible—that we’d make it back, that I’d see Tommy and Mirvel again. That I’d proven myself after all. I looked at the flag flapping in my hands, and the smallest of smiles creeped on my face.

Then I saw it before I heard them.

A small sunken boy standing on the edge of the clearing, a sword pointed to his neck. Jorik.

Rhen stood on the other end of that sword, an intense look in his eyes. Kadar stood beside him, his bow gloved.

Before I’d taken another step, I pulled out my sword and held it to Zach’s chest. “Just play along,” I whispered in his ear. “Tell him to trade. You for Jorik.”

“This has gone far enough, twin blades.” Rhen called across the no man's land that stretched between us. The wind swept around us, rustling the tree branches, leaving an eerie effect.

“Give us the flag, or I swear I’ll cut his throat,” he pushed the blade just deep enough to make Jorik’s neck bleed. Jorik shut his eyes, tears sliding down his face. His lips quivered—prayers, barely audible over the wind.

“I won that flag. Duel me for it, if your blade rings true,” I said.

“That was a smart move you made back there with the flag, and it would’ve worked, had this one run with you,” he kicked Jorik in the legs, bringing him to his knees.

I grabbed Zach by the hood and yanked him to the floor, my blade pressed to his ribs. “You kill him, I kill yours. Then I kill you anyway. You’ve lost.”

“Rand’ar please, give him the flag.” Jorik’s voice cracked, barely above a whisper. “It’s not worth it. We can—look for the other flag—or anything, please.” His breath hitched. “Please, I don’t want to die unworthy...”

Damn that Astaron, there was no one more worthy of freedom among us than Jorik. He couldn’t bear violence, and he’d be deemed unworthy for it. And myself, I’d fall in with him if I handed that flag over.

“Whatever the rumours might say, you can’t take the both of us,” Kadar called out.

“What rumours?”

“Haven’t heard? The Watchers made sure everyone knew about you.” Rhen answered. “Part of the trial, I figured—stir something up. Stories of you crushing Garett, sending him limping back. How you took the last flag right off the summit, how you held your own against Kalandyr and walked away.” He grinned.

“They’re calling you ‘The Fallen’ now. Fell right off the summit and kept running.” Kadar finished.

“Then you’ll know you’ve lost.”

Why were the Watchers stirring things up? Was this Kalandyr’s doing? Never mind, none of it mattered in that moment.

“I reckon we’ll take our chances, Kadar’s a real fighter,” Rhen nodded toward him. “I reckon when we’re done with you, they’ll talk about how you fell to my blade.”

“You take a step closer and Zach loses his head.”

Silence stretched between us. The wind died down. Everything went still. I stared into his eyes, he bared his teeth back, none of us ready to back down.

Rhen’s grip on Jorik loosened. The blade pulled back from his neck. “Alright, alright, you’ve won. We’ll trade.”

Jorik’s eyes finally opened, his prayers ceasing mid-mumble. He looked up at me, a new light shining in his eyes. I loosened up on Zach. Jorik got up and began—

The sword plunged right through Jorik’s chest, protruding out in front of him.

Jorik’s eyes went wide as he grabbed the blade. His blood splattered the soft snow in front of him. Rhen yanked his sword free.

Jorik’s face still had a smile, like his mouth told a different story than his eyes. Then he crumpled into the snow.

“No—” The word tore from my throat.

Rhen wiped Jorik’s blood in the sleeve of his arm, “Now give me that fuckin’ flag.”

My eyes scattered, to the trickling blood in the snow, to his fallen body. Jorik was dead. The skittish kid who’d finally smiled when I’d asked him to teach me. Dead in the snow over some damned flag. Rhen had killed Jorik. Deemed him unworthy.

My vision swam to Zach, still crouched on the ground, trembling. He was part of Rhen’s. He was with them. This was his fault too. He should’ve asked Rhen to trade like I’d told him to.

They needed to know, to understand. Or else, Jorik had died for nothing. An eye for an eye, it was only fair.

Rhen needed to be marked unworthy, I’d mark them all. Starting with Zach. But more than all—I needed to win. I’d been taken from my home, tortured, survived the bloody mountain and taken that flag—survived all this hell. I wasn’t going back empty-handed. I wasn’t going to be deemed unworthy like Jorik.

I was the son of Haestus, I wasn’t going to be sold as some slave. No, I was more than that.

My grip tightened around the hilt. I pulled Zach’s head from his hair, turned him to face Rhen, and before any further rationale could stop me, I swung the blade.

“Rhen—” he tried calling out.

Hot blood sprayed across my face, Zach made a wet, choking sound, his hands clawing at the heavens above.

Thump. Thump. Thump… I heard the last beats of his heart as he tumbled down.

A wild, animal scream tore out of me.

Rhen’s eyes drifted to Zach’s fallen corpse, a new shade of cold layered his eyes. “I’m not going back. I’m NOT going back.” He whisper-screamed, more to himself than anyone.

Kadar turned to him, shaking him desperately, “This was supposed to work! Now Zach’s fucking dead because of you. You weren’t supposed to kill Jorik you fuckin’ dolt!”

Rhen heard none of it, he’d dropped to his knees, his head between his legs, laughing—crying.

“I’m not going back. Not going back to Zargon. I can’t.” He choked.

His eyes drifted to the flag still in my hands, “We can still take it. We can still be worthy Kadar!”

“Rhen the Watchers—”

“Fuck them, if they were gonna step in, they would’ve. It’s up to us to raise ourselves up.”

I put down the flag and readied my steel, Kadar did the same. He still had some semblance of sanity, unlike Rhen who charged at me blindly, swinging furiously in front of him.

Kadar came at me from my side, I pivoted, but I was caught between them.

Kadar’s first strikes came low and fast. I barely got my blade down in time, just barely pushing it down towards the snow. The impact jarred up my arm, nearly knocked the sword out of my grip. He didn’t pull back, he came at me repeatedly—another thrust, aimed at my ribs. I couldn’t bring my sword up in time, I tried to twist away, the point scraped along my side, tearing the fabric. Blood dripped down.

My hands were shaking, each parry felt heavier than the last.

Another thrust. I knocked it away with a wide arc but it forced me to step back. I grabbed my side and tried to calm my breath.

Rhen circled around me waiting for an opening, laughing maniacally.

I couldn’t keep it up, I was bleeding heavily, my side all torn up. Was I ready to give up, having been so close to learning more about my father? I asked myself. No, I wasn’t ready for that. I had a responsibility, to my siblings, to Jorik—to myself—to keep moving forward.

I took one deep breath as they both edged toward me, then I dived towards Kadar, towards his legs. He swung—too high—and I dragged my blade up his spine, dug deeper as I slashed up. A deep howl erupted from his mouth and he stumbled forward and fell, leaving a trail of blood in the snow. He twitched once, twice, then went still.

Thump. Thump. Thump. His heart stopped its one purpose.

The manic laughing stopped as Rhen realized the situation. His eyes went wide and his hand trembled on the sword and it fell from his grip.

“WATCHERS!” He screamed, “He’s killing us! Will you just watch us all die to this monster!”

“No one’s coming for you, bastard,” I spat out. “Are you ready to meet your master? Pick up your blade and meet your end like a man.”

He sat cross-legged in the snow, next to Kadar’s corpse, the blood pooled around him. He was done, no fight left in him

“What’s the point, I’m fucked anyway—”

I swung down with all the strength that remained. It lodged deep into his neck, the blood sprayed on my hands. Rhen choked on his own blood. I brought the blade back up and swung again, his head rolled off. His headless-corpse toppled on top of Kadar.

Thump. Thump. His heart died faster than the others.

I stood there, chest-heaving, bleeding through my side, my blade dripping with the blood of three. Zach. Kadar. Rhen.

I picked up the gore-stained flag with my other arm.

I’d made it. I was worthy. The Fallen stood for another day.

chapters.title: Chapter 14
chapters.content:
I climbed the steps of the great tower in the compound. Each step up a painful reminder of what’d been lost and what I’d gained. I was alive for one, although I was stuck in Doctor Oroya’s clinic for three nights as she patched me up after the trial.

Tsk. Tsk. I suspect I’ll be seeing a lot more of you here, she’d said.

I’d brought her what little I could—strips of dried meat from the trial, helped her sort her supplies while I recovered. She’d waved it off but kept the meat.

Tommy and Mirvel had made it back, two whole days before me. Those bastards were fast.

Figured you’d died, cuz, Tommy laughed.

When I told them what had happened, with Jorik, Zach and the rest, they only looked at me in horror and didn’t talk much after.

As I mounted the last steps, I wondered if I could still make a run for it. I’d survived the Trial after all, survived through the bitter cold and made it out alive—had bested Kael. I could make it through the Belt, back to Nothello.

But I wasn't ready for that. Not with the questions about Father that haunted my dreams—questions only Astaron could answer. I still didn't know who had dragged me here, or what this curse was that Kalandyr spoke of. The Abyss, the headaches, the sounds that overwhelmed me—all of it pointed to something I didn't understand.

I needed answers before I could run.

I knocked on the wooden door to Astaron’s chambers. Once, twice, before Astaron said, “It’s open, come in.”

The smell of musk hit me before anything. His chambers were fabulous to behold, almost comparable to a Northern estaminet. Cloths of exquisite blue and light gold lined the expansive windows around the room. A deep maroon carpet covered most of the area, elegant wooden chairs set up around the desk.

The desk itself was something to behold, further accentuated by the man that sat behind it, his presence only added to the power of the room. He was writing something, dipping his quill in ink and scratching something quickly into a paper.

“Take a seat,” he said without looking up, gesturing to one of the chairs opposite him.

“I prefer to stand,” I said, hands clasped behind my back.

“You still don’t trust us, Rand’ar?” He said, finally moving the paper aside and setting his hands down on the desk.

Us, he said. No, I didn’t trust him. He’d been the architect of my imprisonment, no matter how many smiles he put on now or after.

“Forgive me, Lord, for being weary after you told me I was your prisoner during our previous conversation.”

“Have you felt like a prisoner? Have you not been treated just like any other student? Did Orem or Hurbasa single you out? Tell me and I will address it.”

“I suppose not,” I admitted.

“Then sit, Rand’ar,” he pointed again towards a chair. I gave in reluctantly.

There was a long pause after, like he was waiting for something. So I broke the silence.

“You told me to prove myself—that you’d tell me about Father once I did,” I said.

“I did. First tell me about the trial.”

“You already know everything that happened,” I sneered.

“I do, but I want to hear it from you,” he replied calmly.

I shifted in my sweat, “We made it to the summit. There were only two flags for three groups. Rhen's group turned on us. Jorik was killed. I took the flag and made it back."

“And?”

He knew exactly what had happened.

“On the way back, I encountered Rhen’s group, had to fight them.”

“Aren’t you missing something? What happened to the boy you kidnapped?”

There was no hiding from it.

“I had to put him down,” I stammered. Suddenly the carpet below the desk was a lot more interesting.

“Had to?” his voice remained calm. "I have 4 eyewitnesses saying you killed the boy in cold blood. He was your hostage. Rhen killed your teammate. Then what, you killed his in retaliation?"

I said nothing, could say nothing.

"Look at me, Rand'ar."

I forced my eyes up.

“You didn’t have to do anything. Zach was your prisoner, he was on the ground, unarmed, no threat to you. You killed him because you were angry. Why?”

“If Jorik was unworthy, then how was Zach any different? They all turned on us, he was part of them.”

“But you killed Rhen too, did you not? And Kadar? And did not report their deaths.”

“Why didn’t the Watchers step in?”

He paused for an uncomfortably long moment. The bottle clinked softly as he poured a drink, then he rose and faced the window behind him.

“The Watchers aren’t meant to intervene in every fight. They are there to watch you, see what kind of men you are out in the field,” he said, taking a long sip of his drink.

“Your father was a better man than you,” he continued plainly. “Were he in the Trial, he would’ve figured out a way to unite all the groups, to prove himself without the need of any flag. He would’ve helped the others survive.” He leaned forward on the desk, “That’s the kind of men I need.”

“I am not my father.” I said bitterly, staring back into his eyes.

“Are you your fathers son?”

“What kind of question is that?”

“A simple one. You claim not to be Haestus, fine. But do you carry anything of him? His principles? His judgement?” He paused, “Or is it just his name you hold.”

“Tch,” a sneer escaped me. “Who are you to question that? How do I know you even knew my father? Why would some man halfway across the world—”

“I knew your father for longer than you’ve been alive,” his voice cut through, calm and absolute, “Would you recognize his handwriting if I showed you?”

I hesitated, “I would.”

He grabbed a folder from his desk, inside was a well-preserved paper. I immediately recognized the signature at the bottom, it truly was Father’s. It read:

Astaron,

By the time you read this, we will be long gone. I write not to explain, explanations would take more pages than I have strength for. I write this to say farewell to an old friend who deserves more than silence.

The Withdrawal has failed, I hope you can see it in the coming time. Not in the way our enemies claimed it would, but in a way far worse. We freed bodies, yes. We broke chains of iron and returned men to themselves. But the chains that remain are woven deeper than steel, into law, into custom, into the very fabric of how power moves through this world. I thought we could change it. I was wrong.

My wife and her sister will accompany me North. Sera has asked to come, and I will not refuse her. I leave behind my brothers. One chose his path long ago, and it’s led him far from mine. The other… I pray he finds his own way to the truth. If you are able, I ask that you watch over those who remain, nothing more.

Do not look for me in the North. I do not go seeking for answers, I go because there is nothing for us to do here, and the North is far from my sins.

May the work we started continue in worthier hands.

—Haestus

I scanned the letter, read it three, maybe four times, like scrutinizing the dried ink would make it come alive.

Father had left. Had risen up with all that talk of freedom, of unshackling the chains, and he’d just… left. He just left. Ran North, leaving his family behind, because there was nothing to do. He’d brought his people up from the pits of hell and left them to suffer.

“Why?” I blurted out. “Why’d he give up?”

He continued, “Rand’ar your father understood something that you do not yet. He saw that winning battles doesn’t mean winning wars. That violence only begets more violence. He saw that killing everything in your path doesn’t make you strong, it makes you a slave to your rage.” He took the paper from me, my fingers dragged along the edge, almost refusing to let go. “Sons growing up without fathers, continuing the cycle of violence and revenge.” He looked me in the eye, “You know something about that.”

“Does a leader not accomplish his goal? By any means necessary? I did that, I got our team the flag, Tommy and Mirvel made it back because of what I did.”

“Four children are dead, boy. These were some of the only killings in the Trial this year. The other recruits—your own friends—fear you. A frightening leader is an ineffective one.” He sat back down and clasped his hands together, “You want to be more like your father? Hmm? Learn to control your rage, to acquire the respect of your team. “

He leaned forward, “Haestus didn’t command men, he roused them, the rage within them, and tamed it. They didn't follow him out of duty or fear. When he spoke of freedom, they took it like scripture. When he asked them to die, they went willingly, as if death for the cause was worth more than life without it.”

“I don’t care that you killed them, Rand’ar. I care that you killed them out of stupidity. Out of rage. Like a child playing the knight, with no thought for reputation or legacy.”

“You said you knew him longer than I’d been alive, then tell me, why did he really go North? What was he really running from?” I asked.

“That’s not a conversation for today,” he asserted.

“You brought me here, showed me his letter. You can’t just—”

“I will,” he snapped. “You want to know more? Earn it. The Trial proved you can survive, prove to me you’re an effective leader. You’ll be getting real assignments in the coming months—out in the real world, with real consequences. You’ll work with Kalandyr, who’ll watch over you. Succeed, prove you are worthy of Haestus’s legacy, and you will learn more.”

I grumbled, his eyes shot up at me, glaring. I got up to leave the room. If he wasn’t going to give me answers, I’d have to find them myself. From Faux perhaps, or Hurbasa. I donned my boots at the door and buttoned my coat and made to open the door.

“Did you hear it, Rand'ar? Did you hear the blade?” Astaron started.

“Uh.”

“How it whispered in your ear, like a devil. Creeping on you, inching up in your desperate moment, begging you to call for it. It hissed for you, to your opponent, like a loyal hound. But really, it is a snake. When the violence is over, it says ‘but I did not do it, it was all you.’ Defy the blade Rand’ar, don’t fall for its whisperings, and you may be a better man than your father. Remember this Rand’ar. When you face the blade again—don’t fall for its seductive lies. And it always lies.”

“That will be all,” he finished, back to scratching something on a paper with his quill.

I stepped out into the cold, staring into the distant mountains. Kael lay somewhere out there. What was that all about at the end, I wondered. Was he telling me to put the blade down, I didn’t understand. None of it made sense—Astaron’s ramblings, Father’s abandonment. Too many questions, and too few answers, it all made my head spin. But I was owed one answer at least—from Kalandyr, so I searched for him.

I sauntered down the towering steps of the great tower, the vast courtyard loomed ahead of me. A group of students practiced against each other, running drills under Hurbasa’s watchful eye. His voice cut through the air, barking corrections.

Beyond them, servants hauled crates toward the kitchens, steam rising from the building’s bold chimneys. The smell of baking bread mixed with woodsmoke, wafted in the air. Near the stables, I could hear the clang of the blacksmith's hammer—someone getting a blade repaired, probably from the Trial.

The compound felt different after I had come back. Before it had felt like a prison, shackles holding me back, now it gave the feeling of a second home, busy and full of the bustling noise of people. Safe grounds to rest on before going back out again.

I found Kalandyr past the training grounds, by the livestock pens of the eastern edge of the training grounds. He was tending to a small flock of goats, tossing hay over the fence, his breath misting in the cold.

“You’re here for your answer,” he said, without looking up, as he tossed more hay.

“You said I’d get it if I survived,” I replied defensively.

“I did. You survived,” he brushed his hands off and turned to face me, “Go ahead, one question. Make it count.”

“What did the Abyss do to me?” I asked, grimly.

“I told you not to speak of that,” he snapped. He started slowly, “It revealed your true nature. One of your parents must’ve been gifted with the Sight. Did any of them have a twinkling purple in their eyes?”

“My father,” I replied immediately, “But what’s that got to do with me?”

“Over the next few months, you’ll get the same shift in your eyes. Your perceptions will be enhanced, both a curse and a blessing. Like I told you earlier, learn to block out the noise, and the curse will dissipate.”

“Block out the noise?” I stepped closer, “How? And what’s the Sight? What am I seeing?”

He looked at me for a long moment, perhaps wondering how much to say. “The Sight shows you what others miss. Patterns. Intentions. You’ll see movements almost before they even happen, as if you can react the instant they occur. But it also floods you with everything else. Every movement, every sound, every heartbeat.”

“That’s why the headaches.”

“Yes, that’s why the headaches,” he confirmed. “You receive everything at once with no filter. Most who inherit it learn to control it when they are young. You?” He shook his head, “It ripped it out of you, forced your Essence to flood you.”

“So how do I control it?”

“Practice. Focus. Time. And more practice.” He turned back to the goats. “It awakened it inside you, but it was always within you. Just like your father, and your father’s father.”

“Did you struggle with it too?”

Kalandyr paused for a moment, turning slowly away. “Your question was ‘What did the Abyss do to me?’ I already answered more than just that.”

He must have, he said he’d touched it too, The Abyss. Just thinking about it gave me trembles. The endless falling, the infinite dark, the lack of sensation. It was hell, in a way no man could imagine it without experiencing it for themselves.

“We’re going to be working together. Astaron wants me to keep an eye on you.”

I tensed, “To make sure I don’t lose control?”

“To make sure you survive what comes next—and that too. The Sight makes you dangerous, to yourself and others.”

“And what, you’re supposed to teach me?”

“I’m supposed to keep you alive long enough for you to become useful. Astaron’s invested a lot in you, you know? You’ll need to get stronger fast.” He started walking back toward the dining hall. “Get some rest. Tomorrow we start real training. Nothing like you’ve ever done before.”

He left me standing by the goat pens, with new questions, apprehensions. The cold wind cut through my coat, a reminder of what had been, of the coming winter. It would be nothing like the North.

I wondered what my family was up to, they’d probably given up on me by then, had a funeral perhaps. Went back to their normal lives—they had to keep living after all. Minarra and Daryen must’ve started school by then. Remi would be practicing for the Institute exams, and there I was, across the Belt, with the people we’d left behind. Closer to the ghost of my father than I’d ever been.

My entire life had been upturned, I’d abandoned all sense of normalcy. It seemed everything in the South was the opposite, even the people.

In the North, everyone kept their head down. Looked after themselves. Trusted no one. Perhaps it was safer that way—certainly easier. But here? Tommy and Mirvel had followed me off that cliff without hesitation. Even Rhen—desperate, brutal—had fought alongside Kadar like they were brothers.

These people had formed bonds that transcended blood. Formed bonds that meant something, even in a place like this—like it was the only thing that mattered. Maybe that’s what Father understood, that’s what made those people follow him, jeopardising their own lives for him. It’s what made men follow him through a rebellion that was fated to lose. Loyalty wasn’t just duty—it was more than that, and I wasn’t sure I understood it then. Is this what friendships are supposed to be? I wondered. It didn’t make sense. It must be a means to an end, I decided.

I looked back across the courtyard, the group had dissipated and another group had taken its place, a younger one. Perhaps another batch of children who’d one day take the Trial.

I peered beyond the gate, beyond the village below, out in the open world. A world that had a calling for me, I just needed to find my place in it.

A soft snow began to fall, had already started to blanket the withered stone ground. The mountains, despite their looming strength, would be covered too. In that moment, I looked up at the soft pillowy clouds and closed my eyes.

For the first time since I’d fallen in the dark, I let myself just feel. Not the overwhelming rush of sounds, not the stabbing pain in my head—just the gentle cold of snowflakes falling on my cheek.

When they’d taken me from Nothello, I’d been someone else. After the Trial, I’d become someone else. Not better, perhaps worse, but someone new. Someone forged by the pain, by the blood, by choices I couldn’t take back.

But it was a fresh start, and a fresh start meant new foundations.

I could forge myself anew, figure out what kind of man I wanted to be.

END OF PART I

PART II

chapters.title: Chapter 15
chapters.content:
“Abba, why’d we have to leave the South?” I asked. I craned up to look at him as we sat on the edge of a wooden dock, his stern face shadowed by the sun above.

My fishing rod lay beside me, line tangled and long forgotten. I kicked my legs over the water instead, watching the ripples spread.

“The South is a rich land filled with beautiful souls,” he sighed, his line still in the water. “There’s rolling hills and dense forests as far as the eyes can see. And the people—families gather every evening, sharing meals and stories. No one eats alone.”

“Huuuuh?” I tilted my head to look at him. “Then why don’t we go back?”

“There’s also the bad people, they stay hidden in the corners and try to hurt families like ours,” his voice grew quiet. “Our family over there—they were taken by the bad people. Changed. We can’t go back, not ever.”

“But Abba, did you try to save them? Our family?”

“I—”

His line suddenly tugged, pulling my gaze towards the ripples in the water ahead.

“Look! Something’s tugging the line!” he exclaimed. He motioned me over and handed me the rod gently, resting his big burly hands on my shoulders. “Now remember, slowly reel it in just like I showed you before.”

NO—

He was just about to answer. Fuck.

But the boy I’d been was back to laughing, leaning over the water as the line went taut. The question had dissolved like mist.

Please, I begged myself. Why was I so stupid? Why was it all so fuzzy…

The sword was firm in my hands. Sweat lined my arms in the summer heat. He thrust at my chest. Easy. I stepped to the side and swung the wooden sword toward his neck.

My eyes darted to his face—his eyes, they were … black, like there was nothing behind them. A shiver crawled down my spine and I quickly averted my gaze. Before I’d finished the swing, he’d recalled his sword and pressed mine away.

“Good, good,” he said. His voice sounded hollow, distant, but still familiar. “You’re getting better, Rand’ar. Heard you’ve been training Minarra?”

Something felt wrong about that. You were already gone by then, I thought. You abandoned me too.

I was taller then—almost reached his shoulder. The practice yard felt… different, the edges blurred together. He’d been gone for years by then.

“Why’d you give up on them, Father?” A hint of accusation in my voice. “On our people—our family?”

“Your uncle—Aldrich—sided with our oppressors. He said it was the only way to keep our people alive,” his voice echoed flatly. “I couldn’t bear to see that any more, how he’d been corrupted—”

“So you left them? Didn’t try to help him see reason?” I cut across. I stared back into his eyes, everything in me begged to look away. I was wrong before—his eyes weren’t completely black. Something swirled inside them, like shadows made of mist. Fear took over and my eyes darted down into the dirt.

“So you didn’t have to see the suffering?” I continued bitterly.

The sun had begun setting for the night, long shadows stretched across the courtyard.

“I didn’t want to kill him,” he growled, his voice obscure and unfamiliar. “We fought many times. I tried to explain it to him—with him at my side, we could’ve stormed the Citadel. But he doubted it, was firm that we’d lose and I was wrong.”

“Astaron begged for an attack on the Citadel. But we didn’t have the numbers. We needed your uncle’s support, and he’d already chosen his side.” His voice cracked. “Going to war would’ve meant one of us would’ve had to kill the other. I… couldn’t go through with that.”

Astaron already told me that. Father was supposed to tell me more. Why hadn’t he explained when he was still alive? Now he was in the fucking grave, and he’d left me piss-all in the way of answers.

But the boy back then didn’t know the right questions to ask, couldn’t possibly know what Father was talking about. Before he could continue, darkness swallowed the yard, the last of sunlight vanished. The darkness swallowed us whole. When I opened my eyes again we were somewhere else.

I was sprawled on the ground. It was dark, not a single star in the sky, no sign of the moons either—just darkness. I pushed myself up and looked around. The place was unfamiliar and empty—like a painting barely started. I saw trees on the edges of my peripheral but I could never be sure, nothing to ground me to where I was.

I turned around and saw it—a dark figure, but not dark like shadow. Father, it had to be him, right? I stood up straight, as tall as the figure.

It had to be Father, the figure had the same broad shoulders, the same set of the jaw, but where his face should’ve been, there was only void. The figure stood reserved, the same darkness moved inside him, writhing and coiling like something sentient.

“Father?” My voice came out, deeper then, but hollow. I couldn’t see anything beyond him, everything was so dark, like all the light in the world had been taken away.

“You’re a coward,” I snarled. “Why’d you leave us? Why didn’t you explain things to me before you died?”

The figure stared blankly at me, seeing right through me. I looked behind me—was he looking at something else? There was nothing.

“Did you leave the South because you knew you'd failed? Or because you knew I’d have to be the one to finish it?” I pressed on.

Still nothing. The figure stood motionless.

“What kind of father leaves his son in the dark? You trained me all those years but you never explained why, you just told me to get stronger. I am stronger now!” I sobbed. I tried to grab him but my scarred hands passed right through. “Don’t you see, I’ve gotten so much stronger. We can fight together now!”

But he was gone, never coming back. Why was it hitting me so hard now? It’d been almost a decade since he’d passed. Why did it still hurt so much?

“I’ve trained! W-with Astaron! I can help you. Just… come back.” I weeped quietly. A knot formed in my throat as I tried holding back the tears. “Please Abba, just say anything. Anything!”

When I looked back up, the figure had dissolved into the darkness, leaving a swirling trail of light behind. Something’s wrong, I told myself. I pressed on, following the hazy light through the dark, stumbling over objects or roots I couldn’t see. As I kept following the light, it got brighter, pulsing and sentient. I broke into a full sprint after it, scared I’d lose it and be stuck in the dark forever.

The light led to the same figure of Father, yet something was wrong, his body was morphed. His arms were twisted unnaturally, his neck bent at an awkward angle. The mouth—rather a line barely resembling a mouth—moved. Sound came out, but it wasn’t words. A low hum, barely audible, like the ringing of a scream in a dreary cave. The sound burrowed into my skull, the vibrations threatened to tear my head open.

My legs began to tremble—falter—and the ground gave way, disappearing entirely. I tried to scream—but no sound came out. I fell through nothing. Through a sea of ink that grabbed and consumed me, cold as a bar of steel. The only sound was the ringing of bells, chiming, tolling, clanging in the distance.

I tried to flail, but my limbs wouldn’t budge, like they’d never existed, like I was nothing but part of the sea of void. My name scattered like ash, my essence diffused like a threadbare rope. Rand’ar—what did that mean? Who—

“Up! Now!” Something hissed in my ears.

I gasped, my chest was heaving. Sweat drenched my shirt, cold against my skin. Hands gripped my shoulder, solid, real, shaking me hard enough to rattle my teeth. The world tilted around me—trees, firelight, the smell of smoke. Not the dark. Not the fall. I tried to speak but my throat was raw.

“Are you c—” Faux started, gaping into my eyes. “Never mind. Bandits. Move. Quiet!”

I wiped my face roughly. Tears? No, sweat, I told myself. I was sweating. Why would I be crying?

I slipped off my coat, picked up the blade beside my bedroll, checked for my knives—one in my boot and one in my belt.

Faux motioned me to crawl over to the treeline. I sloshed through the mire, the mud seeped into my trousers.

Kalandyr was already positioned behind a log, still as stone, eyes tracking the bandits' approach. To my left, Kerra crouched low behind some shrubbery, blade on the ready, face hard and focused. Beside her, Mysha’s hand rested on her bow, calm despite the tension. Faux settled in next to me.

“How many?” I asked Faux.

“Five,” he whispered. I could barely make out two of them, my eyes still adjusting to the dark. One of the two held a torch and trudged toward our deserted camp.

“They were just ‘ere,” one of them said, a burly, ragged voice. “Don’t let ‘em get away, Drask’s gonna ‘ave our heads.”

“Look what we have here,” a third one whistled. Shit, he’d found our horses. He shoved his torch in their faces, ran his hands along their manes. “I say we let the fuckers go, take the horses ‘fore they come back for ‘em.”

One of the horses flared its nostrils, tried rearing up, but the rope snapped taut, jerking its head down. It stamped and pulled against the tree, whinnying sharp and high. The others started pulling too, ropes creaking.

“Those bastards,” Kerra growled, a fierce look in her eyes. “They’ve spooked the horses, it’ll take forever to calm them down.”

“We’ll get ‘em, don’t you worry,” Faux said. “Mysha, Kerra, take cover and watch for more of ‘em. When I give ya the signal, you start shootin’ like hell.”

Mysha nodded along quietly.

“Rand’ar, Kal,” he continued. “You both go down there and deal with the rest.”

“And you?” I asked.

“Gonna have a little chat with one of ‘em,” he grinned, like this was the most fun he’d had in weeks.

“I can fight too,” Kerra snarled. “Let me go down there with them.”

“I got no doubt that yer a fighter. But need ya up her with Mysha, so ya can pick ‘em off when they scatter. More useful than ‘nother blade down there,” Faux shrugged.

Her jaw tightened but she nodded, sheathing her sword. Faux slipped into the trees and we waited apprehensively. Down at the camp, the men plundered, stuffing down whatever morsel’s worth of goods they could find—mainly food. It must’ve been half a minute, but it felt like an eternity, before I heard a piercing whistle.

I leaped out of the bushes and sprinted down the hill, aiming for the one closest to me—the burly one. He was bent down, too busy rummaging through our gear.

“Look out—” the one by the horses bellowed, an arrow whizzed through the dark and cut his shrieking short.

The other two brandished their swords and waved them desperately toward me and Kalandyr.

“These don’t look like toilers,” one of them muttered.

“Sure as hell don’t,” The other shivered, backing up and shoving his sword desperately out toward me. “Don’t come any closer! We’ve got more of us down the road.”

I didn’t slow. Closed the distance in three quick strides. He swung high for my neck. I ducked under, watched as the blade made its way across, and thrust my blade into his throat.

His eyes went wide. Blood spewed out of his mouth, staining the steel. Beside me Kalandyr plunged his sword deep into the other bandit’s chest, dropping him to his knees.

I heard a guttural scream pierce the night—somewhere in the trees. Then another sound cut through. Sharper. Terror.

I spun toward the camp. The last bandit had broken from his cover and made a run for his horse. Kerra was already moving—fast, crashing down the hill. Her sword was drawn up to her shoulders and her eyes had a ferocious look in them.

The poor bastard didn’t even see her coming. She yelled something incoherent and drove her sword between his shoulders. His blood sprayed out and he tumbled into the mud.

“I had it handled,” Kalandyr retorted.

“He would’ve ran—,” Kerra doubled over, panting. “Would’ve called for backup.”

“Calm yourselves.” Faux pulled out of the bushes, Mysha followed behind. He dragged along a corpse—no, it was still alive. The last of the bandits, a boy—barely older than I was when I did the Trial. He was gagged, the cloth ripped into his mouth as he mumbled incoherently.

Faux brought his hand down to loosen the cloth, the boy flinched and his eyes went wide with terror. Faux bent down to meet the boy’s horrified eyes.

“This one’s gonna tell us all about this Drask and his little operation. Ain’t that right, boy?” Faux smirked.

chapters.title: Chapter 16
chapters.content:
The first lights of day had dawned onto the forest we’d set up in. The boy, Osric, was strung to a withering tree, far from the main road. Far enough his screams could not be heard. He tried wiggling around, but the rope only bit deeper into his skin, leaving it raw. The gag bit into his jaw, saliva drooled out of the sides of his mouth as Faux edged closer with a serrated knife, a vicious grin plastered on his face.

“So who’s this Drask one of yer boys mentioned?” He asked, dragging the knife along Osric’s bare throat.

You’re not actually going to hurt him right? Mysha had asked earlier. He’s only a boy.

‘Course not, just need answers outta him, Faux answered reassuringly.

What sympathy did he deserve? Sympathy I hadn’t gotten when I’d been kidnapped from home.

I loosened the gag from Osric’s mouth. He coughed convulsively, trying to regain control of his rapid breathing.

“I don’t know, me swears it—we was just robbing, that’s all!” He tried to put on a brave smile, but it came out as an uneasy grin. “Drask? Me’s never heard of him!”

His voice shook and his eyes glanced nervously around the group, Kerra bared her teeth at him. Kalandyr looked bored, sharpening his blade. Mysha’d climbed a tall branch and kept watch for any other bandits.

Faux’s grin only widened, he pushed the blade harder against Osric’s throat, still not cutting like he’d promised. “Boy, I can tell when yer lyin’. Try again, who’s this Drask?”

“H-h-he’s just some lord ‘round here!” Osric blurted out. His eyes darted between the blade and Faux’s odd grin. “He pays us to patrol the roads, keep watch for any stragglers and bring ‘em back. That’s all me knows, swear it!”

Faux’s grin faltered—like he’d been expecting more of a fight from the boy. “Why would he be payin’ ya? Ain’t yer group a nuisance to him too?”

“We’s supposed to let merchants and official lookin’ folk pass through. Please! Put the knife down!” He begged, tears streaming down his face.

“Quiet, boy!” Kerra snapped, “Or I’ll start taking fingers.”

I watched Osric tremble, tears trickling down his cheeks. Just a kid—no older than I was at the Trial, I thought. But he’d chosen his side—hunting runaways for coin. I had no sympathy for the bastard.

“Faux,” I suddenly said. “Why don’t we… reconvene, discuss over there,” I nodded my head down toward a clearing.

He grunted and I stuffed the gag back in Osric’s mouth. He tried to mumble or beg something, but I couldn’t quite catch it, it just came out as a muffled groan. I fastened the bindings, making sure he couldn’t budge, and walked over to Faux and Kerra.

“Why’re we asking him anything? We killed the bandits already, so let's keep moving.” I said.

“Because, Rand’ar,” he frowned. “We don’t want more of ‘em followin’ after us into Greyport.”

He continued, “Besides, this Drask—he’s got coin, property—probably a manor, maybe some workers locked up. We take him out, we remove a threat and maybe find folks who'll owe us. Never hurts to have grateful people in unfamiliar territory."

“We’ve got a mission. Infiltrate Greyport and report to Astaron. This…” I waved my hands around, at Osric, at everything, “complicates things. Could risk the mission. What if this Drask’s got Sargaryn connections and they find out, then we’re fucked.”

“Drask’s a backwater lord,” Faux said. “No one’s gonna miss him.”

“Doesn’t matter,” Kalandyr cut in. “If we start picking fights with every backwater lord between here and the coast, we’ll be dead before we ever give the signal to Astaron.”

Mysha dropped down from the branch, folding her arms. “So what, we leave these people enslaved, because it's inconvenient?”

“Because it’s a risk,” I said. “It's about not jeopardizing the mission for—"

“For what?” Mysha cut across. “Isn’t this what we do all this for? For people like us?”

“Don’t act like a Northerner,” Kerra snapped at me. “Comfortable in their warm homes, counting their coins. Pretending suffering doesn’t exist because they don’t see it.”

How close you are, Kerra. The irony burned within me. Kalandyr’s eyes flickered to me—a knowing glance. He and Faux knew the truth.

“That’s how they act, Rand’ar,” Mysha said softly. “Pragmatic and practical. They’d let someone else suffer as long as the mission stayed clean.”

“It’s decided then,” Faux said, putting the blade back in his belt. “We’re goin’ to Drask’s. A little detour never hurt anybody.”

I grunted in response. A detour always hurts somebody, especially when we’d be going looking for trouble. Trouble Astaron specifically told us to avoid. What did saving a few broken slaves matter? They’d just roam around miserably until they found a new master, only we wouldn’t be around to save them again, I thought.

If we failed the mission, Astaron would have no use for me. He’d put me back in those deplorable scouting missions—the same mind-numbing patrols he’d assigned me after the Trial. Two years of watching empty roads while the wind bit my skin. I wasn’t ready to go back to that, a tread through the Belt back home was more favorable.

All that time Astaron dangled empty answers about Father in front of me. Said I still hadn’t shown I was in control, shown I was ready to be a leader. How was I meant to show that while watching desolate roads in the mountains. Even now, he’s put me as the youngest one here, so that I can’t lead anyone, I thought bitterly.

All those years and I still hadn’t learnt why Father ever started the rebellion. What made him sacrifice everything for these people. Astaron must’ve known more, but he held back. He’s just stringing me along, using me for my eyes, or so I thought.

“Are we just going along with this,” I hissed in Kalandyr’s ear after the others dispersed. “This is bound to fuck the mission over.”

“What choice do we have?” Kalandyr sighed. “We can’t go on without them. Focus on what you can control, we train while we wait.”

“Practice the Sight. Train. Practice. That’s all it is with you. What good is it if we don’t use that training in the field,” I shot back.

“What do you think’s going to happen in Greyport—we’re going to fight? No, we're here to infiltrate. ” He met my eyes. “You still can’t control your rage, I saw how you didn’t hesitate once—shoved your blade straight through that man’s throat.”

“I remember you doing the same,” I muttered back.

He just stared back at me, something flickered behind those hardened purple eyes.

“Pick up your blade, show me that you have control,” he said, walking toward a clearing in the trees.

I scoffed at him. Astaron told me I had to train with Kalandyr. Said if I didn’t I’d be off the missions.

On the edge of the clearing, Mysha and Kerra practiced with their longbows, seeing who could hit a tree in the distance. Kerra shot wide, swearing as her arrow thudded into the dirt.

“You’re pulling too hard,” Mysha said calmly. “Let the bow do the work.” Her shot struck dead center.

Kerra scowled, “Easy for you to say, show-off.”

“Jealous,” Mysha teased back.

Faux was back to taunting Osric, leering over the bound boy.

I pulled out my sword and my knife. We’d sparred with steels before—Kalandyr trusted me not to kill him, and I trusted the same. I held my sword arm out in front of me, and my knife hand pulled close to my face, ready for anything that got through.

Kalandyr got into his own stance, nothing so simple like our first duel in The Gauntlet. Two blades crossed in front of him, the steels gleamed against each other.

I closed the distance first. Never fight angry, Father’s words echoed in my head. To hell with that, anger was the only thing that’d kept me going all those years.

I thrust my sword at his crossed blades, the steel scraped against his, he shoved it to the side. His swords hissed as they came at me in a blur—left, right, overhead. My eyes tracked the flurry of attacks, but my arms couldn’t keep up.

His left sword broke past my guard, knocking my sword aside, I pushed down—hard—with my knife, creating distance as I pivoted away, breathing hard.

“You’re watching my swords, not me.” Kalandyr said, he didn’t look the least bit tired. “Your opponents’ eyes tell you everything about what they’ll do. Learn to read that, and you won't ever need the Sight.”

Always spouting the same shit, I thought. I desperately wanted to wipe that impassive look off his face—to see the real rage underneath that mask of stone.

Never fight tired, the words resounded in my ears. Tired from the journey, the nightmares, the compounding questions, tired from all of it. I rushed toward him, swinging rapidly like a fly stuck behind a window. He parried each strike with perfection, as if he saw the strikes coming before I’d thought them through.

My eyes flickered to his, there was nothing. His moves weren’t magically imprinted in the purple irises. Just cold focus stared back.

The distraction cost me. Kalandyr’s blade pushed against mine and his other slipped past my guard. In one fluid motion, he pressed my sword arm wide and pressed his other blade against my chest—right over my heart—and swept my legs out from under me.

I hit the ground hard. Dead. Again.

He sneered at me, baring his teeth, then withdrew his blade and turned away.

“You see why we keep training now?” he called back.

I glared daggers at his back in response, rubbing my leg where I'd fallen.

“That boy's a machine. You ask me, I’d say you did pretty good,” Kerra said, holding out a hand.

A machine no doubt, but that’s the level of mastery I needed if I wanted to gain Astaron’s trust in these missions—to gain some independence. The mastery I needed if I was to get my revenge on that wretched woman who’d tortured me. Just thinking about it made me seethe.

I grabbed Kerra’s outstretched hand and pulled myself up from the dirt.

“Thanks,” I muttered, my jaw still tight with frustration.

“You really think this detour’s gonna fuck everything up?” Kerra asked.

“Probably—doesn’t matter now,” I shrugged. “Faux already made the call.”

“And you’re just going along with it?” she narrowed her eyes, hands on her hips.

“What do you want me to say? You guys pushed for it,” I said.

“I just don’t want you messing it up. I can see you’re plotting something behind those purple eyes of yours.”

“You’re not planning on leaving us. Are you, Rand’ar?” Mysha smiled, adjusting the string of her bow as she approached.

“Of course not,” I said quickly. Leave and go where? I still had questions that needed answers, strength that required building. I was stuck with this crew. Competent they were no doubt, but they lacked ambition, a drive for something beyond the mission they’d been assigned. Only Kalandyr matched me in that. I may not have been able to read his moves by staring into his eyes, but I could see he was working towards something.

Kerra picked up my fallen knife from the ground, turned it over a few times before handing it to me, “Where’d you learn to fight like that? I’ve seen you at The Gauntlet—you came in knowing how to use that blade.”

“My father,” I said. The words mulled over in my head. I’d forgotten about that torment of a dream I’d had the night before.

“Marshin father teaching his son to fight?” her eyebrow raised. “Must’ve been expecting trouble.”

“He was always expecting trouble after the Withdrawal,” I looked away. “Didn’t help him in the end.”

“We’ve all lost people,” Mysha said quietly. “That’s why we keep fighting on—so others don’t have to.”

I didn’t answer. Wasn't sure I agreed. I fought purely for myself. Why should I fight for someone else? What does that get me? Pain and despair. But pain I could bear, pain that pushed me towards what I wanted.

Kerra shifted, uncomfortable with the moment's weight. "Well, standing around won't get us to Drask's. Faux looks about done with that boy."

We walked through the trees to where Osric was strung up. Sweat trickled down his face, his eyes darted around nervously between all of us. His trousers were wet, and it hadn’t rained. The kid must’ve pissed himself with fear.

“Boy’s gonna show us to Drask’s,” Faux started. He held up Osric’s head to meet his own eyes. “Aren’t you boy?”

“Y-yes! Yes! Me’s showin’ you the way to Lord Drask,” he put on a nervous smile, refusing to meet anyone’s eyes.

Faux grinned and cut him loose. Osric stumbled, nearly fell before pointing a shaky hand toward the road.

“Days walk normally, but you’s got horses. Could be there by sundown.” He rubbed his raw wrists, then choked out, “Lord Drask’s manor sits on a hill—couldn’t miss it.”

I sheathed my blade, put my knife back in its scabbard. Kerra checked her own blade, Mysha shouldered her longbow. Kalandyr’s expression remained unreadable as always.

A few hours to Drask’s. A few hours before we’d see what freedom truly cost.

chapters.title: Chapter 17
chapters.content:
Our horses trotted along the dirt road, the sound of hooves clattering against the ground, splashing mud onto my trousers. The last hours of sunlight peered down on us through the clouded sky as we travelled through the grassy wetlands. Tall grass spouted out from the shallow pools of water on either side of the road. Nothing moved but the wind swaying the grass. No villages, no farms—just endless stretches of marsh swallowing the horizon.

The marshes had a deep reddish colour to them, algae blooming in the brackish water. It looked like diluted blood. The standing water stood eerily among the swaying grass. The air smelled of rot and iron, insects hummed in clouds above the marsh. No signs of people, as if the land itself had been abandoned. I couldn’t blame the people who’d left, it was a wasteland of bog and mud.

Faux’s horse trotted at the head of our group, his back proud and valiant. Kalandyr rode beside Faux. They were deep in an argument, no doubt about how this was a waste of time and we should be heading for the coast instead. Behind them, Kerra and Mysha rode side by side, leaning close and whispering something that made them both laugh.

I brought up the rear. Osric sat behind me on my horse, bound hands gripping the saddle to keep from falling.

“Never been this far east before?” Osric asked. His voice was shaky, like he was trying too hard to be friendly.

I didn’t answer.

"Me’s grown up 'round here, y'know. My ma’s used to—well, she ain't ‘round no more, but she used to say the marshes got spirits in 'em. Souls of folk who drowned, trapped in the marshes forever. Said that’s why them marshes are red." He laughed nervously. "Load of shit, probably. But still, makes ya think, don't it?"

He got nothing but silence.

“Yous ever seen a spirit before? Me’s ain’t, but me cousin—well—he said he did once, out by the—"

“Osric,” I cut him off flatly. “Shut up.”

He went quiet for maybe thirty seconds.

“It's just, me gets nervous when it's quiet, y'know? Me thinks too much about—”

“Osric.”

“Right. Sorry. Shuttin' up now.”

He lasted another minute before starting up again. Something about how his brother swore up and down about how he’d seen riders clad in white in the waters at night.

“Land’s cursed by the Dark, me swears it! Only the Light keeps it alive.”

“If you’re going to keep talking, talk about Drask. His defenses, his guard, his movements. Whatever you know.”

Mysha loosened up on the reins, slowing her horse down to let us catch up to her.

“Aye. Lord Drask. He’s a fat little man, always smokin’ a pipe. Me family was never toilers—”

Mysha glared at him, tightening her reins.

Osric caught himself, stammering, “Err—never, uh… workers. Slaves. Whatever you lot calls ‘em. Me family was never… that.”

“Get to the point,” I snapped at him.

“Right, err—Drask. He’s got himself a guard of uh… slaves, all grew up thinkin’ he’s their dad or whatever. The guards always pickin’ fights with us freebooters, thinkin’ they better than us cause they devoted to the Light.”

“I don’t care about your problems with them, how many are there?” I asked.

“Me’s gettin’ to it, geez. Reckon there’s at least a dozen spread throughout the village, and at least five he keeps close to him.”

“Why would they think Drask’s their father?” Mysha asked.

“Don’t know, but they’s always callin’ him ‘Lord Father.’ Now that you mentions it, it always gaves me the creeps.” Osric recoiled at the thought.

“And his manor?” I pressed on.

“Me’s never been inside, bein’ a freebooter an’ all. From what the other guys say, he’s got hoards of gold.” He whistled, like the thought of it alone could buy him a new life.

“Are you fucking dense?” I snarled at him. “I don’t care for his money. I want to know how protected it is.”

“Then what do you lot cares for?” Osric said, his voice pitched. “Ain’t that what you’s here to do, rob Lord Drask.”

“We’re not scum like you,” Kerra shouted back. “We’re here for the people you and your lot hunt down for coin.”

“Right.” Osric said defeatedly.

“How come we ain’t seen anyone ‘round here, land looks proper for farmin’ the salt,” Faux called back.

Osric jumped at the opportunity to continue his babbling. “After the Withdrawal, slavers fled for North, leavin’ the workin’ folk to fend for themselves. For a while theys tried to farm the marshes, sell the salts to the merchants in Greyport. But then the floods started comin’ in—worse every year. Drowned half the fields, ruined the harvest. Workin’ folk couldn’t pay theys debts, and merchants stopped comin’. Lord Drask bought up what was left for nothin’. Now he owns all the land, all the salt pans, and all the folk workin’ em.”

“Then why does Drask pay you trash?” Kerra accosted.

“Me’s only heard this from me brothers. But apparently, Lord Drask gets paid by the nobles an’ merchants in Greyport to keep the free workers from runnin’ off. He puts that duty on us,” he boasted pridefully. “He pays our crew to make sure none ‘o the stragglers run off. We brings ‘em back, and Drask hopes he gets a bigger estate.”

He recited the answer like someone’d drilled it into him, perhaps a brother or one of the other bandits.

No one responded. The only sound being the hooves of our horses trudging through the mud and Osric’s nervous breathing behind me.

Our path winded through the red marshes, with no sign of another being, human nor animal, anywhere in sight.

Then Faux came to a sudden stop, my horse almost bumping into Kerra’s.

“What’s the hold up?” Mysha called out.

Then I saw them.

Bodies. Naked and hanging from wooden poles driven into the dirt along the sides of the roads. The bodies were twisted around the poles, their limbs jutting out.

Corpses. They’d been dead a long time. The gray skin peeled as flies buzzed around, beetles feasting on the dried open wounds. The corpses' mouths laid open, their teeth contorted in unnatural ways, like their faces had been hammered into the poles.

“Oh Hand of the Light, protect us.” Faux muttered. He pressed the palms of his hands flat against his chest, fingers splayed. A warding gesture, as if the prayer alone could keep the Dark at bay.

“Boy, what the hell’s goin’ on here,” Faux’s voice quivered. I’d never heard him this shaken before.

Osric muttered something incomprehensible.

“Speak up, boy!” Faux’s voice was rough, quaking with anger.

“The slaves that get caught runnin’ away, Drask beats ‘em bloody and leaves ‘em to rot out here. Lord Drask’s got to keep order somehow. Just how it is,” Osric murmured.

Kerra jumped off her horse, her eyes were seething with rage. She pulled out her knife out of its scabbard and walked toward us.

Osric writhed around behind me, trying to make a run for it. He slipped off the back of the horse and fell head-first into the mud.

“Wait, wait! We still need—” I jumped off my horse and moved towards Kerra.

Without hesitation, she drove her knife across Osric’s neck and cut the boy's throat open. His blood spurted onto the road, pooling into the mud, creating a pile of reddish brown.

Osric convulsed on the ground, gurgling on his own blood. His mouth moved, tried to speak, to beg—but only wet choking sounds came out. Then his movements ceased.

Mysha stared in disbelief—at Kerra. She couldn’t bring herself to look at the bloody ruins of Osric.

“Great,” Kalandyr clapped his hands together, only one still mounted on his horse. “That was our only source of information.”

“Fuck,” Faux breathed. He looked at the body, then Kerra, before his eyes darted away.

“What the hell was that for?” I yelled. “He was a lowlife, but we could’ve used him still. Now he’s a fucking corpse in our way.”

Kerra dragged the corpse off the road and tossed it into the shallow waters. She waded through the reeds, dragging Osric deeper into the marsh. The tall grass bent around him as she shoved his body under the murky water. It sank slowly, the pink algae creeping over his pale skin.

“What’s done is done, he got what he deserved.” She wiped her blade clean and stood there a moment, glancing one last time at where the body sunk, then mounted back on her horse.

It all happened so fast. Kerra just… butchered him, right there in the middle of the road. I’d seen violence before—killed men myself. But that felt different. I suppose it wasn’t, I’d killed Zach the same way in the Trial. And unlike Osric, Zach had been innocent.

The speed—efficiency with which Kerra did all of it, killing him and hiding Osric’s corpse, sent shivers down me. Could she be trusted? I wondered.

I slipped my foot into the stirrup and swung my body up and over the saddle. Now we’re going in blind, no map, no intel on the guards’ position or routines. We’d have to improvise, figure it all out ourselves.

As the sunlight dimmed and we trudged through the lines of corpses strung along the roads—each one more rotten than the last—the road climbed up a hill and we spotted a manor in the distance, Drask’s.

The manor jutted out at the hill’s peak, stone walls rising like a fortress. Below it, halfway down the hill, long barracks stretched in rows, crude stone buildings that were dilapidated and decaying.

“Faux, let’s plan before we move forward.” Kalandyr pulled on the reins bringing his horse to a stop.

We got off our horses and huddled between two dead trees that jutted out like skeletons. Mysha hung back, still silent, her eyes glossy and distant.

“Osric said there were a dozen guards around the village and five on Drask at all times,” I said, taking a bite of dried meat, wondering if it’d be my last meal.

“Assuming they’re trained, we can’t take on all of them at once,” Kalandyr said.

“We hit ‘em at night, guards won’t see us comin’. And with you two’s… sight, we can take ‘em before they raise the alarm,” Faux said.

Kalandyr shook his head, “Too risky, they’ll see five miscreants going around the village before we kill two. We don’t know the layout, patrol routes, nothing.” He glared at Kerra, who scowled back.

“One mistake and we’re fighting the whole garrison,” he continued.

“I have a plan,” I said. “This is a good one.”

We waded through the freezing water, crouched beneath the tall grasses. The water reached up to my knees, cold enough to numb them. It was dark. Even with the Sight, I could barely make out the manor in the distance. The insects clicked incessantly in the shadows.

“Can’t see anything,” Mysha hissed behind me.

“Quiet,” I whispered back, grabbing her arm, and leading her through the standing water.

We reached the base of the hill and crouched behind the tall grass that danced in the soft wind. The back of the hill was a lot steeper and laden with boulders. Enough so that no barracks were constructed. An open climb up toward the manor, but a swift and deadly fall if we slipped down the jagged rocks.

The manor was glowing with soft lighting, the windows casting long flickering shadows on the rocks, imposing even from the bottom where we stood.

“We’re climbing that?” Mysha exclaimed.

“I don’t see how we have a choice.” I studied the path up the pointed rocks, eyeing for handholds. “Can you see well enough from here?”

“I’ll manage.” She tested her grip on a nearby rock. “Just don’t climb too fast.”

I nodded and pointed toward a ledge halfway up, “We can rest there if we need to. Don’t want to rush and slip.”

I grabbed a pointed edge and pulled myself up, nestling my fingers deep between the rocks, squeezing for dear life. Mysha climbed faster than me, taking sporadic nervous glances downward. My soaked trousers dripped with water, making small splashes in the distant rocks below.

I pulled up with my left, then my right arm, careful to hug the rocks as I pulled myself up. My hands were damp, gripping the edges tightly, fingers threatening to slip. The ledges came and went, neither of us wanted to stop and we ascended faster than I’d expected. By the time we hauled ourselves over the top, my arms were shaking, but we’d made it.

I leaned against the stone wall, catching my breath, spreading out my fingers to get the blood flowing again.

We started to edge around the perimeter, searching for a way to get into the second floor, ducking under windows and steering clear of the edge.

We found a narrow open window on the second floor, barely wide enough to slip in, its shutters hung loosely on its hinges. There was a barrel nearby, just tall enough to stand on top of and sneak in through the window.

I crouched beneath the window and pressed my back against the cold stone. Mysha settled beside me, she’d left her bow behind with the horses and opted for her sword instead, which lay in her lap.

Then we waited.

The silence stretched on for a while, the distant sounds of pots and pans clacking and the voices of slaves working inside the house. I could hear distant shouts down the hill—guards perhaps.

Mysha shifted on the ground. “Back on the road,” she said quietly. “When Kerra killed that boy. You tried to stop her.”

I didn’t answer immediately.

“Would you have?” she pressed on. “If you’d reached her in time?”

I sighed and looked off into the distant swamp, or whatever I could see of it, unable to meet her gaze.

“I would, he still had his uses,” I said bluntly.

“Is that the only reason why? Because he was useful?” she asked softly.

I didn’t answer.

“Before Astaron freed us—me and Kerra I mean,” she started. “We were slaves for a man not so different from Drask. I used to work the house, dusting, laundry and whatnot. Kerra used to work the rice fields, her skin used to peel off her back because of the thick heat and I would patch her up. At some point, me and Kerra became close, or as close as people could be in that place. She would tell me she was riling the other workers up, trying to get them to stand up. But the others were scared, scared of leaving the comfort of familiarity behind.”

She sighed, looking up into the sky. The twin moons were locked in their eternal dance, pulling at each other like lovers. “The slaver, Dane, used to tell us we were lucky, that there was nothing beyond the chains for people like us. That we’d just starve and die. He made us believe we needed him.”

“And… I did—I believed him.” A single tear rolled down her cheek. “When Astaron’s people came, Kerra wanted blood, she’d taken a sickle and went on a killing spree, she couldn’t tell the difference between slave and slaver. It took years for me to show her that the problem was the Sargaryns and the North. Not our own people.”

Her voice wavered, “Then when I saw Kerra murder that boy, I thought her old self had come back, that—” She stopped, wiping at her eyes. The tears shone in the moonlight.

I didn’t know what to say, and even if I did, would I have said it? My hand reached for her before I’d thought about it. To comfort her, like I would’ve Daryen or Minarra when they came to me. To fix whatever was wrong.

But my hand faltered and I pulled back.

“Sorry I—” A quiet three-fold whistle pierced the chill air. Kerra’s signal.

Mysha wiped her face and nose. I dragged the hulking barrel right up to the stone wall, helped Mysha up on top, her eyes still red. She grabbed onto the ledge and peeked through the window.

“It’s clear,” she whispered, before climbing through.

I took one last look at the marshes below as I pulled myself up before slipping into the horrors inside.

chapters.title: Chapter 18
chapters.content:
The room was dark and cramped, littered with brooms, dustpans and ragged washcloths. I stood silently behind Mysha, ready to jump back out at the first sign of trouble. She peered through a small crack in the door, the light from the hallway slipping through.

She gasped suddenly and pulled away from the door.

“What is it?” I hissed. She just shook her head, covering her mouth.

I skirted around her and glanced through the angled door. A deep knot formed and twisted around in my stomach. Half a dozen girls, their arms shackled to the walls as they bent forward awkwardly with their hair covering their faces. If I hadn’t known any better, I’d say they were marked by The Abyss itself.

How could anyone—

“Merchants from Greyport you say?” A deep voice bellowed out from down below, cutting through my thoughts. Loud and eager, “Welcome, welcome! It’s rare we receive such distinguished guests in such dark times.”

Then the clattering of boots. The cover must’ve been working.

“Err, yes. We’ve heard you’ve got the best salt in the area, only the finest for the noblemen up North. Rest of the area seems pretty dead.” Faux worked his hardest to cover his thick Southern accent with the rhotic one of a sailor.

Mysha was crouched down against a wall in the dark closet, her eyes downcast and remote.

“Mysha, we have to keep moving.” I grabbed her hands. “We don’t have long but the cover’s working for now. We can still save these people.”

She stayed silent but got up, her face a mask of agony. I craned my neck out of the doorway, checked both sides—clear of guards. I pulled her through the doorway behind me.

We crouched down and slipped past the hollowed girls, they stayed still and silent—save for their shallow breathing, as if we were never there. Mysha’s hand shot out toward one of the chains. I grabbed her wrist.

“We need the key,” I whispered. “We’ll come back for them.”

Her jaw tightened but she nodded, pulling her hand back and following after me.

There was a set of stairs leading down towards the room Drask was entertaining his new guests.

“Amara, brew our pleasant guests some tea, and do it fast.” Drask barked from below.

“Oh, you don’t have to trouble yourself—” Faux started.

“Nonesense! How could I not, you are my honoured guests.”

“Let’s get to business then,” Kalandyr cut through, forthright as always. “What’s your current monthly output? We need reliable supply—the noblemen don’t tolerate delays—”

Faux and Kalandyr had them distracted, we had our cue to stick to the plan.

We creeped down the hallway and I peered through the first room that was lit. Children lay on the floor, thin rags covering their little bodies. An old woman sat next to a laying boy, squeezing his head. She rocked back and forth, humming an old lullaby.

I stepped into the doorway, slowly, my hands visible and away from my sword. Mysha followed behind me. “By the Hand of the Light, we mean no harm to you. We’ve come to free you.”

“What’s you croakin’ about, boy,” the woman said, turning to look toward us. She had a shawl covering her ancient matted hair, the room reeked of sickness and herbs. One eye was pale and glassy while the other studied me suspiciously.

Beyond her, other slaves stirred—two women tending to the children in the corner. Their eyes shook nervously, glancing at the old woman, waiting. She was the one they looked to.

Mysha kneeled down in front of the old woman and matched her tense gaze, “We’ve come to free you from servitude.”

A wry cackle spewed out of her mouth as she continued rocking back and forth. “Only the Lightbearer himself can free us,” she snorted. “And he ain’t comin’ for a thousand years.”

“Forget about that, we can help you leave now. Gather the servants up, we’ll take care of Drask and his guards,” I said, still half-peering at the doorway in case a guard came up the stairs.

“Leave? Why?” She continued her senseless chortle. My blood began to boil, in the hallway women were chained up and there she was laughing as if we’d told her the sky was falling. “We got a roof o’er our heads here, food and clothes. We got a real home. Look at these poor ones, they’d be the first to starve out there.”

“So go, run back to where you came from, we ain’t needin’ your help,” she continued, putting a damp towel on the boy's head.

“You is only gonna bring down trouble on us,” a shrill voice said—one of the other slave women.

“You’re not living here, just coasting along,” I said. It was pointless. They were born in servitude, and they were prepared to die in it. Only the young ones caught my pity—they deserved a chance to live for themselves. The rest of them were weak, couldn’t fight for themselves, couldn’t even see for themselves. Why should I bleed for them?

“There are places out there,” Mysha said, her voice steady despite the tremors in her hands. “Communities of Marshin, people just like you. They can take you in, help you start over.”

“What about the guard? Can they be turned?” I pressed.

“Bah,” she said. “Those fools are devoted to him. Grew up callin’ him Father, thinkin’ he saved ‘em from the gutter. He feeds ‘em well, clothes ‘em, gives ‘em weapons, makes ‘em feel special. They’d die for him ‘fore you’d get a word out.”

“Fool, they ain’t lettin’ us out,” the other slave spat out.

“—best salt in the area, can promise you that. Stay for dinner, try it yourself. Any nobleman’ll taste the quality of it,” Drask bragged from below.
