“Impressive operation you’ve got out here. How do you maintain the quality with the… labor shortages?” Kalandyr asked. His words calm and pragmatic—befitting that of a true Northerner.

“Don’t you worry about the quality, it’ll never go down, by the Light. Come, come! Let me show you the operation.”

The barracks. Where Kerra was supposed to be freeing the field workers, taking down the guard one by one. I could only hope her part was going better than ours.

“How about dinner first?” Faux cut in quickly. “We’ve had a long journey to get here, and I’d hate to tour with my stomach grumbling”

“Hah! Of course! Only the most delicious meals for my guests.” Drask roared. “And after dinner, you’ll want to rest, I’m sure. I can have any of the house girls attend to your…needs, anything you want. My guests deserve the finest courtesy.”

A pause. Then Faux’s voice, lower, softer. “You’re too generous, Lord Drask.”

I turned my attention back to Mysha and the crone.

“— slave once too. I used to get beat in the name of the Light by my master. But I was freed, I can see it now!” Mysha pleaded. “Drask is lying to you, the Light wouldn’t want you suffering like this. If not for yourself, do it for these children.”

The old crone shook her head, “We’ve got to obey the Light, if that means servin’ our masters, that’s what we’ll do. Until it sends for us, we’re stayin’. Now leave ‘fore I call for the guard.”

No wonder Father fled for the North, I thought. Tired of the people stuck in their own loop of self-pity, unable to see the chains bound around their necks. They’re weak, and weak people don’t deserve my effort—my blood, I thought bitterly.

“Fine, stay here. Let us take the children, we’ll give them a better chance at life than you did,” I snarled at the old woman.

“What’s wrong with your eyes, boy,” she croaked, pulling back.

“What if The Light sent us for you? An answer to your prayers,” Mysha said softly.

“You’re askin’ me to sin,” the crone whispered, shaking. “The greatest sin—disobedience. We start disobeyin’ our masters, soon we gonna be disobeyin’ The Light.”

“I’ve kept us safe, kept us blessed.” The crone said, barely above a whisper. She continued her rocking, still shaking her head violently. “Besides, Lord Drask treats us well, needs his company for the evenings. I choose the girls who need blessin’ most. The priests say servin’ the master means servin’ the Light.”

Mysha’s voice began to break, “You chose them? T-Those girls?”

My stomach turned. A blessing? She’d cursed those women, who knows how many others there were before.

A shrill scream pierced the night outside.

“What’s wrong with his eyes?” one of the slaves muttered to the other in the corner. I was too furious to care.

“Better than starvin’ on the streets, or workin’ the marshes.” The crone’s one functioning eye kept glancing at me nervously, the other one, pale and unmoving. “Somethin’s wrong with you, boy.”

“Isela, get away from him!” one of the slaves shouted.

I creeped toward the crone—Isela—slowly. Her shaking increased as she crawled backward toward the wall, covering her wrinkled face with her shawl.

She tried muttering something, but her voice trembled with fear.

“Demon! Demon!” Isela bellowed. “You’ve been sent to tempt us!”

“Quiet!” I hissed. “Mysha, we have to warn Faux and the others. We have to leave, now.”

She looked between me and the old crone, her voice quivered, “What—we’re supposed to just leave them? Look at what they’ve done to them!” her voice pitched.

“I can’t, I can’t leave yet!” Mysha continued. She turned to the other two slave girls, pleading, “Please, he’s not a demon. I can help you, we can protect you.”

They just shook their heads with widened eyes.

All for nothing, we’d come here all for nothing. They were devoted to the lies they’d been sold.

Amidst the crone’s desperate screams, I heard Drask’s voice from below “Should I call for the women, only the finest for—what the hell is that noise, disturbin’ the peace.” His voice quaked with rage.

“It’s from upstairs, Father,” someone said, must’ve been a guard.

“Go quiet them now—aggravatin’ our guests,” he yelled.

Heavy boots thundered up the stairs.

Mysha’s eyes met mine—we were out of time.

I moved to the doorway and looked down. Two guards had made it halfway up the stairs.

Then a loud crashing sound as the main door burst open. I could barely make out Kerra from where I hid, stomping the floor as the guards dragged her to Drask. Blood seeped from a gash on her head, her hands were bound by the guards.

“What’s the meaning of this?” Drask demanded.

“Saw this bitch cuttin’ the locks to the barracks, Lord.”

“How many?” His pockets of fat rolled as he strutted up to her. “How many did you release?”

Horror creeped into his voice.

“Most of them, Father. She killed four of our brothers too,” one of her captors said.

Drask pummeled his fist into Kerra’s jaw, but she took it like a true bellator—didn’t flinch, didn’t scream. My hand immediately went to my beetle bow, which hung at my belt. I donned the bow on my hand, the hold fitting me like a glove. I nocked the arrow and let it loose.

The shaft of the arrow punctured the closest guard’s throat, blood spilling out of his neck. He toppled on top of the other one, sending them both tumbling down the stairs.

Every head snapped toward me.

Drask turned to look up at me. His eyes widened, then narrowed as he looked between me, Faux and Kerra. His face twisted with understanding.

“What is all this? Who are you bastards?” He snarled.

chapters.title: Chapter 19
chapters.content:
Was the freedom we provided preferable over bondage? Was it even freedom if we chose for them?

No, it wasn’t.

We barged in, shattered their world, ripped off their chains, and disappeared. It was just like my capture from Nothello—no choice on my part, yet it was easier to pose the decisions that followed as my own.

The violence—the pain that followed suit, didn’t matter. We’d be branded as heroes, while the dead cursed us from their graves. Their memories were forgotten, while our glory surged.

Just like the Sargaryns did at the dawn of the path, we’d decided that autonomy was superior to subservience.

I can still hear Faux’s blade, the sound of steel scraping steel as he drew his sword.

“Haven’t you heard, old man, Withdrawal was two decades ago.” Kalandyr followed suit, drawing his own sword. “Slaves have been outlawed.”

The guards, all clean-shaven bald, rushed to protect their Lord Father, forming a wall of men all around him. They pointed their spears outward, daring any of us to come forth.

“Merchants from Greyport, eh?” Drask said, sparking his pipe with a quick puff. “I gave you the most delicate courtesies as my guests and you tried to violate my operation.”

He continued, “You think these dirty toilers want freedom? No, they yearn for leadership, for purpose.” He gestured his hands all around the guards who surrounded him. “My sons know this. They could kill me right now—they certainly outnumber me, could overpower me. But they won’t.”

He smiled and took a puff from his pipe slowly, letting the smoke swirl around him. “Because they understand what you never will. Freedom’s a curse for those too weak to wield it.”

Not one guard flinched. No one turned back to look at him, their eyes were set on us. Mysha trembled with rage beside me at the bloodied sight of Kerra.

“Now, I will show you what my sons can do.” He took another long puff, this time blowing the smoke right into one of his son’s faces. “Their corpses, bring them to me, and let us make an example for anyone who dares to dishonor my hospitality.”

He turned and flounced out of the main door, boots heavy on the stone floor. The two guards holding Kerra dragged her after him, her blood leaving a trail behind them.

“Take this one to the post,” I heard Drask bark from outside, followed by Kerra’s muffled shouting.

As Drask left, more of his guards pooled into the manor. Almost a dozen of them, and four of us.

They attacked immediately, splitting into two groups. One for Faux and Kalandyr, the other for me and Mysha upstairs. A silent unison between all of them.

Their heavy boots thudded on the stairs as they rushed up, spears pointed toward us. The bound women made no noise, no movement as the guards thundered past them.

The two in front thrust their spears toward me, careful in keeping their distance from my blade. I weaved between them, the points slipping by my sides, and jabbed my own blade toward one of their throats. A third spear swatted my blade away like a fly and a fourth lunged for my chest. I brought down my knife with all the strength I had, deflecting the tip of the spear. Just enough to create some distance and back away toward the chained woman.

For once, I wasn’t overwhelmed by the sounds and what I saw. The Sight had helped me catch the rapid movements—without it, I’d have been dead. These men were trained, unlike the inadequate bandits who’d simply picked up copper and called it blades.

I had to end it fast, get to Kerra. I could hear her screaming in the distance, Drask’s voice barking orders I couldn’t make out.

My eyes caught the flurry of movement on the other end of the halfway. The other two guards were on Mysha. Their spears glinted in the warm candlelight as they sent powerful jabs toward her, she deflected them—barely. One grazed her shoulder.

The remaining four marched toward me in the narrow hall. A spear plunged toward me, I knocked it aside with my sword—too hard, too wild. The tip veered off its course and tore through one of the chained women’s shoulders. She gave a breathy wheeze before collapsing into her shackles.

The guard pulled his spear back out with his lip curled in disgust, the blood spewing across the wall.

Another whirl of jabs came at me—to my left, my right, above me. I couldn’t keep pushing back, they were pressing me close to the stairs.

I caught a glimpse of the scene below, Kalandyr spun around his opponents with wild fervor but utmost precision. His limbs moved like that of a spider trapping its prey. He swerved between two spears that thrust at him and in one smooth motion, drove his blade across two of the men’s’ throats.

The guards came at me again. I tumbled forward, slipping beneath the point of their spears, and swung my blade in a wide arc, catching one in the leg. The muscles of his leg spasmed as he grunted in pain, dropping his spear. A quick slash across his stomach left him soaking in his blood.

I flipped my knife in my grip and hurled it, with as much precision as one can in chaos. The blade spun wildly in the air before burying itself between the eyes of one of the guards. His eyes rolled back and his hands reached toward his head and trembled, before he toppled down.

The third guard roared and lunged at me. His spear punched through the side of my thigh. My vision went white as the pain shot up my leg and I grabbed my leg with my free hand, screaming. The fourth guard shook his head in contempt and turned toward Mysha, spear raised.

It was just a duel now, me and the one guard. I wiped the blood on my trouser. His eyes tightened as he glanced at the two corpses by his feet. Whatever loyalty he had to Drask, wavered for just a moment.

Long enough.

I reached forward and swung my blade down his head, splitting his face down the middle. He dropped with a loud thud, his spear clattering on the floor.

The chained women looked at me blankly, as if the corpses and the blood pooling around them weren’t there. The one who’d been struck was unconscious, her blood dripped down her shoulder, pooling with the guards’.

A thunder of footsteps rumbled outside, and an influx of raspy voices.

I wrenched the knife free from the dead guard's forehead, gripped the blade firmly in my hands and pulled myself up, wincing with each step. Mysha backed toward the room where Isela continued her pointless screaming. One of the guards lay at Mysha’s feet, his face a bloodied mess. The other two edged toward her.

Pounding shook the door outside and voices roared with rage.

Then, the door crashed, the wood split off its hinges as a mass of people flooded through the door. A cacophony of shrieking and wordless fury came with them.

The freed slaves.

They were armed with crude weapons, if one could even call it that. Salt rakes, shovels, dredging poles, spades, whatever they could find. The crowd rushed in with no sense of formation or order. Pure chaos.

In the horde, I saw thin-limbed and hollowed eyed children no older than eight or nine, screaming at the top of their lungs, desperate sounds of the terrified.

Faces that should’ve been playing in the mud, not the blood. For a moment, I saw Daryen among them, screaming and charging toward a guard. He darted toward the guard, swinging a hook in his hands and before he’d made three strides, the long shaft of a spear protruded out of his chest.

The hook slipped out of his small hands as he crumpled to the floor. Not Daryen, just a boy. Same dark hair and small frame. But a stranger’s face, forever frozen in anguish.

The guard yanked his spear free from the child’s body and moved to the next target without looking back. No regards.

I stood there frozen. Not Daryen, I repeated to myself. Just another mother’s dear son.

But we’d brought them this hell.

A sharp scream pierced my thoughts.

Mysha.

I turned to look at the mess of limbs around her. She was locked in a clash with one of the guards. The other stood nervously behind, hesitating in fear of striking his brother. With one hand pressed down on my leg, I limped towards Mysha. Each passing step sent a sharp pain up my back.

My knife flew from my hands as I flung it at the one colliding with Mysha. It nudged itself deep into the wall behind him, barely missing my mark. I nearly fell as I stumbled forward and swung my blade down the distracted guards back. Not deep enough.

The pain was getting to me, but it wasn’t over yet. Kerra was still out there.

Downstairs I heard the sound of rattling and banging, the sound of screams and cries.

The man’s back arched. He sucked in a deep breath, sharp and wet, and his grip on the spear faltered. Blood seeped through his red tunic where my blade left its mark. The cut wasn’t deep enough to kill him, but deep enough to hurt.

He turned slowly, his teeth bared and lip curled. Mysha pushed back against her opponent and slipped into the room behind her, he thundered after her, leaving me and the last guard in the hallway.

We each stood there, wincing with the pain of our respective injuries. Blood dripped off the wounds on my skin, while beads of sweat lined my forehead.

“Come at me, heretic.” He breathed hard, his back still arched but his spear pointed straight.

I didn’t move. His spear beckoned me forward, so it could make nice holes in my body, but I didn’t move. My leg started to tremble and I shifted my weight to the other, locking my knee in an awkward stance.

I limbed forward, step by step and he pressed further back, his shoulder hitting the wall. He shoved his spear at my throat, my legs faltered, and I diverted the spear with my sword to my right. It grazed my shoulder, not deep, but blood seeped across my tunic.

He’d been trained, but training wasn’t the same as fighting for your life. Every move of his was backed with uncertainty.

His eyes met mine and I sort of grasped what Kalandyr was trying to teach me earlier. I saw fear swirling in his eyes. Not enough to read his moves, but enough so that I knew his hesitation would be his defeat.

I feigned right with my blade, and he pressed it away with the shaft of his spear, leaving me open. I dared him to take the oppurtunity—he hesitated, but he did. He poked his spear at me—weak and uncertain— and I batted it aside with my free hand, gripping the shaft. My blade found its way down his chest.

“Rand’ar!” Mysha rushed forward, her leg soaked with blood. I peered behind her, the other guard’s blood was draped across the wall in the other room. Isela had gone quiet and had opted for prayers instead. Mysha’s eyes glanced between my leg and shoulder nervously.

“How bad is it?” I asked her.

“Bad enough.” She pulled out a piece of fabric from her pack and wrapped it tightly around my thigh. “This’ll stop the bleeding for now, but you’ll need a proper doctor for this.”

She bandaged my shoulder after, pressing the cloth tight against my skin. The pain didn’t dissipate, but in the heat of the moment I hardly felt it.

As soon as she finished, I stumbled for the stairs, gripping the railing firmly.

“Rand’ar, you can’t keep fighting in that state,” her voice shook.

“They’re going to hang Kerra,” I shook my head without looking back. No time to explain.

“I’ll come with you—” she started.

“No,” I cut across. “You unshackle these women, one of the guards must have a key.”

I turned to look back at her, gesturing to the chained women, their eyes downcast and most of their faces hidden behind matted hair. “You’re better at this than I am. They need someone who understands. I’ll find Kerra. Besides, your leg’s as bad as mine.”

She nodded quickly and fumbled the guards pockets for a key.

I walked—tripped down the stairs, leaning on my good leg with each step. Below was chaos incarnate. The freed slaves swarmed around nervously. The first group of guards lay dead, but reinforcements had come. Faux was locked in a fight with two, his sword swung elegantly, deflecting each thrust of the guards’ spears. Kalandyr fought another, his movements precise despite the blood dripping down his forehead.

I trusted they’d have it handled.

I slipped out the door where Faux and Kalandyr’s horses were tethered to a post. I nudged Kalandyr’s horse with my hand before hauling myself up on the saddle, hissing as pain flared through my leg.

Pain seared everywhere in me. Not just my leg and shoulder, but my head and arms as well. The thrill of the battle died and fear settled in its place. The type of fear Father trained me to avoid. But it was inevitable.

I feared the sight I’d see—Kerra strung up against a pole, her face hammered in like the other corpses we’d seen strung on the road.

The freed slaves, they’d fought in the end. Stood brave with us. But why hadn’t they revolted on their own?

I kept nudging my horse down the road, only the twin moons and the pale stars lighting our path. As we trotted further from the manor, the disorderly sounds of battle faded into the night, and was replaced with the sounds of insects chirping away.

I rushed the horse down the road, worried that I was too late—that they’d already finished and ran for it. But in the distance, off the beaten path, I heard hissed shouting. Drask.

I slipped off the horse and followed the sound, careful to stay low and behind the shrubs. They stood in the clearing. Drask towered over Kerra, who was bound to a pole.

He was demanding something, but I couldn’t quite make it out without getting closer. I creeped closer, inch by inch, my blow gloved and the arrow loaded.

“How many others are there?” Drask growled, he’d lost the sense of calm confidence he’d had at the manor earlier.

“Who else knows about my operation?” he pressed on. “Tell me, or I’ll nail your other hand next. My sons won’t hesitate to spill blood.”

Kerra stood in defiance against him, her one hand had a large iron spike nailed through into the pole.

One of the guards held her other hand in place, while the other raised a hammer tauntingly.

The bastards. I only wish I could’ve shown them the scene of their dead brothers sprawled over the floor back in the manor.

I took aim with my bow, targeting the one with the hammer. I took a long breath and pressed down on the trigger. The arrow whizzed through the air and lodged itself into his shoulder.

He doubled over, grunting in pain as Drask and the other guard looked around expectedly for me.

The guard clutched his shoulder, tracing the path of the arrow back to me. His eyes widened and he pointed. “There!”

I drew my blade out of its hold, and stumbled forward. Two guards, one wounded, one fresh. And Drask.

“How the hell did you—” He looked past me back at the manor. “The guards—”

“Are all dead. Or rather, being finished off as we speak.” I pointed my blade between the two guards, “Let her go. Your guards are dead. Your slaves freed. My people will be here any moment.”

“Oh really, I don’t see them here. Looks to me like once we finish you, a message to Greyport will have the King's soldiers combing these marshes for your friends."

I looked at Kerra defeatedly, she only shook her head. This wouldn’t end without blood being spilt.

The uninjured guard yanked his spear out of the dirt and charged at me. Despite my worn state, I read his attack like a book—a quick parry left him reeling into the dirt.

I was stuck between them. The wounded and the unwounded. They both circled me, one’s brow furrowed at me while the other watched me with skepticism.

They both thrust their spears at the same time, I knocked one aside and twisted away from the other, putting too much weight on my wounded leg. Pain shot up my thigh and my knee buckled.

I almost collapsed in the mud right there. Each ounce of pain built on top of the other, pushing me to give up. Standing was an agony, and fighting was anguish. It was easier to lie down than go on.

“Finish it, boys.” Drask shouted from the side. His blade remained in its hilt, as if he couldn’t be bothered to help finish it himself. A task too lowly for him.

Kerra's hand hung from the pole, the blood seeped down onto her head. She watched me with uncertainty, unsure of what to do.

“Up, Rand’ar! Move!” She hissed at me. “The wounded one favours his right! Go left! They die or we do—”

Drask whipped his hand across her face, “Quiet, girl.”

She was right, the wounded one circled to my right, the arrow still lodged in his shoulder. He gargled up blood and spat it out, wiping it with his free hand.

I pushed myself up with my legs. One last fight, I told myself. A lie to get through it. But my body followed suit. My breath whistled as it escaped me.

They both charged at me again, but this time, the moment seemed to slow down. I saw the spittle flying out of the wounded one’s mouth as he roared, the end of his spear dragging along the ground, kicking up mud with it. The other stormed toward me with his thick brow furrowed.

My eyes locked onto theirs as they both came at me head on. The wounded one had a desperate look, like a drowning man gasping for air. The other wore an air of confidence, his strike well telegraphed.

The eyes—like Kalandyr had said. It was all in the eyes! My vision sharpened in the night and despite the pain, the fatigue, I saw everything. I saw Kerra digging her free hand at the nail, wrenching to pull it free. Drask bellowed something at the guards, some threat of what he’d do if they failed. I heard it, but it didn’t matter. The guards pointed their spears at my chest, to strike me, but I saw them. Not just their bodies—their intent, their attack before it ever happened.

It was as if I saw the truth of the world, my eyes and limbs worked in synced tandem. My limbs reacted faster than my eyes, I could see clearly then.

In that moment, I was in tune with my Essence—with The Sight. The guards thrust their spears at me, but I parried each strike away with swift ease, returning the favor by piercing their chests, their throats, their guts—wherever my blade found purchase.

Each strike left my blade bloodier, and their bodies more ravaged. With the last of my strength, I swung my blade at each of their necks, ending their petty lives. Their blood sprayed in my face and they tumbled down at my feet.

I stumbled back and dropped to my knees to catch my breath, the pain all catching up to me, before I heard a strange crunching sound.

Kerra had torn the nail free out of her hand. She’d pounced at Drask, pinned him to the ground and drove the nail deep into Drask’s skull. The mush of his brains flew out with each strike, splattering on her bloodied face. Over and over again, long after he’d stopped moving.

I let her finish.

Eventually her barbarity subsided. She gripped the nail tightly above Drask’s head, letting it slip from her hands. Her injured hand limped at her side as she slipped off his corpse, staring into the mud.

I stared at my own wounded hands in disgust, the pain and the guilt seeped into me. Six men I’d killed that day, and another the night before. Is this the path Father ran from—the one Astaron warned me of, yet sent me on anyway.

Defy the blade, he’d said. No resistance had come from me, I’d fallen for its seductive whisperings again. Forget Father, what would Mother think? I asked myself.

I shook my head fiercely, I didn’t have time for those kinds of thoughts. They were the thoughts of free men, of believers who worried about sin and guilt and penance.

My worries were more immediate—about survival. And the violence had come with a purpose. Who was to say that those wretched souls hadn’t deserved it. The guards were Marshin themselves— had turned on their own people and punished them for trying to leave, strung them up like meat.

This was necessary, I affirmed to myself. We’d freed hundreds, whether they’d wanted it or not.

A groan pulled me back to the mud. Kerra, clutching her mangled hand. She looked at me, face pale, jaw tight.

“Can you ride?” I looked up at her.

She nodded once.

I pushed myself off the ground, grimacing and snarling with each limping step back toward the horse. I hauled myself up onto the horse, every muscle screaming in protest. I helped her up and she grabbed my shoulder with her one good hand, the other hung loosely off the side. The manor awaited in the distance, the lights inside dancing against the dark ink of night.

We rode back in silence.

chapters.title: Chapter 20
chapters.content:
The first lights of dawn creeped in over the horizon as I sat on the stone steps leading up to the manor. Mysha moved between the wounded slaves, her leg trembling with each step.

My own injuries throbbed—where the spear had gone through, bandaged tight but still seeping.

The freed slaves huddled in small groups, some tending to injuries, others deep in worried talk about what comes next.

A small boy, no older than ten, approached me. His hands fidgeted at the hems of his ragged shirt, at the holes and the stained seams. He stopped a few feet away, glancing nervously at me.

“My mother said I should thank you,” he said quietly, eyes fixated on the ground. “So thank you, for freeing us.”

I wasn’t sure if we’d freed them, so I only nodded once.

Mother. The word struck me like a drummer hitting the cymbal.

Astaron had once told me that Sephyra was more than just the wife of Haestus—more than just my mother. She was a raised woman, people came to her for blessings. For guidance when all seemed lost. When she left for North with Father, the rebellion lost more than a guiding figure, they’d lost their faith.

But I didn’t like thinking of her that way. To everyone else, she was a symbol. To me, she was just my mother. The one who comforted me when I needed her most.

One memory stood out from the rest. It was when I was around eight. My parents had forbidden me and my siblings from making friends in school. Too dangerous, they’d said. They didn’t want people asking questions about why Marshin were in the North.

I never understood why. I’d come home crying and furious, seeing the other kids laugh and converse—seeing them happier than me.

On the days I felt worse, I’d often climb up to the roof of our home and watch the people in the streets bustling about. I saw children playing and chasing each other down the teeming thoroughfare.

One day, my mother found me up there and sat down with me. She asked me what was wrong.

After much reluctance, I told her. She listened quietly, nodded along like she understood. Then she stood up and held out her hand.

“Come with me,” she said.

I took it and we walked down from the roof and through the streets together. Her hand was warm around mine and I stayed close. She didn’t ask more questions, didn’t try to fix it with words. We just walked until we’d reached a bakery at the corner of the market square.

I remember jumping up the steps and picking out three of the pastries. We went up to the terrace to eat. The sun set in the horizon, light spilling down on Mother’s auburn hair. The sounds of chatter and people filled the square below.

I finished one, savouring it, the rest remained uneaten on the table. When I finished eating, she leaned in over the table and told me something that stuck with me.

“I have loved you long before you were born and will love you long after I’m gone. If you ever feel alone, remember me, remember this moment. I’ll always be with you.”

She cupped my hands in hers, “One day, Rand’ar, you will help shape a world where children like you need not hide. Remember that.”

I nodded along like I understood. I didn’t, but I was just happy to be there with my mother.

I wasn’t sure I understood it then on those silent steps either. We’d freed most, but left the others screaming in their graves. I thought of the dead children and the ones left orphaned. The guards had held little restraint against the frail slaves. This wasn’t the world I wanted.

The sight of Daryen screaming like a madman and jumping into the fray of violence kept creeping back every time I closed my eyes.

I hugged my knees tighter, my sword lay beside me. The blood had dried and left an odd smell of meat and metal. It would need to be cleaned soon.

Kerra wandered aimlessly behind Mysha, her hand wrapped with thick bandages. Her screams had torn through the night as Mysha applied strong liquor on the wound, while some of the slaves prayed around Kerra for her survival.

Faux settled in beside me, clearing his throat. His breath smelled of stale smoke and coffee, “It’s gonna be a long time ‘fore these folk heal from this.”

“Hmm,” I grunted, not in the mood to talk.

“Kalandyr’s been trainin’ you well, hasn’t he? Heard you took down six of the guard.” He turned with a small smile.

“I did.”

He stayed quiet for a long aching moment, fidgeting with the hilt of my blade. He rolled the long blade in his hands, saw the blood and set it back down.

“I know things didn’t turn out so well. Lots of folk dead. But we did a good thing here, Rand’ar. We can direct these people to one o’ the other colonies, have ‘em rebuild.”

I nodded quietly. I couldn’t shake the feeling we’d made things worse. The orphaned children, the broken families, it would be just like my own. Lost and alone in a dangerous world itching to kill us.

One of the freed slaves, a young woman in a long gown and a tattered head wrap bowed low in front of us.

“May the Light bless your path, sirs.” She said quickly.

“We’re just doin’ what’s right, miss.” Faux beamed, waving as she hurried back to a group of women. They whispered and giggled as she returned.

“Without what we’ve done here, these folk would’ve toiled on for Drask. Now they’ve got the choice to choose their own path forward.” He patted me on the back, “You helped give ‘em that choice. Be proud of yerself.”

I felt no pride, but something more tempered. Resolved.

Like I could tell myself what we’d done was better than the alternative. We’d freed hundreds, given them agency. Astaron had always drilled in our heads that violence was the only answer to the eternal regime of the Sargaryns. It wasn’t the violence that deterred me, but the sense that it was pointless.

I’d never seen a Sargaryn. Even the lowest of their patricians were all holed up in the high Citadel. Their eyes watching all, domineering over all.

But we’d struck something real. Drask was dead, his guards with him in the afterlife. His slaves freed. We’d done something tangible.

I watched the free people move about. Some tended to wounds, others stood around, uncertain of what comes next. Part of me will never understand the adults who’d clung to their chains, clawing at the familiarity of bondage.

They needed that push. In that moment, I was glad we’d made the choice for them. Now they’d have to choose their own path forward. Wherever it may lead, triumph or disaster, the choice would be their own, and that was worth more than all the blood we’d spilled to buy it.

Kalandyr walked up the steps, bandage wrapped around his forehead. He tilted his head at me before turning to Faux.

“We need to point these people to Goldwood Colony. They won’t survive these marshes without direction.”

Faux nodded and got up, shaking off the dirt from his tunic.

“Eat something, Rand’ar. We’ve got a journey ahead of us.” He pulled a map out of his pack and followed Kalandyr down the steps toward a group of people packing food and supplies into an old rickety cart.

The chained women from upstairs huddled together in a corner, still silent. The one who’d been speared was alive, her shoulder wrapped in thick bandages. Mysha had freed them, but they looked even more lost than when they were chained.

After the last of Drask’s guards had been killed, the house slaves made a run for it. They feared the retribution of the freed field slaves. I still remember Isela’s horrid screaming as one of the other women dragged her out of the manor.

You’ve cursed us, boy. You and your damned eyes. Disobedience is the first sin. Mysha’d just shook her head in disappointment.

They wouldn’t survive in the marshes, not without supplies and a destination in mind.

I went down the hill to a quiet place, free from the crowd and chatter to clean my blade. At the edge of a small stream, I rinsed the blade and wiped down the last of the blood, careful to keep the leather-hilt dry. After drying it, I slid the blade back into its scabbard and sat there, staring at my reflection in the water.

This is who I am now. Someone who abandoned my family. A monster, a killer. Another voice creeped in, quieter: a freer of slaves. It felt wrong to call myself that, but it was true. The freed Marshin looked at me with admiration. Some of them gaped at me across the hill where I sat. One group waved me over.

“You sure know how to use that blade of yours, son.” One of them flashed his crooked teeth at me as I approached, shuffling a worn deck.

Three of them sat in a circle on the soft grass, acting free of any worries, bickering amongst each other about something unimportant.

“Play with us, boy. Got room for one more.” An older man, voice strained and rough.

“Alright,” I set down my blade and knelt in the grass beside them.

Cards, something familiar even in that distant land. I’d stayed up late nights with Tommy and Mirvel. Instead of coin, we’d bet dares. Sneaking extra rations from the kitchens, or anything else that would’ve got us whipped if we were caught. Tommy usually paid up.

“Where you comin’ from, boy.” The old man croaked.

“Veylands,” I muttered, sticking to my story.

“Where from? I been there in my years here and there,” he said. His hands shook as he grabbed his set of cards.

“Why’s you care, Milo? Just let the boy play with us.” The one shuffling the deck said, handing me my set.

“I’m just askin’, Jack. Nothin’ wrong with—damn it! Why am I always gettin’ shit for cards.” The others snickered at his misfortune. Each of them held their cards close to their chest, peering at the other, trying to see who’d fold before the game ever began.

“We’re playin’ Sheeps Tower,” Jack said. “You know it?”

I nodded. Tommy had taught me it—high sun cards take the hand, low moons beat the straights.

I studied my own cards, not a bad hand.

Jack tossed a card into the center, “Alright, let’s see what you boys got.”

Milo groaned and snatched a card from the deck, adding to his set. “Damn it, already startin’ bad.”

Jack couldn’t contain himself, a massive grin plastered on his face.

“You’s hidin’ somethin’, Korin,” Jack nodded at the quiet one.

Korin had a sly grin on his face, then slammed three of his cards down in the pile. A groan escaped Jack. Milo’s grin widened—at least he wasn’t the only one losing.

“You’re next, err, what’s your name, boy?” Milo asked.

“Rand’ar,” I put down a card. The old man kept staring at me, like the name didn’t fit what he’d expected.

Then, when he realized it’s his turn, he took one look at his set and snatched another card from the deck, muttering something about bad luck.

“You used up all yours gettin’ that old,” Jack snickered at Milo.

“Keep talkin’ and you ain’t gonna make it to mine.”

“Well, none of you’s makin’ it to the end of this game,” Korin jumped in.

“A quick prayer, and you’ll all be cowerin’ when you see my set.” Old man Milo kissed the back of his cards.

The banter took me away from my worries. Worries of home, of our mission, if we’d survive the coming struggles. The men in front of me had lived harsh lives—each of them had scars along their arms, and a worn look that made them seem older than they were. A life of long labor. Yet even they were able to find joy in the simplicities.

Eventually, Korin slammed down the last of his cards, jumping about, kicking up dirt in the air.

“Rigged from the start,” I muttered, tossing down my cards. I caught myself smiling at Korin’s boyish celebration. When was the last time I’d done that?

“You’re all cheatin’ bastards. I ain’t playin’ with y’all again.” Milo hurled his cards into the dirt. Jack snickered despite his own loss.

“You’re a brave kid, son. But you ain’t got the knack for the cards,” Jack smirked at me.

“Like you’s any better,” Milo snapped from behind. “You know boy, you did a heroic thing there. You and your fellows. The others might not say it, but you saved us from that Drask.”

Korin nodded along quietly, Jack nudged me in the shoulder, “You got the old man gettin’ all soppy.”

Truth was, I had called this quest a distraction earlier, but seeing these men who I’d barely known invite me to play with them touched me in a way I couldn’t describe.

“Where will you all go now?” I asked with sincerity.

“Don’t know. Figure we’ll just go along with the group,” Korin shrugged.

“Always have,” Jack nodded.

“What about you, son?” Milo asked, scratching his beard.

“We’ve got some business in Greyport.”

“Some business, eh? Well, I hope you give ‘em the hell they deserve.” Jack poked at my ribs playfully. “We’ll pray for you, son. You’ve given us somethin’ we never saw for ourselves.”

“You gave me something too,” I said, turning away. “Take care of yourselves, just don’t lose all your coin to Korin.”

I found myself twinged with longing as I walked away. But unlike before, I awaited the trials ahead in Greyport. Astaron had put us on this mission for a reason. A nation of subservient people whose chains had faded but still clung to their necks needed us.

I clutched the hilt of my sword, inspected it one last time before attaching it to the leather belt on my hip.

Whatever tyranny awaited us in Greyport—whatever wickedness, my sword would be ready. The path was ordained, I just had to walk it. Some men would bear witness to my guided steel. Others would fall to it.

chapters.title: Chapter 21
chapters.content:
“Your objective is straightforward,” Astaron pressed over the aged map table in the dark chamber. The candlelight flickered across his stern face. Faux stood beside him, studying a map of the kingdom of Greyport, with a big circle around the city of Walstose.

“You will pose as emissaries on behalf of our King Salem of The Veylands. The previous ruler broke trade relations with Greyport, opting for hostility. You will approach the seated king of Walstose, broker a peace between our two nations and offer to renew trade as it once were before the Withdrawal.”

“The Synod will be your greatest obstacle. They have eyes in every court, ears in every room, they must not discover your true objective. You must identify their agents in Walstose and neutralize them before they report to the Citadel.”

A knot formed in my stomach. The Consecrated Sargaryn Synod. Just the name of it sent chills down my spine. The Synod is what keeps the royal powers in line, ensures that they bend to the wills of the Sargaryn masters.

“Won’t the Citadel find out eventually?” I asked.

“They will. Greyport is but a small kingdom, riddled with internal conflicts, they will think this is one of them. When they send more of their Synechs, we will abide by their followings for a while, until we gather strength enough to root out that curse.”

Astaron eyed each of us grimly. Kalandyr stood with his brow furrowed, Kerra stood next to Mysha, her hand resting on Mysha’s shoulder. Faux scratched the scar along his cheek as he bent over the map, tracing our path from The Gauntlet to our objective. I folded my arms and leaned against the cold stone wall.

“Once you’ve infiltrated the court, you must divert the city guards away from the king, at which point I will bring in the strongest of our forces and we will seat the next king of Greyport.”

“What about reinforcements?” Faux butted in. “Do we have any support from the Veylands?”

“The Veylands is still unstable, I must divert my attention there for the time being.”

The Veylands campaign, the one Astaron told me I wasn’t ready for. I waited for two months as Kalandyr and the others marched off to storm the kingdom, and placed our own puppet, Salem. Astaron had learned a trick or two from our Sargaryn persecutors.

“I cannot spare any forces for you, the conquest is too recent. You will have contacts in Walstose you can trust.” Astaron stood up straight and met Faux’s gaze, “Get this finished, brother, and we will be one step closer to achieving Haestus’ vision.”

Father’s vision. Despite his patronizing of Father’s abandonment, he still worked toward their shared vision. The one I still did not share.

Faux nodded slowly, “We’ll get it done.”

As the others filed out, Astaron motioned me to stay back. He stayed silent a long while, pondering and studying the map. I opened my mouth to speak and he interrupted me before I got a word out.

“You are still our prisoner, Torin Haestus.” Son of Haestus.

He looked at me with a fierce gaze. His eyes searched through the purple of my own. I stared back defiantly. “I am allowing you to undertake this assignment, but I warn you, Faux and Kalandyr have been instructed to kill you if you try to sabotage or abandon the operation.”

I pushed back his threat, I had no intention to leave—not yet. “And if we succeed? When I come back, you’ll tell me about how Father achieved The Withdrawal?”

He hissed a simple, “Yes,” and waved his hand, instructing me to leave the chamber.

That briefing was two weeks earlier. After I left the room, I remember Kerra looking me up and down, holding me with contempt. Her cold eyes stared at me like I was dead weight she’d have to carry. But after Drask’s, something changed. She'd nod at me when our eyes met. Respect.

The sky had changed from cloudy to perpetuate gray, soft rain pouring into the cracks of the stone.

Our horses trotted along the road toward the gates of the port city. The road had transitioned from mud to cobblestone as we approached the gates, the horses snorted at the hard surface, kicking up rainwater with each step.

The big wooden panels of the gate were swung wide and inviting, with layers of aging stone lining the sides. The gatehouse bridge ran above, watch towers erected on either side. Two guards stood watch on the bridge, bored and inattentive. One leaned over the railing, smoking a rolled leaf, while the other barked a harsh laugh.

We passed through the gate uneventfully, just one of many merchants and travellers passing through the city. Only we alone would be plotting against it.

From one danger to the next, it seemed like this was all my life. How I longed for home, to see Remi and the others again. I wondered if Daryen would even recognize me. Would he run into my open arms like he used to? Or would he turn the other way when he saw my scarred hands.

The port city sprawled before us. Somewhere out there, ships left for the North every day. I pushed the dark thoughts away.

In the street, the people bustled about, some vendors shouting about whatever oddments they were selling, while others begged for food on their knees. Amidst the downpour, I saw farmers stringing along carts filled with bags of rice, escorts eyeing travellers with batty eyes and scant clothes, leaving little to the imagination.

In the swarming crowd, I spotted a hooded man who stood in the far corner of the street, eyeing us wearily. I trotted up to Faux and nudged him in the side.

“Faux,” I muttered, nodding my head toward the man closing in on us. Faux had already noticed him.

“It’s fine, he’s one of ours,” Faux said calmly.

He spread his arms as the man approached, as if to embrace the man. “Ahh, Rowan, good seein’ ya.”

The hooded man stopped short of Faux’s horse, keeping his voice low, “You are late.”

“You see, time’s a subjective thing. You wouldn’t call a kid born today late, would ya?” Faux chuckled.

Rowan stared back unamused, his hood clouded most of his darkened face. Rain dripped down the sides of his hood.

“We err, we ran into some trouble on the way,” Faux turned to look at me, Kalandyr and the girls with a sharp glance. “We took care of it though, won’t be a problem no more.”

“We are behind schedule.” Rowan said quickly. You will have to meet the king today, he has been expecting you.”

No respite for us. A day and a half’s journey out of Drask’s to Walstose, and immediately into the machinations.

“I don’t care why you are late, but the king will ask. This isn’t a good look for us, so you better have a good excuse prepared. His guard wouldn’t mind putting our heads on display for dishonoring the king’s hospitality.” He said, pulling his hood lower over his face.

“We’ll think of somethin’, don’t worry.” Faux said, waving away the man’s worries.

“Don’t worry? I’ve been here for two years working shifts at the docks and mucking the stables. Don’t worry, you say? I’ve been gathering scraps of information while you sat clean in The Gauntlet. If you walk in there unprepared and insult the king for his time, all of those years mean nothing—and we’ll hang for it.”

“We’re only two days behind schedule,” I muttered. It was that detour to Drask’s and other complications that had hindered our arrival.

“Yes! Two days! That’s enough to disgrace the king, humiliate our own. What kind of envoys come late to treat with a foreign ruler?”

None of us could say anything. The man felt satisfied winning the argument and with a hiss he turned and started walking up the street.

The hooded man—Rowan—guided us through the thick crowd and wet roads, pushing carts and people aside roughly to make room for our horses.

On either side of the wide boulevard, stood old rickety wooden edifices. The buildings stood short and of shabby make, crudely assembled together. Each building leaned slightly on one side, propped against its neighbor as if it’d collapse without the extra support. No design went into these shoddy buildings—no planning, just wood thrown together for shelter. A far distance from the glorious structures I’d expected in a city of this size.

Children huddled under the stairs of one establishment, mud and soot were engrained in their hands. Some slept under the covering, while others dragged buckets and tools. One reached up and knocked on the door.

In some ways, the city could not be more different from Nothello, the people poorer and the buildings shoddier. In Nothello, it seemed as if every building was designed by an artist, each structure was held up by magnificent stone and were adorned with towering arches. The men would wear linen suits with tall hats while the women wore long gowns, embroidered with depictions of the twin moons.

In Walstose, the men wore loose flowing garbs that were stained or ragged while the women wore tattered shawls and faded skirts that dragged through the mud.

My eyes scanned the streets for any signs of the Synod, but I found only the bustle of merchants, the clatter of worn carts, and the murmurs of locals.

“You have the letter at least, yes?” Rowan turned his head to look at Faux while still trudging forward. Faux only nodded back.

Behind me, Mysha whispered to Kerra, “I didn’t think cities got this big."

“Look,” a sound of awe escaped her as she pointed up at a tower that stood above the rooftops in the distance. Unlike the dilapidated shacks that flanked the street, the tower was made of stone. It stood proud above the rest of the city.

“Still nothing compared to The Gauntlet,” Kerra shrugged. Her injured hand remained wrapped in thick bandages, hanging limply off the side of her horse—no treatment could cure a nail through the palm.

The boulevard winded up a hill and as the king’s palace came into view, so did the surrounding architecture. The closer we got, the more striking the buildings became.

The wooden structures were replaced with towering stone walls. We passed under arches and in between lofty estates. The guard became more present as well. They stood in pairs, posted around each corner. They stood still as statues in the midst of the pouring rain, as if it was never there.

They wore leather armor painted in striking red, water gleaming on their chests. Their arms protected by pointed braces which sat perfectly under the shoulderplates. Their breastplates were made of many layers of leather that were marked by the king’s emblem.

Each guard had a longsword strapped to their hip, the pommel stamped with the same emblem on their chestplates.

As we got closer to the centre of the city, the people grew wealthier. They were aristocrats from the North who’d come here for business and to exploit the desperate Marshin. With cheap labor and low standards, it was easy to see why they would conduct their business here.

A man climbed up onto a heavy cart and barked orders for his two workers to start dragging the cart down the road. The two men were bare chested, the sun gleamed off their backs and sweat trickled down their faces. One stumbled in a dip on the road, and the man lashed him with a stick. I flinched as the sound reverberated off his back.

A bell rang from somewhere deep in the city. Around us, people paused, some just a heartbeat, while others bowed their heads fully.

Faux stopped his horse and brought his head low. Behind me, Mysha and Kerra did the same. The hooded man touched two fingers to his brow, whispering an invocation of protection.

Kalandyr kept his eyes forward, away from the bowed heads. I didn’t move either.

After a moment, the city resumed its noise. Faux urged his horse onward up the street, and we continued as if nothing had happened.

We stopped in front of the gates to the king’s palace. Guards were situated along every post. Beyond the gates and the gardens, stood the king’s grand estate. Towering pillars of handcrafted marble jutted at the sky. Arches and stained panes of glass lined the lofty stone walls, some bore images of crowned figures, others showed priests with hands raised to the heavens engraved upon them. Sharp spires pierced the very sky along regular intervals. Buttressed walls and twisting pillars supported the grand structure.

Around the gates, some people clawed at the guards’ feet, begging to be heard by the king, while others rocked on the floor, hands cupped together, muttering prayers—or curses.

“Give me the letter, I’ll need to show the stamp for the guard to let us in,” Rowan said with an outstretched hand. Faux gave in reluctantly, pulling a neatly folded paper from his satchel.

“We’ve got an audience with the king,” Rowan announced plainly to the nearest sentry.

“Sure, and so’ve all these toilers,” he nodded at the people on the ground, “Get lost before you join ‘em on the ground.”

Rowan waved the Veylandic seal in front of the man. The sentry’s eyes turned wide then narrowed in anger. “I should have you lot killed right here. I lost two brothers fighting you Veylandic dogs.” The man spat as he pulled out his sword. He tried to snatch the paper from Rowan with his other hand, but Rowan was quicker and pulled it back, one hand hovering over the hilt of his knife.

“Cede your prejudices, guard. This is a matter between two kingdoms, not you and me. Turn us away now, and explain to your king why his coffers remain empty, why skirmishes still riddle his borders.”

“Is there a problem here,” another sentry announced loudly from behind Rowan. My hand hovered over my sword, I saw Kerra do the same. Faux held my arm and shook his head.

“We’ll lose,” he whispered. “Let him take care of it.”

“Aye,” the first sentry said, his hand still gripping his sword. “This bastard claims he’s from Veylands, and he’s got an audience with the king.”

“We’ve got a message for peace, and restoring trade. Your king is expecting us.” Rowan bared his teeth and showed the seal again to the second sentry.

His eyes widened when he saw the seal, “Stand down, Langdon.” He barked at his lieutenant. “The king’s been waiting for these envoys all damn week. You nearly turned away the one thing that might save this damned kingdom.”

The sentry—Langdon, slid his blade back into its scabbard. “Sorry sir,” he muttered before touching his chest, invoking a prayer.

“Your weapons, you can’t take ‘em inside,” the man turned to us.

“Course,” Faux muttered and we handed over our swords. I reluctantly handed over my dagger, but I kept the knife in my boot. I didn’t like going in powerless.

“Show them the waiting hall, Langdon,” he nodded toward the palace. He turned to all of us and with the rain dripping down the ends of his mustache, he said, “Welcome to Walstose.”

The heavy metal gates slid open with a loud creak, and our horses slipped through. The crowd tried following us inside but the other guards pushed them back with the threat of their swords.

We slid off our horses and a pair of servants offered to watch them for us. The gardens brimmed with the most vibrant blooms, and the most flowering fragrances. I looked up at the palace itself, at its secret patios and spiraling columns. Figures moved behind the stained glass windows.

Langdon led us through the main doors into a long corridor lined with tapestries and rich carpets.

I was thankful to be free of the constant downpour, but the water had already seeped into every part of my clothes.

He stopped at a set of wooden doors and pushed them open.

“You’ll wait here. The king’ll summon you when he pleases.”

Inside was a narrow hall with a lone bench of stone and a single window overlooking gardens. No decoration, no comfort, and no warmth.

Langdon lingered a moment in the doorway, his hand hovering over the hilt of his sword. “Two years ago, you mutts attacked our villages on the Western front. My brothers died defending them.” His jaw tightened and his eyes narrowed, “So you'll forgive me if I don't bow and scrape for you Veylandic dogs."

With that he turned away and slammed the door behind him. I heard the faint click of a lock.

I sighed and sat down in a corner of the room, opting to not be squished between two people on the bench.

Eventually, Kalandyr settled in beside me. We sat there in silence for a while until the question that had been on my mind came out.

“You didn’t pray when the bell rang earlier,” I said quietly, the other four were locked in their own conversation. Faux gestured wildly about how Rowan nearly got them killed at the gate.

“I didn’t,” Kalandyr said flatly.

“Why not?”

“I don’t believe,” he started, glancing at the door, no doubt fearing the Synod, then back at me. “I don’t believe the Light listens.”

I shifted against the wall, “But everyone else does, look at Faux.”

“Faux and the others, they… It’s easier to believe than to feel abandoned. It’s nice thinking someone’s looking over us, but there isn’t. The Light’s forsaken us, and if it hasn’t, it’s been real quiet.”

He leaned his head back. “Fear and faith look the same from the outside.”

I thought back to Drask’s, the slaves and how they clung to their chains. Disobedience is the first sin, the old crone had said. It sounded like something a presbyter might preach. “So it’s all just control?”

“Always has been,” Kalandyr said.

I wasn’t sure why, but I wanted to argue. Part of me agreed with him, but another part didn’t like the thought that we’d been forsaken. Maybe the Light was guiding us, maybe it had brought me here for a reason, ripped me from home, set me on this path.

“But the freed slaves, they thought we were blessed.”

“Don’t go there. You’re thinking too much of yourself.” He shook his head, “That’s dangerous.”

“Dangerous?” I asked.

His eyes met mine. “You’re not chosen, Rand’ar, you’re just here. Don’t get the two confused.”

He continued, “The Light didn’t guide us here, we’re not blessed. We’re just killers with a cause.”

“And if we fail, would it all be for nothing?”

“Not nothing. We tried.” He paused, then added. “But trying doesn’t free the slaves we left behind, doesn’t bring back the dead.”

“Trying doesn’t kill the Sargaryns,” he added more quietly.

“So then what’s the point? Trying doesn’t matter unless we succeed.”

“The point is we succeed. Or we don’t, and none of this mattered. That’s it, there’s no divine plan, no one guiding our steps. There’s no greater meaning, there’s only results.”

“If we fail, the slaves go back to their chains. The dead stay dead, with no meaning for it.”

“Maybe none,” he said quietly.

“Unless, there’s something guiding us,” I said faintly. “Something that means it won’t be for nothing.”

Kalandyr’s jaw tightened and he shook his head, “There isn’t.”

“You can’t know that for sure,” I said.

“I do know,” he stood up and brushed off the dirt from his trousers, “And the sooner you can accept that, the better.”

He left me with bitter thoughts I couldn’t shake. If he’s right, what am I even doing here? If none of it means anything besides the results, then what does it matter if I stay or not. I should just head back home. Somewhere where I mean something—to people who actually care about me.

“Rand’ar,” Mysha said from across the room. She patted the space beside the bench. “Come sit. You’re stressing me out, sitting there like that.”

I hesitated, before pushing myself off the wall and crossing the room. I took the small space next to her.

“Rowan,” Faux leaned in forward. “It’s been a few years, eh? Must have some stories to tell. Give us somethin’ while we wait.”

Rowan pulled his hood back slightly, revealing locks of hair that flowed down to his shoulders. His face was a dark brown and he had darker eyes. A scar ran down from his eye down to his lip, awfully similar to the one on Faux’s. “What kind of story?”

“You worked the docks, must’ve heard something there,” Kerra said.

“Right.” He thought deeply for a moment. “I shall give you a sorrowful one. One of the dotards at the dockyard told me this one—said it happened before The Withdrawal.”

He paused, letting the room go quiet.

“There was once a young Marshin in service for a great noble in this very city. Early on, the master discovered the boy had a gift, for he could play the harp like no one around. Beautiful, haunting melodies that brought the most hardened men to tears.” Rowan’s voice lowered, “The man dressed his servant in the finest clothes and paraded him like a prized stallion. Every week, after the fourth bell rang, the young Marshin would play for a great crowd in the Risen Square—”

“Risen Square?” Mysha asked.

“A reserved square for nobles only. Commoners weren’t even allowed to pass through after sundown.”

Mysha’s mouth tightened. Kerra’s brow furrowed.

“One night, the square was particularly crowded, and the boy played the most touching piece. Lords and ladies from across the vast kingdom had heard of his great talent and had come to hear it. As the boy played, his eyes caught those of a young woman standing near the fountain. The daughter of a wealthy dock lord—one of the richest families in Walstose."

He paused.

I knew where the story was headed and so I turned away.

“She was beautiful. And she watched him pluck the strings like he was guiding the very stars themselves.”

“They fell in love?” Mysha asked. Kerra snorted.

Rowan nodded with a sad smile. “They did indeed. But it had to be in secret, for no noble shall be with a Marshin. They would meet by the docks after dark, long after the city would go quiet, when the workers had gone home and the nobles were deep in their slumber. For months, they kept it hidden, enjoying each other’s company. He never told her he was Marshin—and she thought he was some talented musician, perhaps the bastard son of a lesser noble. He let her believe it, for he loved her, and she loved him.”

Kerra raised an eyebrow, “She never realized?”

“How could she?” Rowan said. “He wore the fine fabrics of a noble, played in the squares where no Marshin was allowed. To her, he was just a boy with a harp.”

He exhaled slowly.

“Eventually, the girl was with child. And when she told her father she wanted to marry this boy—this musician she loved—it all began to unravel. Her father demanded to know who this boy was, where he was from, what riches did he possess. For his daughter would only marry the finest. When the truth came out…” Rowan shook his head slowly.

“The girl could not handle it, wouldn’t even believe it at first. Then, the shame began to set in, the disgrace of carrying a Marshin child.”

The room had gone silent.

“One morning, after a particularly heavy storm, when the clouds were still grey, and the air still damp. The dockworkers arrived to see the young woman teetering over the edge. The waves were still crashing high, slamming against the wood. They tried to talk sense into her, to make her walk away from the edge, but she threatened to jump if any of them came closer.”

“So they stayed back. She jumped anyway.”

No one said a word.

“The waves held little regard, they took her—took her unborn child with her.” Rowan’s voice was distant. “When the young servant heard what happened, something broke inside him. The dockworkers said his eyes changed, like a dark mist swirled inside the irises. The Abyss had taken him.”

Faux flinched at the word.

“What happened to him?” I asked, already knowing the answer.

Rowan met my eyes, “Synod put him down. Couldn’t risk him turning into something worse. So they slit his throat and tossed his body into the waters, perhaps they both found peace in death.”

He leaned back again, pulling his hood forward.

“When the girl’s father heard that the workers stayed back, that they didn’t stop her…” Rowan let the thought trail off.

“So many lives lost because she loved the wrong kind of person. That's Walstose for you.”

Mysha stared at the floor, Kerra clenched her jaw. Faux cleared his throat but said nothing. Only Kalandyr seemed unbothered, his eyes set out the window.

Taken by the Abyss, like I almost had—no, I had been taken by it. But I’d pulled back. But he was weak, lost himself for some girl, part of me thought. I know now that the torment of the mind is often a far worse agony than the pain of the body. But I didn’t understand that then.

Eventually, we all retreated to our own corners of the room as the wait dragged on. The beams of light through the clouded sky crawled down toward the horizon, yet still they did not call for us. A pair of servants came to give us some food, vegetable soup and warm bread that was surprisingly fresh. No meat, but it filled my stomach well enough.

As the day reached its end, my patience had worn thin. I vowed that whoever would come through the door next, would see the sharp end of my knife unless they got us our audience. Thankfully, the servant who finally appeared, came bearing better news.

“The King will see you now.”

I rose, brushing the dust from my clothes and the doubts from my mind. The doubts of our fates. Either we’d be strung like Rowan had said, or we’d be forming an alliance between two nations. The door swung open, and we followed the servant and a group of sentinels down the wide corridor, toward the throne room, toward whatever horrors the Synod had in store.

chapters.title: Chapter 22
chapters.content:
Our entourage stepped through the great oak doors and the sentinels swung it shut behind us. The walk ahead was for us and us alone.

The chamber hall was made in the shape of an arch. Ornate chandeliers hung from the coffered ceiling. Banners lined the walls on either side, faded red and gold, each bearing the royal crest; a crowned serpent coiled around a ship’s mast, gaping back at me. Some looked centuries old, the ends of the banners withered and worn thin by time.

Guards armed with lances stood at intervals along the walls, still as statues. Courtiers lingered near the walls, some watched us with eager curiosity as we walked toward the raised dais.

“You are in the presence of the great king of Greyport,” a voice droned from somewhere deep in the hall. “Bow in front of King Stynn the Third.”

Faux and the others dropped to their knees immediately—I hesitated just a moment—Kalandyr dragged me down by the hems of my shirt.

He dared not express his contempt, but his eyes were set forward. I followed their trail up to the throne itself. The very platform on which it sat was raised above us, so that all may look up to address the king. It rose above us twice a person’s height, and the throne back reached near the vaulted ceiling. Below the throne, on lesser platforms, were the advisors, each with their own seat looking down upon us.

High above the throne, chiseled out of the darkest of marble, loomed a figure of The Hand of The Light. Six fingered, no thumb, perfectly formed. Two of its fingers curled downward while the rest pointed to the heavens above. No rings, no engravings, no adornments. The Hand needed none, for we could not truly represent its divinity.

I couldn’t shake the feeling like it was watching me.

On the towering throne sat the king himself. An old man—older than Astaron—with greys in his beard and wrinkles on his cheeks. He wore a mantle of crimson red, the hem heavy with gold embroidery that caught the sunlight spilling through the stained glass.

For a moment he said nothing, then he leaned forward in his seat and lifted his hand—two fingers extended, trembling slightly as they pointed.

I followed the gesture, expecting to see a guard or courtier, someone behind us.

But the throne room stretched empty behind our backs.

His fingers were pointed at me.

“I’ve seen your kind before,” The king said, his voice steady and resonant. His eyes moved from Kalandyr to me, before narrowing. “Those eyes. Where exactly did King Salem find his emissaries, I wonder.”

“We’re from The Veylands, Your Eminence,” Faux said, a hint of confusion in his voice.

“Ah,” the king shook his head. “I was asking the lads behind you.”

“Our father was in service to King Salem before he passed,” I answered quickly for both of us. I suppose we were brothers then. “We took up his debt.”

The debt Astaron thinks I owe him.

“Debt, you say?” The king paused for a moment, meeting my gaze. “Does King Salem treat you well?”

Was he trying to turn me? Did he know about the Sight? Has the Synod already discovered us? My eyes darted around the many advisors around the grand throne itself, each seated on their own chair, each reaching higher and higher based on their rank. No faces jumped out at me as one of the Synechs, they were all plain and uninterested. Each sat with their arms folded and looked down at us with disdain.

“He does, Your Eminence,” Kalandyr said plainly.

“Very well,” King Stynn said, disappointment in his eyes. “State your proposal. What is Salem’s business with us?”

“Your Eminence,” Faux began, pulling a sealed letter from a satchel. In his most ceremonious voice, he intoned, “Our kingdoms have bled each other for too long. Border raids, skirmishes over trade routes, villages set ablaze on both sides.” He shook his head. “The previous king of The Veylands saw Greyport as a rival to be crushed, lands to be taken, people to be subdued. King Salem does not share his designs.”

Faux held up the letter, letting the light hit the wax seal.

“He offers peace. An end to all hostilities. Your Western dukedoms remain yours, we lay no claim to them, no demands for reparations. In return, he asks only that trade be restored as it was before The Withdrawal. Open ports, fair tariffs and mutual prosperity.”

The King sat on the back of his seat, leaning his head on one arm. Faux steadied his voice, confident but no trace of arrogance.

“Greyport was once a jewel of the Eastern coast, a centre for trade and commerce. King Salem believes it can be again, with our two kingdoms as partners, not enemies.”

“You would speak poorly of your previous king?” Someone from his court spoke up, a boy who sat nearest to the king, dressed in the robes of royalty. I could only take him to be the king’s son.

Murmurs spread between the many advisors, some turned to whisper in each other’s ear, others remained still and absolute.

“He was not our king. He was only an iron hand that sent our sons to their deaths in a senseless pursuit for land and coin. We did not share his intentions,” Faux said.

Stynn paused for a long moment, eyeing each of our entourage, as if searching for something.

“Guard,” he called out, “Bring me their missive.”

A guard in crimson armour trudged up to Faux, who, still on one knee, held out the letter. As the guard grabbed the letter from Faux’s hand, I saw his eyes peering at me through the slits of his helm.

The guard stopped at the base of the many platforms, not even he was to step upon the raised dais. An advisor in flowing dark robes descended the steps, stooped down to grab the letter and carried it up to the king. He dropped to one knee and with his head lowered, he held out the letter before the king.

King Stynn’s eyes scanned the letter wearily. His eyes widened and narrowed as he read on.

“Salem would cede the Thorngate region?”

“In the pursuit of peace, yes.” Faux replied. “King Salem only wishes for the safety and prosperity of his people, if that means returning a land that was once yours back, then he is prepared to pay that price.”

Faux paused for a moment, perhaps considering what to say next. “Your Eminence, our kingdoms were once the twin pillars of the Eastern coast, let us bring back that glory to—”

Somewhere deep in the chamber, a great door burst open, slamming against the stone, sending a crack that reverberated in the hall.

“Ah, The Veylands.” A man’s voice boomed through the hall, bouncing off the gleaming marble. “Such a rich kingdom, filled with river valleys and plains of wheat. Such a beautiful kingdom yet such an abhorrent people.”

The man’s footsteps preceded him, each one blasting down the marble, a squeaking sound surrounded him, like something dragging along the floor.

“How many diplomatic negotiations have we had with these people?” Everyone on the raised platforms craned their necks to see who had dared to interrupt. Everyone except the King, whose face remained impassive yet his eyes gleamed with fury.

“After the battle of The Laymans, where they lynched innocent villagers, they came to treat for harmony, yet broke it within the first year.”

The man stepped into view beside the platform then. I heard Mysha gasp and Kerra shake her head and turn away in horror.

A man with jet black hair, smoothly combed back, and a blacker uniform to match. He wore the black vestments of a high cleric, crimson threads tracing the King’s brand across his chest, yet no holy symbol of The Light adorned him. A dark cape hung around his neck. By all means the man looked normal, some might even say handsome. If it were not for that repulsive arm that stuck out of his chest.

The man had only one arm, and it stuck out through the left side of his chest, protruding through his tailored uniform. A green, sickly, veined and bloated arm, the skin stretched tight over the coils and muscles that twitched beneath. The flesh glinted with moisture in the light, mottled with patches of rotted skin, yet the strength in them was undeniable. Thick as a grown man’s thigh and a hand as large as an infant’s body. The arm stretched down below his knees like that of an ape.

But the horrors did not end there. A repugnant viridescent liquid dripped out of the pores in his hand, pattering against the marble. Two servants—slaves in all but name—dragged beside him, their legs twisted and useless, pulling themselves forward from their bellies like worms. Their fingers clawed at the marble desperately to keep up with the man, writhing desperately to keep pace with his stride. Each of them carried a basin, holding it out to catch every last drop of the bilious liquid, as if the liquid itself might cure them.

He stooped down beside the platform, his arm reached down and patted, almost tenderly, the head of one of the servants. The poor man tensed up, his eyes went wide with fear before he whispered something inaudible.

The cleric stood back up and continued around the platform stopping in front of the throne to face us, “What about after the Redstone skirmishes? When their raiding parties crossed our borders, yet when we retaliated, they cried foul and demanded reparations.”

He turned back to his king. “Emissaries from another kingdom come to sing in your ear, have they now, my king? Have we not heard these tales before?”

“Archbishop,” the king replied formally, eyes stiff.

“My king.” The Archbishop bowed his head defiantly.

Faux, still horrified no doubt, straightened and cleared his throat. “Your Eminence, the… Archbishop speaks of old wounds—and he is right to remember them, but these events were under the dynasty of the old ruler, one who wronged Greyport. We do not deny this.”

He paused, letting his thoughts catch up.

“But King Salem is not that man. He holds no intentions of violence for the sake of expanding his domain, he only wants to rebuild and let both of our peoples prosper.”

He gestured towards the letter still clutched in the King’s hand. “The lands he offers, the peace he extends, these are not empty words. They are restitution. Words cannot change the past, but they can hold new futures.” He looked directly into King Stynn’s eyes. “Let us write a future we don't regret.”

The king’s fingers drummed on the arms of his throne, eyes darting between Faux and the Archbishop, before resting somewhere in the ceilings above.

“A new king, they may have. But the denizens of that kingdom are the same. Have you all forgotten?” The Archbishop turned and stared each of the many advisors down. “These are the same people who hung our men from their intestines. You would have us treat with these barbarians?” He roared.

“The Archbishop raises a valid concern,” the king started slowly, “The Veylands have given us little reason to trust them.”

He paused, the hall remained silent and tense.

“But..” His gaze lingered on the litter, as if every part of him was conflicted. “...King Salem offers what his predecessor did not. Lands. Trade. Peace.”

Then I saw the Archbishop do what no other man could dare, he walked up the dais, holding out his arm over the edge for the servants to catch the vile liquid from beneath. He trudged up the stairs to the highest throne, not bowing, but standing proud.

“You would trust in Salem’s emissaries? They came to us requesting peace talks, yet they came late. They insult our kingdom,” he turned around, pointing at us with his decrepit hand, then turned back to Stynn. “They insult you, my king.”

The young boy seated just below and to the right of the king spoke up. “He’s right, why have they come late? To keep his Eminence waiting shows contempt, not the respect you claim.”

I saw Rowan shoot the slightest glare in Faux’s direction. All eyes in the room had turned to look at us, to see how we would defend our king’s honor as his emissaries. But Faux faltered, and it seemed like the very air grew hotter in the room.

I moved to step forward, Kalandyr pulled on my arm.

“Don’t!” He hissed, I saw the faintest glow in his violaceous eyes.

I pulled my arm away from him and stepped forward anyway. Gasps rippled through the lesser advisors, some edged forward in their seats. I was not the messenger and so I was forbidden to speak unless spoken to.

The room was quiet and all eyes were on me. Even the Archbishop, still standing beside the king’s throne, narrowed his eyes and tilted his down at me.

“We were attacked by bandits. Bandits from Greyport’s own lands,” I projected my voice, letting it bounce off the distant walls of the chamber. “The bandits stole our king’s missive, and when we demanded for its return, they laughed at us, saying, ‘Can’t even protect your letter, how will you hold the peace?’ Look at the bandages on her hand—we did not escape unscathed.” I pointed toward Kerra’s hand. “Do not, for even a moment, believe we did not do our utmost best to deliver Salem’s message.”

I spared a glance at Faux, who gave me the briefest of nods.

“Then how did you get the letter back?” The king’s son queried.

I appealed to something they had to accept, lest they deny The Light guides the faithful. “Only through The Light’s guidance did we find them, and when we did…” I just shook my head, letting the lie settle in. “The letter remained untouched. By The Light’s mercy.”

“By The Light’s protection, eh? And your own?” The Archbishop asked.

I let the question remain unanswered. The Archbishop’s eyes met my own. But I stood my ground. He could not be one of the Synechs, not with that hideous deformity.

If this falls apart, I could run. The docks aren’t far. I don’t owe anyone here anything.

“Enough Mesa!” The king growled at the Archbishop. Then more quietly and only for the man beside him, he added, “We have had an increasing bandit problem, it is plausible enough. They speak truthfully.”

Only through the revelations of The Sight did I catch that last bit. Kalandyr’s eyes flickered to the throne, he’d heard it too. To everyone else it was a distant whisper.

“Bandits, really?” Mesa’s eyes flickered to mine and Kalandyr’s. “Men with eyes like theirs don’t fall to common thieves. They’ve come here for more than what they claim.” Mesa hissed back, still quiet enough that only the king’s son may have heard.

“You insult us! You insult our guests.” The king’s voice rose, enough so that some of the nearer advisors could hear.

“I insult no one. I may not see the revelations woven into our world, but I see they mean to make a fool of you.” Then loud enough for everyone to hear, he said, “Peace does not exist. It is only a fragile dream. The blade is always half drawn.”

“You’ve been reading too much of that Hierophant’s dogmatic ramblings. I will not have you tarry on this discussion any longer.”

“Father, perhaps you ought to—” The king’s son started.

“Silence, boy.” Stynn cut across. “That is enough from the both of you. I know what is best for these lands.” The King rose from his seat, his leg trembling as he pushed off the arms of the throne. He spread his arms out and said, “I accept King Salem’s offer of peace, and pray for the successes of both our kingdoms. We will reconvene on the morrow to discuss trade, borders and the future of our treaty. Until then, you are my guests.”

I would no doubt be chewed out by Kalandyr later, but I had sold our story—for now. We just had to make it true.
