The Archbishop, Mesa, looked down at me, rage lingering in his eyes. Regardless of if he was with the Synod or not, he had some notions about The Sight, and that could mean trouble for us.

After Faux’s concluding words, a guard led us out of the chamber hall, out of the palace through the gardens to the stable where they kept our horses. The guard escorted us to the Eastern wing of the palace, the guest quarters reserved for dignitaries.

The rooms were rich and comfortable. Stone walls hung with thick tapestries, beds with clean linens and a stained window peering down at the city below, which had begun to light up as the sun went down. A servant brought some bread, cheese and a local drink made with milk, then left us to settle in.

“That went well, right?” I turned to Faux and Rowan.

Faux let out a long breath and dropped onto one of the narrow beds, “Well enough. We’re still alive, and the king’s accepted the offer.”

Rowan leaned against the wall, “He needs this, you saw his eyes when he read that letter—he’s desperate.”

“The Archbishop though…” Mysha frowned. “Mesa. He’s not biting it.”

“No,” Faux agreed. “But he’s just one voice. An important one, but still just the one.” He turned to look at me. “You almost threw it to the vipers with that stunt of yers, Rand’ar. But…” He nodded approvingly, “Quick thinking. That bandit story—it was smart.”

Kalandyr said nothing, his eyes were distant.

“It was reckless, but it worked.” Rowan folded his arms. “Now we just need to make it true, or seem true enough.” He turned to look at Faux, “How are we getting the guards out of this city?”

“I’ve been thinking about that,” I started slowly, finishing the last of the bread. I’d been thinking since that moment in the hall. “We escalate the bandit reports, until Stynn can’t ignore it. Make it look like a real crisis at the borders. We wait till he deploys his legions, and then Astaron swoops in.”

Everyone went silent for a moment, considering my proposal.

“It’s possible,” Kalandyr nodded slowly. “When the Archbishop and the king were arguing, I heard them whisper something about a growing bandit predicament, so it won’t take much to make it seem like it’s spiraling out of control.”

“You heard their whispers?” Rowan tilted his head. “They were thirty or forty feet away, that can’t be.”

“He’s got a good ear,” Faux said, throwing around a rusty coin at the ceiling and catching it before it falls. “It’s why we brought him.” Faux shrugged.

Among all the Bellators at The Gauntlet, only Lord Astaron and Faux knew about The Sight.

“Sure, but how do we grow the problem without getting our own hands dirty?” Rowan asked.

“That’s easy,” Faux chuckled. “We bribe merchants to report attacks on their caravans. Pay off a few scouts to bring in word of raids from the outer villages. You know how talk spreads. ‘Fore long, whole city’ll be fidgetin’ itself half to death.”

“You have the coin for that?” Rowan raised an eyebrow.

“Well, err… Astaron gave us a bit for the journey, but we… we used most of it on the journey here. I was hopin’ you’d have some saved up, seein’ as you’ve been workin’ the docks these years.”

The truth was, we had brought money, but against mine and Kalandyr’s will, Faux had given it to the slaves to help them on their path. We only had enough left to eat for the next few days.

“Of course,” Rowan threw his hands up. “Seems to me you’re always asking me for my money, just like in Ashford.”

“That one’s not fair and ya know it,” Faux chuckled. “Besides, it’s not like ya got a family to take care of or anythin’, Astaron’ll pay you back for it.”

“Speaking of vipers,” Mysha said with a sly grin, cutting the planning short. “I’ve heard they’re everywhere in Greyport. In the gardens, in the streets, some even nest in the attics.”

Kerra’s face went pale. She shifted uncomfortably on the edge of a bed, gripping the pale sheets. “Vipers, of course there’s vipers.” Her voice came out in between shivers. “Probably in the walls… in the beds… waiting in the sheets.” She wrapped her arms around herself. “Hate this city already,” she grumbled.

I retreated from the group and stared out the window. The streets had gone quiet, and the rain had picked up again. The plan was going well, but do I really want to be here? I asked myself.

I looked into the distance, where the mist curled around the buildings, veiling what lay beyond. Somewhere out there in the distance, the dockyards await. My only ticket home.

A pit formed in my stomach just thinking about it. Would I abandon my team in the critical moment?

Yes. I would if it meant I got home, a part of me whispered.

Astaron had made it clear what would happen if I tried to leave, but I was willing to risk Faux and Kalandyr’s blades if it meant seeing them again. My family.

What if Minarra had gotten sick? What if Daryen had done something reckless? The thoughts got darker and darker. What if someone had died? The last one hit me like a knife to the gut. It would be my fault, I’d left them like Father and Mother had left us. I’d left Remi to fend for herself, to raise the other two. A lone tear slipped down my cheek.

I had to try. For myself.

I’d always believed that the best decision is the one I’d least regret. And sitting there, in that foreign city, plotting a war I didn’t fully understand, it was clear which one that was.

I knew I’d regret not trying to go home. Even if it got me killed.

So I waited. I waited till Mysha and Kerra had retreated to the adjoining chamber. I waited till Faux and the others had slipped into the dreams of night.

I slipped on my garb, pulled down my hood, took one last weary look at where Kalandyr slept, terrified I’d see the purple glow behind me. My hand hovered over the knob, shivering in that warm room.

They might call me a coward. A deserter. Astaron might hunt me down. But they weren’t the ones who’d left a family behind.

I gripped my arm with my other hand to stop the shaking. I turned the knob and slipped into the hallway.

The corridor was empty save for a lone guard that yawned at the far end of the hallway, facing away.

The time was ripe.

I turned down the stairs and slipped into the mists of night.
